  <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter at-navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Issue\" >This issue</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"\" selected=&quot;selected&quot;>All  Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</option>\r\n\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                                    <optgroup label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term at-microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049422 id=\"246049422\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper presents a detailed analysis of two giant Lyman-alpha (Ly\u2009\u03b1) arcs detected near galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038 and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754 lensed by the massive cluster MACS\u20091206\u22120847 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.44). The Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae revealed in deep MUSE observations exhibit a double-peaked profile with a dominant red peak, indicating expansion/outflowing motions. One of the arcs stretches over 1 arcmin around the cluster Einstein radius, resolving the velocity field of the line-emitting gas on kpc scales around three star-forming galaxies of 0.3\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.6\\, L_*$|</span> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038. The second arc spans 15 arcsec in size, roughly centred around two low-mass Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitters of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 0.03\\, L_*$|</span> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. All three galaxies in the <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038 group exhibit prominent damped Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption (DLA) and several metal absorption lines, in addition to nebular emission lines such as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb1906, 1908. Extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission appears to emerge from star-forming regions with suppressed surface brightness at the centre of each galaxy. Significant spatial variations in the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profile are observed which, when unaccounted for in the integrated line, leads to biased constraints for the underlying gas kinematics. The observed spatial variations indicate the presence of a steep velocity gradient in a continuous flow of high column density gas from star-forming regions into a low-density halo environment. A detailed inspection of available galaxy spectra shows no evidence of AGN activity in the galaxies, and the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals are primarily explained by resonant scattering. The study presented in this paper shows that spatially resolved imaging spectroscopy provides the most detailed insights yet into the kinematics of galactic superwinds associated with star-forming galaxies.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: evolution&quot;\">galaxies: evolution</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;intergalactic medium&quot;\">intergalactic medium</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: ISM&quot;\">galaxies: ISM</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: kinematics and dynamics&quot;\">galaxies: kinematics and dynamics</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049424 id=\"246049424\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The formation and evolution of galaxies are intimately connected to the properties of the circumgalactic medium (CGM). Characterizing the interactions between galaxies and their surrounding gas, such as gas infall and outflows, is a critical step towards improving our still patchy understanding of the life cycles of baryons and galaxy evolution over cosmic time. But because of the low-density nature of the CGM, studying such tenuous gas has historically relied on absorption spectroscopy along individual QSO sightlines. Over the past few decades, absorption-line studies have yielded sensitive, mostly one-dimensional constraints on the gas density, temperature, metallicity, and kinematics in the circumgalactic space (see the review by Chen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Tumlinson, Peeples\u00a0&amp; Werk <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib133\" data-open=\"bib133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Rudie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>, and references therein). However, uncertainties remain in connecting gas to galaxies in the absence of a spatially resolved two-dimensional map of the gas. To access the spatial information of gas distribution in the CGM, direct detections of the tenuous gas in emission provide a promising avenue. The hydrogen Ly\u2009\u03b1 line, being the strongest emission line expected of photoionized gas at a temperature <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$T\\sim 10\\, 000$|</span> K, provides a sensitive probe of the tenuous CGM (e.g. Osterbrock\u00a0&amp; Ferland <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Draine <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). At <em>z</em> \u2248 2\u20137, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line at 1215 \u00c5 is conveniently redshifted into the atmospheric transmission window and becomes accessible on the ground. In the past two decades, narrow-band imaging and deep long-slit spectroscopic observations have successfully revealed extended line-emitting gas around galaxies (e.g. Adelberger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Rauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Steidel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Xue et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib143\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib143\" data-open=\"bib143\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and QSOs (e.g. Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Cantalupo, Lilly\u00a0&amp; Haehnelt <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Cantalupo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Those observations have shed light on several important physical processes in the CGM, such as the ubiquity of large-scale gas flows on 10\u2013100 physical kpc (pkpc) scales at high redshifts (e.g. Rauch, Becker\u00a0&amp; Haehnelt <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and the non-trivial contribution of star-forming galaxies to reionization (e.g. Dijkstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Matthee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recent advent of high-throughput, wide-field optical integral field spectrographs (IFSs) on large ground-based telescopes, such as the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) on the Very Large Telescopes (VLT) (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the Keck Cosmic Web Imager (KCWI) on the Keck Telescopes (Morrissey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), has brought a significant breakthrough in systematically uncovering extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission in typical, low-mass galaxies as well as QSOs at <em>z</em> \u2248 2\u20137 (e.g. Borisova et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Cai et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Leclercq et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Arrigoni Battaia et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). These sensitive IFS observations have uncovered extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission out to &gt;20\u00a0times the spatial extent of the stellar continuum, and revealed key insights into the physical nature of these extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 sources. For example, significant spatial variations of Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles are directly observed within a single line-emitting nebula (e.g. Rauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Vanzella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib136\" data-open=\"bib136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Erb, Steidel\u00a0&amp; Chen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). In addition, there exists a positive correlation between the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line and the continuum UV brightness of the associated star-forming galaxies (e.g. Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Leclercq et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>), indicating an intimate connection between the origin of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons and star-forming activities (e.g. Dijkstra\u00a0&amp; Kramer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Cantalupo <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple processes can lead to Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission in the CGM, such as fluorescence powered by ionizing photons from star-forming regions or active galactic nuclei (AGNs), cooling radiation, and scattering of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons by mostly neutral hydrogen gas (e.g. Hogan\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Gould\u00a0&amp; Weinberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Cantalupo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Faucher-Gigu\u00e8re et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Kollmeier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Hennawi\u00a0&amp; Prochaska <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Disentangling different processes that contribute to the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal is challenging due to the resonant scattering nature of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons, especially when Ly\u2009\u03b1 is the only observable line feature from the emission regions. At the same time, the detailed double-peaked profiles of spectrally resolved Ly\u2009\u03b1 lines provide a sensitive probe of the underlying gas kinematics. It is expected that Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission originating in infalling and outflowing medium will result in blue-enhanced and red-enhanced peak, respectively (e.g. Dijkstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, and references therein). This has motivated increasingly sophisticated Monte Carlo radiative transfer models that incorporate different gas geometry and kinematics to accurately track Ly\u2009\u03b1 photon scattering and infer the physical properties of the gaseous clouds (e.g. Dijkstra, Haiman\u00a0&amp; Spaans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Hansen\u00a0&amp; Oh <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Verhamme, Schaerer\u00a0&amp; Maselli <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Laursen, Sommer-Larsen\u00a0&amp; Andersen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Schaerer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Gronke, Bull\u00a0&amp; Dijkstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These Monte Carlo Ly\u2009\u03b1 radiative transfer codes can generally reproduce the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 line width based on a combination of thermal broadening and bulk motions, but significant discrepancies are also seen between observations and model predictions (Verhamme et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Kulas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Orlitov\u00e1 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Such discrepancies have both theoretical and observational implications. Theoretically, there is a lot of room for better capturing the physical processes in radiative transfer simulations, such as a realistic treatment of dust attenuation and gas clumpiness (e.g. Laursen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Dijkstra\u00a0&amp; Kramer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gronke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Observationally, as Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons are scattered both in spectral and spacial dimensions, it is critical to obtain observations with not only high spectral resolution, but also high spatial resolution to provide the best constraints on the source environment.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing provides sharpened images of the high-redshift Universe via an enhanced spatial resolution of highly magnified images of distant galaxies (e.g. Coe et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and recently individual, luminous high-redshift stars (Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Massive galaxy and cluster lenses have revealed detailed properties of lensed background sources down to sub-kpc or even as detailed as tens of pc scales (e.g. Livermore et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bordoloi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Berg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Florian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Multiply lensed QSOs and extended, lensed arcs of bright background sources have been used to spatially resolve the diffuse CGM in absorption spectroscopy (Rauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Zahedy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib145\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib145\" data-open=\"bib145\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Lopez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Rubin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Mortensen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Several gravitationally lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae have also been reported, in which the enhanced spatial resolution has aided to reveal the underlying physical environment of the source in greater details (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib131\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib131\" data-open=\"bib131\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Claeyssens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Erb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we present a detailed analysis of two gravitationally lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae, System <em>A</em> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) and System <em>B</em> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), detected in deep MUSE observations of the field around the strong lensing cluster, MACS\u20091206\u22120847 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.44 (hereafter MACS\u20091206). Both nebulae are multiply lensed to form giant tangential arcs in the image plane around the Einstein radius of the foreground cluster, and both exhibit a double-peaked Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile. In particular, the serendipitous alignment of the nebula in System <em>A</em> results in an extended low surface brightness arc of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }\\approx 3\\times 10^{-18}\\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> and \u22481 arcmin in length, comprising three contiguous lensed images (Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), while System <em>B</em> forms an arc of \u224815 arcsec in length with high surface brightness peaks exceeding <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }\\approx 2\\times 10^{-17}\\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>. In addition, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting region in System <em>A</em> consists of two separate nebulae, detached from a group of three continuum sources with one being an <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 1.6\\, L_*$|</span> galaxy and the other two being sub-<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> galaxies. All three of these galaxies exhibit prominent interstellar absorption lines, including hydrogen damped Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption (DLA) in their spectra. One of the sub-<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> galaxies (<em>A</em>3 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> below) is further resolved into two high-intensity peaks. In contrast, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebula in System <em>B</em> exhibits a symmetric morphology in the source plane, centred approximately at two compact continuum sources separated by \u22480.1 arcsec (\u22480.3\u20130.5 arcsec in the image plane), both of which are low-luminosity <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 0.03\\, L_*$|</span> Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitters (LAE) with a rest-frame Ly\u2009\u03b1 equivalent width of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$W ({\\rm Ly\\,\\alpha })\\approx 30\\, \\text{A}$|\u2060</span>.</p>                        <a id=\"246049431\" scrollto-destination=\"246049431\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=MrB3udd7Uroryv2Epfg0yTma3xRx1C904L87fVrbwyPlBDq9OQ35ro~vxSExcgUfWUebxj7RkN9n~fr-kM-6IAXcZIUB7j1UY5NauZzCblC1t1lmVlcgWkqARLOARMr3Ol6WazG1MvyHe1VjW8wdkmNnnG36iCR3jiivbBfxhzGgihHpPKjEwoEQE-KUbaTXtRvkDfwRbP~~nr2TUJCkcXyrWMLILY4SClHqrbtntSwvS6nPL9i4VqQrdPdl-vQMbKBC12lQvc6SjBFtzvCCCL7xFxAVsjfDhjBEVj2L9Q40BBcxXh0H~1YfW7AzGjJvIs6Fcc1yP5BukHDUUx52xQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Composite image of the core region of MACS\u20091206, produced using HST F475W (blue), F814W (green), and F160W (red) images. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System A at a surface brightness of ${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a05.1 below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at z\u00a0= 3.038. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around lensed images of galaxies A1, A2, and A3, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Note that the galaxy A1 at z\u00a0= 3.0364 is magnified but not multiply lensed. Cluster member galaxy Gm1 is located close to lensed images of System A and is individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a03. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is $L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$ (see Section\u00a05.1).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049431/stab1041fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049431\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=Y-ecEzQnwrq38WuslkGLdkIQ9ocCN8RTh0Pt7m~qT81YE5hbDnKqVotmaDCn3vTn3Nkf9JUDmTRTWYHuiKnizibT6SiRDVuNwinMTvgmWZNknrkHkF5B65IU2mE0VKkNcibnB~o-ipU~yGfl5WABUygTHQ-F-CgmQMQ7twvbSyyOKkT1NyqrYPhShegCZ2epxJuyAWUQvSkMaQS6yJVDJxN7wHJJfGrDSZPOZmJbl5in7UqlMSSCWxGNWEVpwUgLN-F3zFd0YAQZeJvDvSfcI03dYbmZhKPulQelxBCWCoTvT0TMxbpx85Gmet-3OZC4He~ihUEgXb1Ix9AAmqKrLA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049431&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Composite image of the core region of MACS\u20091206, produced using <em>HST F</em>475<em>W</em> (blue), <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> (green), and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> (red) images. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System <em>A</em> at a surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around lensed images of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Note that the galaxy <em>A</em>1 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.0364 is magnified but not multiply lensed. Cluster member galaxy Gm1 is located close to lensed images of System <em>A</em> and is individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=MrB3udd7Uroryv2Epfg0yTma3xRx1C904L87fVrbwyPlBDq9OQ35ro~vxSExcgUfWUebxj7RkN9n~fr-kM-6IAXcZIUB7j1UY5NauZzCblC1t1lmVlcgWkqARLOARMr3Ol6WazG1MvyHe1VjW8wdkmNnnG36iCR3jiivbBfxhzGgihHpPKjEwoEQE-KUbaTXtRvkDfwRbP~~nr2TUJCkcXyrWMLILY4SClHqrbtntSwvS6nPL9i4VqQrdPdl-vQMbKBC12lQvc6SjBFtzvCCCL7xFxAVsjfDhjBEVj2L9Q40BBcxXh0H~1YfW7AzGjJvIs6Fcc1yP5BukHDUUx52xQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Composite image of the core region of MACS\u20091206, produced using HST F475W (blue), F814W (green), and F160W (red) images. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System A at a surface brightness of ${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a05.1 below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at z\u00a0= 3.038. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around lensed images of galaxies A1, A2, and A3, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Note that the galaxy A1 at z\u00a0= 3.0364 is magnified but not multiply lensed. Cluster member galaxy Gm1 is located close to lensed images of System A and is individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a03. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is $L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$ (see Section\u00a05.1).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049431/stab1041fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049431\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=Y-ecEzQnwrq38WuslkGLdkIQ9ocCN8RTh0Pt7m~qT81YE5hbDnKqVotmaDCn3vTn3Nkf9JUDmTRTWYHuiKnizibT6SiRDVuNwinMTvgmWZNknrkHkF5B65IU2mE0VKkNcibnB~o-ipU~yGfl5WABUygTHQ-F-CgmQMQ7twvbSyyOKkT1NyqrYPhShegCZ2epxJuyAWUQvSkMaQS6yJVDJxN7wHJJfGrDSZPOZmJbl5in7UqlMSSCWxGNWEVpwUgLN-F3zFd0YAQZeJvDvSfcI03dYbmZhKPulQelxBCWCoTvT0TMxbpx85Gmet-3OZC4He~ihUEgXb1Ix9AAmqKrLA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049431&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Composite image of the core region of MACS\u20091206, produced using <em>HST F</em>475<em>W</em> (blue), <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> (green), and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> (red) images. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System <em>A</em> at a surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around lensed images of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Note that the galaxy <em>A</em>1 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.0364 is magnified but not multiply lensed. Cluster member galaxy Gm1 is located close to lensed images of System <em>A</em> and is individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>).</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"246049432\" scrollto-destination=\"246049432\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=SqpSHO~WoQ5rxZA~2ebCgSh06npMIvr6AtK-IZOqlKgi2ynAmwrr8KzkJGk8zWCBWBlBMyCkI-n~yyDQ-olGH7kf-RXQ3mC3IX6AxXk15ZsOuvTKWLf06GCb9KO9Yhmza1FIbvyIDaR0rCsbyCkurpYF6otnVhMORWPLWizV8E7HwmgT4B80uJ8M0cZ-T1Ly-koYR2f4eakiWYioqPTxX7PtAf0VNZ3uCoXnZ~wNYNOWfBKa09klVsckznO6HM3kEPWr5uTwPWhp~50Nq3mHMjy7ISvLbbhU-3g5pvfPP5fawxXSgt97VSiDHkqKY18u5697~OqNWl7001bi3MzhsQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Same as Fig.\u00a01, while highlighting the configuration of System B. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System B at ${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 5766\u20135796 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a05.1 below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at z\u00a0= 3.754. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around the lensed images of galaxy B consisting of components B1 and B2, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Cluster member galaxies Gm2 and Gm3 are located close to lensed images of System B and are individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a03. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is $L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(9.8\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{41} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$ (see Section\u00a05.1).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049432/stab1041fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049432\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=wuOg18g0zHuao5VnTASXiF6gvSNolRMXB0nslChk82frRdeSADjxWspSVwUQFg~ItIZ-jFf-T6IAsYmWbFbfVS7I1hc2SEhSzl4d5mtAPDCf-ZxvSEUN2rypntUjldSRStZg8axjSDRBSDwaPHRf8~kicjXqWPqL~jLkf2fXw2MzMvYK1yZUUlKWq27mXSN5UGvEPN9SWlMmpnUdrTK4ElgpNRAf3UGLuBodh8Y~Yq-OS3njSc4ffvGif-iyx3hlXkjq-FSAzYlBl~5w70xP4SKuWR1DnHtGKGjcwOnqM0-t7bnz~~kXdO3h-iD6s0LsiAKs3Dx1jl19-Al8zVre7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049432&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Same as Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, while highlighting the configuration of System <em>B</em>. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System <em>B</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, integrated over the spectral window of 5766\u20135796 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around the lensed images of galaxy <em>B</em> consisting of components <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Cluster member galaxies Gm2 and Gm3 are located close to lensed images of System <em>B</em> and are individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(9.8\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{41} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=SqpSHO~WoQ5rxZA~2ebCgSh06npMIvr6AtK-IZOqlKgi2ynAmwrr8KzkJGk8zWCBWBlBMyCkI-n~yyDQ-olGH7kf-RXQ3mC3IX6AxXk15ZsOuvTKWLf06GCb9KO9Yhmza1FIbvyIDaR0rCsbyCkurpYF6otnVhMORWPLWizV8E7HwmgT4B80uJ8M0cZ-T1Ly-koYR2f4eakiWYioqPTxX7PtAf0VNZ3uCoXnZ~wNYNOWfBKa09klVsckznO6HM3kEPWr5uTwPWhp~50Nq3mHMjy7ISvLbbhU-3g5pvfPP5fawxXSgt97VSiDHkqKY18u5697~OqNWl7001bi3MzhsQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Same as Fig.\u00a01, while highlighting the configuration of System B. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System B at ${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 5766\u20135796 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a05.1 below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at z\u00a0= 3.754. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around the lensed images of galaxy B consisting of components B1 and B2, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Cluster member galaxies Gm2 and Gm3 are located close to lensed images of System B and are individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a03. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is $L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(9.8\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{41} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$ (see Section\u00a05.1).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049432/stab1041fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049432\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=wuOg18g0zHuao5VnTASXiF6gvSNolRMXB0nslChk82frRdeSADjxWspSVwUQFg~ItIZ-jFf-T6IAsYmWbFbfVS7I1hc2SEhSzl4d5mtAPDCf-ZxvSEUN2rypntUjldSRStZg8axjSDRBSDwaPHRf8~kicjXqWPqL~jLkf2fXw2MzMvYK1yZUUlKWq27mXSN5UGvEPN9SWlMmpnUdrTK4ElgpNRAf3UGLuBodh8Y~Yq-OS3njSc4ffvGif-iyx3hlXkjq-FSAzYlBl~5w70xP4SKuWR1DnHtGKGjcwOnqM0-t7bnz~~kXdO3h-iD6s0LsiAKs3Dx1jl19-Al8zVre7g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049432&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Same as Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, while highlighting the configuration of System <em>B</em>. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System <em>B</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, integrated over the spectral window of 5766\u20135796 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around the lensed images of galaxy <em>B</em> consisting of components <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Cluster member galaxies Gm2 and Gm3 are located close to lensed images of System <em>B</em> and are individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(9.8\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{41} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this study, we examine the underlying gas flows by combining spatially resolved Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission profiles from MUSE and known star formation properties of the neighbouring galaxies from available <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) broad-band photometry. This paper is organized as follows. First, the archival data included in our analysis are presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a>, including broad-band imaging data by <em>HST</em> and IFS data by VLT/MUSE. The lens models fine-tuned to best reproduce multiple images from Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. In Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>, we present detailed analysis of UV continuum galaxies and the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line-emitting gas, respectively. We discuss our results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a>, and conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a>. Throughout this paper, we adopt a Hubble constant of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0= 70\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub>\u00a0= 0.3, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda = 0.7$|</span> when deriving distances, masses, and luminosities. All magnitudes quoted are in the AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049434 id=\"246049434\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONAL DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MACS\u20091206 is a well-studied cluster, which was first identified as a luminous X-ray source in the <em>ROSAT</em> All Sky Survey (Voges et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib140\" data-open=\"bib140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; B\u00f6hringer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) and later confirmed to be a massive, strong-lensing cluster by the Massive Cluster Survey (Ebeling, Edge\u00a0&amp; Henry <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). It was also selected as one of the 25 clusters in the <em>Cluster Lensing And Supernova Survey with Hubble</em> (CLASH) program (Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Exquisite imaging and spectroscopic data of this cluster field are available in public data archives, including high-quality multiband imaging data from the <em>HST</em>, follow-up galaxy spectroscopic survey data from the CLASH-VLT redshift survey (Biviano et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Rosati et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and wide-field IFS data obtained using VLT/MUSE (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). High-level science products are retrieved from these public data archives for our study. In this section, we provide a summary of these data products.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049436 id=\"246049436\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 <em>HST</em> images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">High spatial resolution, UV, optical, and near-infrared imaging data of the field around MACS\u20091206 obtained using the <em>HST</em> were retrieved from the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST) archive<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> (PI: M. Postman). These include images taken using the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS), the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3), and a suite of UV, optical, and near-infrared filters (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> below). Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> show composite images of the central region of MACS\u20091206 from combining <em>F</em>475<em>W</em> (blue), <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> (green), and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> (red) images, highlighting the lensing configurations of System <em>A</em> and System <em>B</em>, respectively. Detailed photometric properties of each system derived from these <em>HST</em> data are described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the close proximity of <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 in the source plane (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below), it is possible that they correspond to distinct star-forming regions in the same galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. However, without high-resolution infrared data, we cannot determine confidently whether or not <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 originate in the same galaxy. We therefore proceed with referring to <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 as individual galaxies for simplicity.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049439 id=\"246049439\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 MUSE IFS data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field IFS data of MACS\u20091206 were obtained using MUSE on the VLT UT4. The observations were carried out under Program ID\u2019s 095.A-0181(A) and 097.A-0269(A) to cover an effective area of 2.63 arcmin<sup>2</sup> around the cluster in three pointings (PI: J. Richard), which are part of a systematic survey of 12 strong lensing clusters using MUSE (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>). In the region where lensed images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are found, a total exposure time of \u22484\u00a0h was collected. Pipeline-processed and flux-calibrated data cubes were retrieved from the ESO Phase 3 Archive, covering a wavelength range of 4750\u20139300 \u00c5 with a spectral resolution of FWHM \u2248 170 (110) \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> at \u22485000 (7000) \u00c5 and a pixel scale of 0.2 arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.2 arcsec. The mean point spread function (PSF) in the final combined data cube was determined using a bright star, and found to be \u22481 arcsec at 7000 \u00c5. Astrometry of the combined MUSE data cube was recalibrated to match the world coordinate system of available <em>HST</em> images. The pipeline-generated combined data cube contains non-negligible sky residuals that affected the detection of faint emission features. Additional sky subtraction was therefore performed using a median sky residual spectrum generated from object-free spaxels in the data cube. Detailed spectroscopic properties of both continuum sources and Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae are described in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>, respectively. Finally, the wavelength array is converted to vacuum to facilitate accurate velocity calculations based on known rest-frame UV wavelengths.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049441 id=\"246049441\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 CLUSTER LENS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To determine the intrinsic properties of both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, it is necessary to construct a cluster lens model to correct for the gravitational lensing effect. Here, we employ the software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (version 6.5) (Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) to construct a parametric cluster lens model of MACS\u20091206 by incorporating known multiply lensed galaxies identified in the MUSE data (Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and those reported in the literature (e.g. Umetsu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Eichner et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). As both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are in the core region of the cluster, we only include the strong lensing constraints and do not consider weak lensing effect in our lens modelling process. We first obtain a fiducial cluster lens model that gives a good fit to a total of 72 multiple images from 21 background sources. Those images cover a field of view (FOV) of \u22482 arcmin relatively evenly, providing robust constraints for the projected cluster mass distribution within this FOV. We then fine-tune the lens model by considering only multiple images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, optimizing the mass distribution projected close to those particular images as well as the multiply lensed extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae. Details regarding the lens modelling process are described below.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049443 id=\"246049443\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Fiducial cluster lens model</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Following Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we adopt a parametric model based on a pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution (PIEMD) (Kassiola\u00a0&amp; Kovner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>) of ellipticity \u03f5 and include two additional isothermal halo components to represent the cluster-scale diffuse mass. This three-halo configuration is found to minimize the dispersion between predicted and observed image positions for all multiply lensed sources (see Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, for detailed discussions). The convergence of PIEMD is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1619361932826\" content-id=\"update1619361932826\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _\\mathrm{ c} = \\frac{\\sigma _{v}^2}{2\\, G\\, \\Sigma _{\\mathrm{ cr}}\\, \\sqrt{R_{\\epsilon }^{2}+r_{\\mathrm{ c}}^{2}}} ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>R</em><sub>\u03f5</sub> is the distance from the centre of the cluster, defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nR_{\\epsilon }^2 = \\frac{x^2}{(1+\\epsilon)^2}+\\frac{y^2}{(1-\\epsilon)^2},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div><em>r</em><sub>c</sub> is the core radius, and \u03a3<sub>cr</sub> is the projected critical mass density. Given the angular diameter distances between the observer and the lens (<em>D<sub>l</sub></em>), the lens and the source (<em>D<sub>ls</sub></em>), and the observer and the source (<em>D<sub>s</sub></em>), the projected critical mass density is defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1619361989971\" content-id=\"update1619361989971\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Sigma _{\\mathrm{ cr}} = \\frac{c^2}{4\\pi G}\\frac{D_s}{D_lD_{ls}}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>All six parameter of the three PIEMD haloes (x, y, <em>r<sub>c</sub></em>, \u03f5, position angle, velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>v</em></sub>) are free to vary. We also include external shear (parametrized by the intensity \u03b3<sub>shear</sub> and position angle \u03b8<sub>shear</sub>) to account for possible massive structures in regions further away from the cluster core.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the cluster-scale diffuse mass distribution, we account for local perturbations in the vicinity of individual galaxies by including 128 cluster member galaxies in the lens model. These member galaxies are selected based on their redshifts in the catalogue of Molino et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), which is downloaded from the MAST archive.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> We first eliminate galaxies fainter than <em>AB</em>\u00a0= 24 mag in the <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> band. For galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts, we select those with 0.425 &lt; <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub> &lt; 0.453. For galaxies without <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub>, we apply the same criterion based on available photometric redshifts. A total of 128 cluster members are selected from this exercise. Note that in general, the cluster lensing potential is dominated by the large-scale diffuse mass distribution, which is primarily in the form of dark matter. Member galaxies only introduce perturbations local to the location of individual galaxies. Therefore, in cases where lensed images do not appear close to individual member galaxies (\u22645 arcsec, corresponding to typical Einstein radius of individual galaxies), the variation in the selection of member galaxies does not introduce significant uncertainties to the cluster lensing potential. However, in cases where lensed images form close to individual galaxies, careful modelling of those individual galaxies is required to accurately reproduce the positions of nearby images. As our goal here is to obtain a good cluster-scale lens model instead of optimizing individual galaxy mass distributions, we exclude image systems 2, 7, 13, 21, 24, and 27 in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) (see their fig.\u00a01), whose multiple images fall very close to massive cluster member galaxies. This way we do not need to fine-tune every member galaxy with lensed images nearby and still maintain the accuracy of the large-scale cluster lens model.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We include cluster member galaxies as 128 dual pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distributions (dPIE) (El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) located at their detected light centroids, with the ellipticity and position angle fixed to their observed values obtained from the Molino et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) catalogue. The convergence of the dPIE profile is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1619362188013\" content-id=\"update1619362188013\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _g = \\frac{\\sigma _{g,v}^2}{2\\, G\\, \\Sigma _{\\mathrm{ cr}}}\\left(\\frac{1}{R_{g,\\epsilon }}-\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{R_{g,\\epsilon }^2+r_{g,t}^2}}\\right) ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where <em>r<sub>g, t</sub></em> is the truncation radius. To reduce the total number of free parameters, we scale all 128 member galaxies with a constant mass-to-light ratio through <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\sigma _{g,v} = \\sigma _{g,v}^0(\\frac{L}{L_0})^{\\frac{1}{4}}, \\, r_{g,t} = r_{g,t}^0(\\frac{L}{L_0})^{\\frac{1}{4}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>where <em>L</em><sub>0</sub> is the reference luminosity with magnitude <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0= 19.6. Hence there are only two free parameters for member galaxies: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{g,v}^0$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{g,t}^0$|\u2060</span>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Constraints of this fiducial cluster lens model are positions of 72 multiple images from 21 background sources identified by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), excluding image systems 2, 7, 13, 21, 24, and 27 for reasons described above. The optimization is performed based on object positions in the source plane. We obtain similar best-fitting parameters as Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The root-mean-square positional offset between observed and predicted images is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\, {\\rm rms}\\, \\rangle _{\\rm im} =0{_{.}^{\\prime\\prime}} 76$|</span> in the image plane, averaged over all 72 images of 21 sources. The rms position offsets for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are found to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\, {\\rm rms}\\, \\rangle _{\\rm im}=0.38$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\, {\\rm rms}\\, \\rangle _{\\rm im}=0. 73$|</span> arcsec, respectively. In the Appendix, we list the coordinates and redshifts of all 72 images used as constraints, as well as the best-fitting model parameters.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049448 id=\"246049448\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Fine-tuned lens model for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the fiducial cluster lens model described above, we now optimize the lens model for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> separately to ensure the highest accuracy in matching the observed locations of multiply lensed images in these two systems. In the fiducial model, the respective centres of the three cluster-scale PIEMD haloes are located at \u22482 arcsec from the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG), \u224813 arcsec north-west and \u224830 arcsec south-east of the BCG (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA2\" data-open=\"tblA2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a> for a summary). As the south-east cluster-scale PIEMD halo occurs close to the lensed images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, we obtain a refined lens model, leaving all parameters of this PIEMD halo free while fixing the other two cluster-scale PIEMD haloes to their best-fitting parameters in the fiducial model. We also notice that three of the cluster member galaxies (marked as Gm1, Gm2, and Gm3 in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) are located close to some images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. We therefore allow the velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>g, v</em></sub> and truncation radius <em>r<sub>g, t</sub></em> of these three cluster members to vary freely in the fine-tuned model optimization, instead of being scaled together with the rest of member galaxies. Finally, the external shear parameters are fixed to their best-fitting values in the fiducial model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because we are particularly interested in accurately producing the lensing effect for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, we also include constraints from the two substructures of <em>A</em>3 (designated <em>A</em>31 and <em>A</em>32 in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>), and the fainter galaxy <em>B</em>2 in System <em>B</em>, which are not used in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). With a total of 18 multiple images of <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> as constraints (the first 18 entries in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>), we then run <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> again with the above set-up, and obtain a fine-tuned model. This model places significantly more weight on the local perturbers (Gm1, Gm2, and Gm3) and provides much improved root-mean-square positional offsets for the systems of interest in this study. The rms position offsets for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are reduced to rms<sub>im</sub>\u00a0= 0.1 arcsec and rms<sub>im</sub>\u00a0= 0.21 arcsec, respectively. The best-fitting parameters are listed Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA3\" data-open=\"tblA3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a> in the Appendix. In Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show the predicted critical curves by this fine-tuned model for sources at the redshifts of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. Mean lensing magnification factors of multiple images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> based on the fine-tuned lens model are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Wherever required in subsequent analyses, we use this fine-tuned model to derive image position deflections and magnifications.</p>                        <a id=\"246049451\" scrollto-destination=\"246049451\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mean lensing magnification of multiple images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. Calculated based on the fine-tuned lens model as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span
