.\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>1\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>15.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.3\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>10.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>5.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>13.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>6.2\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mu }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mu }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>1\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>15.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.3\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>10.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>5.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>13.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>6.2\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049451\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049452 id=\"246049452\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 ANALYSIS: GALAXY PROPERTIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> comprise two distinct components: (1) the continuum sources detected in the broad-band <em>HST</em> images and (2) the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae that are more spatially extended than the continuum sources and are only visible in the MUSE IFS data. Available broad-band photometry and spectra of the galaxies provide important constraints for the star formation histories and the underlying stellar populations. In this section, we investigate the properties of the galaxies by analysing the photometric and spectroscopic data of the continuum sources. We will present the analysis of the associated Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049454 id=\"246049454\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Photometric properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Accurate photometric measurements of galaxies in Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are challenging due to the crowding of members of the lensing cluster and non-negligible intracluster light (e.g. Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). We first measure broad-band magnitudes of individual lensed images of each galaxy in different bandpasses using a combination of circular and isophotal apertures determined by <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (v.2.19.5; Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). These measurements (presented in the Appendix) are then corrected for lensing magnifications based on the fine-tuned lens model (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 in System <em>A</em>, their <em>b</em> images occur between two bright foreground galaxies, resulting in uncertain background subtraction in the photometric measurements. The de-magnified apparent magnitudes of <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 are therefore determined based on an average of images a and c. The de-magnified magnitudes of <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 in image <em>a</em> are \u22480.2 mag fainter than that in image c, suggesting that the true magnification factor for image <em>a</em> relative to image <em>c</em> is smaller than what is predicted by the lens model. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a> below, we also show that the apparent Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness in the extended nebulae from image <em>a</em> is fainter than what is seen in images <em>b</em> and <em>c</em>, supporting a smaller relative magnification factor at the location of image <em>a</em>. Such a discrepancy in image brightnesses is commonly seen in strongly lensed galaxies and quasars, and is often due to the limited accuracy of lens models and/or the presence of small-scale substructures in the lens (e.g. McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The discrepancy of \u22480.2 mag seen here is within the typical scatter of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim 25{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> between de-lensed magnitudes of multiply lensed galaxies in cluster lenses (e.g. Lam et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>). By averaging the de-lensed magnitudes between images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em>, we therefore mitigate the effect of lensing uncertainty on the magnification of these two galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similarly, the <em>b</em> images of galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 are excluded due to the contamination from the nearby cluster member galaxy Gm3. In addition, image <em>e</em> of <em>B</em>1 is unusually bright compared with its counter part in images <em>a, c</em>, and <em>d</em>, which are between 0.8 and 1.2 mag fainter than image <em>e</em> across different bandpasses after the lensing correction. Such an enhancement in brightness is not observed in image <em>e</em> of <em>B</em>2. This brightness anomaly of <em>B</em>1<em>e</em> can also be seen in the colour image in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and may be attributed to magnification perturbation caused by unseen substructures local to <em>B</em>1<em>e</em> (e.g. McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Consequently, the de-magnified apparent magnitudes of <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 are determined by averaging measurements of images <em>a, c</em>, and <em>d</em>. Finally, Galactic extinction corrections are calculated using the NED Galactic Extinction Calculator<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> and applied to the observed magnitudes in individual bandpasses following the Schlafly\u00a0&amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) extinction map.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For galaxies in System <em>A</em> (<em>B</em>), the bandpasses bluer of <em>F</em>390<em>W</em> (<em>F</em>475<em>W</em>) correspond to rest-frame wavelengths \u03bb<sub>rest</sub> &lt; 912\u00c5, and no fluxes are detected above the background noise. We therefore place a 2\u03c3 upper limit of the observed flux in each of these bandpasses. Unfortunately, these images are not sufficiently sensitive to provide meaningful constraints for the escape fraction of ionizing photons from these galaxies. The final de-magnified apparent magnitudes of galaxies <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> in different bandpasses are presented in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, while the direct measurements of individual images are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a> for reference.</p>                        <a id=\"246049459\" scrollto-destination=\"246049459\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn1\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>.<sup><em>a</em></sup> All magnitudes are de-magnified based on the lens model described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>, and averaged among images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn2\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn2\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of galaxy photometry for System <em>A</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Redshift<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm 1500}^b$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>300<em>W</em><sup><em>c</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>390<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>435<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup> 2\u03c3 flux upper limit.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of galaxy photometry for System <em>B</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>606<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>625<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Redshift<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm 1500}^b$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>450<em>W</em><sup><em>c</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>475<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>606<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>625<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>F</em>775<em>W</em><span aria-hidden=\"true\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>B</em>1\u00a0</td><td>3.7540\u00a0</td><td>\u221217.23\u00a0</td><td>&gt;30.08\u00a0</td><td>29.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.20\u00a0</td><td>29.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>28.94\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>28.69\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>28.81\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>2\u00a0</td><td>3.7540\u00a0</td><td>\u221217.01\u00a0</td><td>&gt;29.99\u00a0</td><td>&gt;30.68<sup><em>d</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>29.59\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11\u00a0</td><td>29.57\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.17\u00a0</td><td>28.91\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11\u00a0</td><td>28.95\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>F</em>850<em>LP</em>\u00a0</td><td><em>F</em>105<em>W</em>\u00a0</td><td><em>F</em>110<em>W</em>\u00a0</td><td><em>F</em>125<em>W</em>\u00a0</td><td><em>F</em>140<em>W</em>\u00a0</td><td><em>F</em>160<em>W</em>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>1\u00a0</td><td>28.80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11\u00a0</td><td>29.29\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09\u00a0</td><td>29.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.05\u00a0</td><td>29.19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.09\u00a0</td><td>29.28\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>29.22\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>2\u00a0</td><td>28.87\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.15\u00a0</td><td>29.15\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td><td>29.11\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.06\u00a0</td><td>29.12\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td><td>28.98\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>28.83\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.07\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn4\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>.<sup><em>a</em></sup> All magnitudes are de-magnified based on the lens model described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>., and averaged among images <em>a, c</em>, and <em>d</em>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn5\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> At <em>z</em>\u00a0= 4, typical star-forming galaxies have <em>M</em><sub>1500</sub>*\u00a0= \u221221.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1 (e.g. Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn6\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup> 2\u03c3 UV flux upper limit, averaged among the <em>F</em>225<em>W, F</em>275<em>W, F</em>336<em>W, F</em>390<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>435<em>W</em> bandpasses.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn7\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn7\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup> 2\u03c3 flux upper limit.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049460\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To characterize the intrinsic luminosities of these galaxies, we also estimate the rest-frame UV absolute magnitudes at 1500 \u00c5, <em>M</em><sub>1500</sub>, using the observed <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> (<em>F</em>775<em>W</em>) brightness for galaxies in System <em>A</em> (<em>B</em>). At the respective redshifts of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, these bandpasses correspond roughly to the rest-frame 1500 \u00c5, and provide a robust estimate of the intrinsic UV luminosity. The absolute magnitudes of <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, <em>A</em>3, <em>B</em>1, and <em>B</em>2, at rest-frame 1500 \u00c5 are found to be <em>M</em><sub>1500</sub>\u00a0= \u221221.52, \u221219.87, \u221219.63, \u221217.23, and \u221217.01, corresponding to 1.61, 0.35, 0.28, 0.03, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.03\\, L_*$|\u2060</span>, respectively, for a characteristic rest-frame absolute magnitude of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0= \u221221 (e.g. Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Reddy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049462 id=\"246049462\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Stellar population parameters</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed broad-band spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of galaxies in Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> based on the photometric measurements presented in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> are typical of star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3\u20134 (e.g. Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). To quantify the star formation histories, we perform a stellar population synthesis analysis using <em>Bayesian Analysis of Galaxies for Physical Inference and Parameter EStimation</em> (<span class=\"small-caps\">bagpipes</span>, Carnall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), which employs the 2016 version of the Bruzual\u00a0&amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) stellar synthesis models. We assume an exponentially declining star formation model, SFR(<em>t</em>)\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>e</em><sup>\u2212<em>t</em>/\u03c4</sup>, where \u03c4 represents the e-folding time and is a free parameter, and infer the stellar mass (<em>M</em><sub>star</sub>), star formation rate (SFR), age and dust extinction (<em>A<sub>V</sub></em>) of the continuum sources in both systems based on the observed SEDs from <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> to <em>F</em>160<em>W</em>. Because of a strong degeneracy between stellar age, metallicity, and dust attenuation (e.g. Conroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), we impose a metallicity prior based on the mass\u2013metallicity relation for high-redshift galaxies (e.g. Ma et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and fix the metallicity of <em>A</em>1 to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$20{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> of the solar value, 10\u00a0per\u2009cent for <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, and 5\u00a0per\u2009cent for <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$16{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span>\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$84{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> confidence intervals in <em>M</em><sub>star</sub>, SFR, age, and <em>A<sub>V</sub></em> are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. All five galaxies are best characterized by a long star formation e-folding time that exceeds \u03c4\u00a0= 1\u00a0Gyr, along with a relatively young, best-fitting stellar age. In particular, the best-fitting stellar ages for galaxies in System <em>A</em> are less than 200\u00a0Myr, making the adopted exponentially declining star formation model equivalent to a constant SFR scenario. This makes the inferred stellar age and SFR insensitive to the adopted star formation history, either exponentially declining or rising (Reddy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). As discussed below, a constant star formation history is also consistent with the spectral features uncovered in the MUSE data. The inferred SFR for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 range between 10 and 100 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm M}_\\odot \\, {\\rm yr}^{-1}$|</span> and <em>M</em><sub>star</sub> between 10<sup>9</sup> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10^{10}\\, {\\rm M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>, typical of UV luminous star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u2248 3 (e.g. Shapley <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). In contrast, galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 have significantly lower SFR and stellar mass with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm star}\\approx 10^8\\, {\\rm M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>, more typical of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitters (LAE) at <em>z</em> \u2248 3 with a characteristic star formation time-scale of \u2272 1\u00a0Gyr (e.g. Feltre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"246049465\" scrollto-destination=\"246049465\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED fitting results, showing <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$16\\,\\, \\mathrm{ per\\, cent}$|</span>\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$84\\,\\,\\mathrm{ per \\,cent}$|</span> confidence interval for each parameter.</p></div> </div><div .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>1\u00a0</td><td>3.0364\u00a0</td><td>[9.93, 9.98]\u00a0</td><td>[89.84, 11.45]\u00a0</td><td>[0.05,0.06]\u00a0</td><td>[1.30,4.38]\u00a0</td><td>[0.62,0.65]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3\u00a0</td><td>3.0384\u00a0</td><td>[9.23,9.27]\u00a0</td><td>[13.02, 0.40]\u00a0</td><td>[0.13,0.53]\u00a0</td><td>[1.26,4.25]\u00a0</td><td>[0.05,0.25]\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>B</em>2\u00a0</td><td>3.7540\u00a0</td><td>[8.43,8.72]\u00a0</td><td>[0.50, 0.91]\u00a0</td><td>[0.43,1.31]\u00a0</td><td>[1.31,4.35]\u00a0</td><td>[0.47,0.74]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049465\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049466 id=\"246049466\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Spectroscopic properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3\u20134, available MUSE data cover the rest-frame wavelength range from \u03bb<sub>rest</sub> &gt; 1200 \u00c5 to \u03bb<sub>rest</sub> &lt; 1920 \u00c5, and provide additional constraints for the star-forming interstellar medium (ISM) and the stellar populations in Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. We extract individual galaxy spectra using spherical apertures centred on the location of the continuum sources, with varying sizes for different images depending on the intrinsic image size and magnification. Because galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 are blended in the ground-based MUSE data, we are only able to extract a single spectrum for these two galaxies. The extracted spectra (without lensing correction) are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, along with the corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectra. For galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, the spectra shown are combined from images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em>, while image <em>b</em> is excluded due to possible contamination from nearby cluster member galaxies. Similarly for <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, image b is excluded from the combined spectrum due to possible contamination from the nearby elliptical galaxy. Note that the brightness anomaly of <em>B</em>1e described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a> does not affect the spectral features due to the achromatic nature of lensing. Image <em>e</em> is therefore included in the combined spectrum.</p>                        <a id=\"246049468\" scrollto-destination=\"246049468\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=4OAdQGvQptKQyvBvtj7zl~v1KN4mIGKLDVbGsIy0s0azge~ES32ez739gVyCJK3yf7yZtF1bviKZZoUVCUQJOeGoV9xvZRyOvmTqnJ4p5nH1K7SSI9q8480Mk32GhCOUuwzZrc1nVE3NFmHC8jQ7cjbsL0GImdTFcVSNBv7CMn03EF9uCwNS~jHjbl22db9tdgbm40jU~TfVjihcotA47Yv30I2EbSz~crX708pnnQyJEoGfXY5C8FHnvuPzx1RyKcdJJx1l1YF7pz-nGPzfTTX9uW5AjR9SlW5gVtXcGnvGKToOPheKL3F8PajUQsJCxqlZXknussW8JDBOHGdc-A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sky-subtracted spectra of Systems A and B without lensing magnification corrections. For A2 and A3, multiple images a and c are stacked. For B1\u00a0+\u00a0B2 combined spectrum, images a, c, d, and e are stacked. Rest-frame wavelength is calculated according to the best-fitting redshift of each galaxy, as marked in their individual panels. The corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectrum is shown in blue in each panel. The red dashed lines indicate major emission features and the green dotted lines indicate major absorption features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049468/stab1041fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049468\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=BtI~4A8-PR8SHKpVFoqedZNbtui4uyq4r50kFNja-vZNRvfZy6bMyb27ywBl4wo3ioeJ7Qg3nXWueh1IU4KYXBRPzf5Y0ABs3p9PvTNiTN9Wepo8Abz0~3gIBRkGjjx2LfZryCKew~JUYJ0UgHuJYCiJVx0OwveRaYvN6OKF9z-ul8zEW3qe5sJSsl3bk9S5DiWo-~7SZDCmcaQ62lY8tMiDwS3-WmurBsnoKFmkzJ91TfEePxHKRc9~29ALhJVf495OI9vfLsu3z6lFv2bwqXwWeA2TydH7aMoto4U59KENY8FoZ0WzcjAhqNB7GOrI0AouMrNJtMZFsL33w6H8rA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049468&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sky-subtracted spectra of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> without lensing magnification corrections. For <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, multiple images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> are stacked. For <em>B</em>1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>B</em>2 combined spectrum, images <em>a, c, d</em>, and <em>e</em> are stacked. Rest-frame wavelength is calculated according to the best-fitting redshift of each galaxy, as marked in their individual panels. The corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectrum is shown in blue in each panel. The red dashed lines indicate major emission features and the green dotted lines indicate major absorption features.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=4OAdQGvQptKQyvBvtj7zl~v1KN4mIGKLDVbGsIy0s0azge~ES32ez739gVyCJK3yf7yZtF1bviKZZoUVCUQJOeGoV9xvZRyOvmTqnJ4p5nH1K7SSI9q8480Mk32GhCOUuwzZrc1nVE3NFmHC8jQ7cjbsL0GImdTFcVSNBv7CMn03EF9uCwNS~jHjbl22db9tdgbm40jU~TfVjihcotA47Yv30I2EbSz~crX708pnnQyJEoGfXY5C8FHnvuPzx1RyKcdJJx1l1YF7pz-nGPzfTTX9uW5AjR9SlW5gVtXcGnvGKToOPheKL3F8PajUQsJCxqlZXknussW8JDBOHGdc-A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sky-subtracted spectra of Systems A and B without lensing magnification corrections. For A2 and A3, multiple images a and c are stacked. For B1\u00a0+\u00a0B2 combined spectrum, images a, c, d, and e are stacked. Rest-frame wavelength is calculated according to the best-fitting redshift of each galaxy, as marked in their individual panels. The corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectrum is shown in blue in each panel. The red dashed lines indicate major emission features and the green dotted lines indicate major absorption features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049468/stab1041fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049468\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=BtI~4A8-PR8SHKpVFoqedZNbtui4uyq4r50kFNja-vZNRvfZy6bMyb27ywBl4wo3ioeJ7Qg3nXWueh1IU4KYXBRPzf5Y0ABs3p9PvTNiTN9Wepo8Abz0~3gIBRkGjjx2LfZryCKew~JUYJ0UgHuJYCiJVx0OwveRaYvN6OKF9z-ul8zEW3qe5sJSsl3bk9S5DiWo-~7SZDCmcaQ62lY8tMiDwS3-WmurBsnoKFmkzJ91TfEePxHKRc9~29ALhJVf495OI9vfLsu3z6lFv2bwqXwWeA2TydH7aMoto4U59KENY8FoZ0WzcjAhqNB7GOrI0AouMrNJtMZFsL33w6H8rA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049468&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sky-subtracted spectra of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> without lensing magnification corrections. For <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, multiple images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> are stacked. For <em>B</em>1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>B</em>2 combined spectrum, images <em>a, c, d</em>, and <em>e</em> are stacked. Rest-frame wavelength is calculated according to the best-fitting redshift of each galaxy, as marked in their individual panels. The corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectrum is shown in blue in each panel. The red dashed lines indicate major emission features and the green dotted lines indicate major absorption features.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectra of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 are characterized by three distinct features: (1) a blue continuum consistent with the broad-band photometry presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>; (2) strong interstellar absorption due to neutral hydrogen and heavy ions (marked in green, dotted line) that are commonly seen in <em>z</em> \u2248 3 galaxies (e.g. Shapley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Erb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and (3) nebular emission lines due to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1660,1666$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1906,1908$|\u2060</span>, as well as excited <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Si ii}$|</span>*\u03bb\u20091264, 1309, and 1530 lines. The strong DLA features observed in the spectra of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 reveal the presence of a significant amount of neutral gas in the ISM of these galaxies. A Voigt profile analysis of the red damping wing at the systemic redshifts of these galaxies (see below) yields best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{H i}$|</span> column densities of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{i}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}=20.9\\pm 0.1$|\u2060</span>, 21.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1, and 21.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1 for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, respectively, indicating a minimum surface neutral gas mass density of \u03a3<sub>gas</sub>\u00a0= 8\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$20\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot \\, {\\rm pc}^{-2}$|\u2060</span>. The best-fitting DLA profiles are presented in the top row of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. Note that the blue-side of the observed DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground and therefore excluded from the fit.</p>                        <a id=\"246049470\" scrollto-destination=\"246049470\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=jBQubozZbKjDKkx~K9MEXV0nUxfAubaYcDeJ20Isa3RGasiznQqD6zpKOArk2p6C91SECoDCDQ7Q1RYHIEGKa0~KwEFcAXGbMUFgV~tLM19jUYUgZlXymnwArGGDP08yJAyHIGZNQvF28EEWL680BqLF-8ZcWgXMiQuPydYtvqRMUGohwY605lh7oc6xZH1fpCKzCqHR5~Raj1zl6NKN5xwXJXponVamVbf3-bUPzCHp7lf0TZQfvJD4z3iDWjrRj~gsNpA1eAYhNAKj0g4pIQL2ogvhjM5~opcDb6XjI3S61OKz0N-End0NnPkO2DETlNiS8QvFY0shF~lPw4fpnw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the ISM absorption and emission features of Systems A (left three columns) and B (right column). Zero velocity corresponds to the systemic redshift determined from nebular emission lines of each galaxy (see Table\u00a05). The red curve in the $\\hbox{H i}$ panels shows the best-fitting DLA profile with the estimated $N({\\rm H\\, i})$ displayed at the top of each column. At negative velocities, the DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground. The $\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$ absorption profiles are presented in the second and third rows, showing blue absorption tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$. The 4th\u20136th rows show the low-ionization lines $\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$, $\\hbox{Si ii}\\lambda \\, 1526$, and $\\hbox{Fe ii}1608$, which exhibit asymmetric absorption profiles with extended blue tails, indicating the presence of gas outflows in the ISM. The best-fitting Gaussian models of $\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$, $\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$, and $\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$ emission lines are shown in red curves in bottom five rows. $\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$ is fitted with a single Gaussian. The doublets are all fitted with a double Gaussian, and the separation between two Gaussian components are fixed by their rest-frame wavelength separation. We fix the flux ratio $\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1666$/$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1660$ \u00a0=\u00a02.5. The redshift is tied to be consistent among all lines in each galaxy, and the best-fitting values (shown at the top of each column) set the zero velocity marked by the vertical dotted line. Data spectrum (continuum normalized) is shown in black, 1\u03c3 error spectrum in blue, and the best-fitting models in red. Flux and rest-frame equivalent width measured from the best-fitting models for each emission line is listed in Table\u00a05. While galaxies B1/B2 display a strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 and modest $\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$ emission features, the data quality is not sufficient to place meaningful constraints on $\\hbox{He ii}$, or $\\hbox{O iii}$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049470/stab1041fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049470\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=nuZCVtOGNlTW6jUy7ZMJfVfSXg0tgeg-Qh1VDcan1KzC3ZdW--gOGlCPlJz3HRjMdSbCdIJHHt5LyaqnLL8pJ61is8Zhl3NopTOECXMLZUwyt3dhzMKXjWY-cXBSCexBG1pHfwivpG18AxijFXHPTDQGOYNC~3vzTH-nyNi2~Rpi7CA-FV2xNzv-8AaguAmmPv8fr7qu77DcTH069nEijqaEsrM1vwGwpv1ogSgXaTLdiebXCKxyfPfHZq47tcenRBf4oILwTiRkguyNmzXe2Wafzh1R3pbBX-z4YByTw8cMFP-3i-pUlIghgeFoh9UU6yrfsIwK9Sq5hhEKzQFHLw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049470&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the ISM absorption and emission features of Systems <em>A</em> (left three columns) and <em>B</em> (right column). Zero velocity corresponds to the systemic redshift determined from nebular emission lines of each galaxy (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). The red curve in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{H i}$|</span> panels shows the best-fitting DLA profile with the estimated <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N({\\rm H\\, i})$|</span> displayed at the top of each column. At negative velocities, the DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> absorption profiles are presented in the second and third rows, showing blue absorption tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. The 4th\u20136th rows show the low-ionization lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Si ii}\\lambda \\, 1526$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Fe ii}1608$|\u2060</span>, which exhibit asymmetric absorption profiles with extended blue tails, indicating the presence of gas outflows in the ISM. The best-fitting Gaussian models of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$|</span> emission lines are shown in red curves in bottom five rows. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|</span> is fitted with a single Gaussian. The doublets are all fitted with a double Gaussian, and the separation between two Gaussian components are fixed by their rest-frame wavelength separation. We fix the flux ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1666$|</span>/<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1660$|</span> \u00a0=\u00a02.5. The redshift is tied to be consistent among all lines in each galaxy, and the best-fitting values (shown at the top of each column) set the zero velocity marked by the vertical dotted line. Data spectrum (continuum normalized) is shown in black, 1\u03c3 error spectrum in blue, and the best-fitting models in red. Flux and rest-frame equivalent width measured from the best-fitting models for each emission line is listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. While galaxies <em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2 display a strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 and modest <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$|</span> emission features, the data quality is not sufficient to place meaningful constraints on <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}$|\u2060</span>, or <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=jBQubozZbKjDKkx~K9MEXV0nUxfAubaYcDeJ20Isa3RGasiznQqD6zpKOArk2p6C91SECoDCDQ7Q1RYHIEGKa0~KwEFcAXGbMUFgV~tLM19jUYUgZlXymnwArGGDP08yJAyHIGZNQvF28EEWL680BqLF-8ZcWgXMiQuPydYtvqRMUGohwY605lh7oc6xZH1fpCKzCqHR5~Raj1zl6NKN5xwXJXponVamVbf3-bUPzCHp7lf0TZQfvJD4z3iDWjrRj~gsNpA1eAYhNAKj0g4pIQL2ogvhjM5~opcDb6XjI3S61OKz0N-End0NnPkO2DETlNiS8QvFY0shF~lPw4fpnw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the ISM absorption and emission features of Systems A (left three columns) and B (right column). Zero velocity corresponds to the systemic redshift determined from nebular emission lines of each galaxy (see Table\u00a05). The red curve in the $\\hbox{H i}$ panels shows the best-fitting DLA profile with the estimated $N({\\rm H\\, i})$ displayed at the top of each column. At negative velocities, the DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground. The $\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$ absorption profiles are presented in the second and third rows, showing blue absorption tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$. The 4th\u20136th rows show the low-ionization lines $\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$, $\\hbox{Si ii}\\lambda \\, 1526$, and $\\hbox{Fe ii}1608$, which exhibit asymmetric absorption profiles with extended blue tails, indicating the presence of gas outflows in the ISM. The best-fitting Gaussian models of $\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$, $\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$, and $\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$ emission lines are shown in red curves in bottom five rows. $\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$ is fitted with a single Gaussian. The doublets are all fitted with a double Gaussian, and the separation between two Gaussian components are fixed by their rest-frame wavelength separation. We fix the flux ratio $\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1666$/$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1660$ \u00a0=\u00a02.5. The redshift is tied to be consistent among all lines in each galaxy, and the best-fitting values (shown at the top of each column) set the zero velocity marked by the vertical dotted line. Data spectrum (continuum normalized) is shown in black, 1\u03c3 error spectrum in blue, and the best-fitting models in red. Flux and rest-frame equivalent width measured from the best-fitting models for each emission line is listed in Table\u00a05. While galaxies B1/B2 display a strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 and modest $\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$ emission features, the data quality is not sufficient to place meaningful constraints on $\\hbox{He ii}$, or $\\hbox{O iii}$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049470/stab1041fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049470\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=nuZCVtOGNlTW6jUy7ZMJfVfSXg0tgeg-Qh1VDcan1KzC3ZdW--gOGlCPlJz3HRjMdSbCdIJHHt5LyaqnLL8pJ61is8Zhl3NopTOECXMLZUwyt3dhzMKXjWY-cXBSCexBG1pHfwivpG18AxijFXHPTDQGOYNC~3vzTH-nyNi2~Rpi7CA-FV2xNzv-8AaguAmmPv8fr7qu77DcTH069nEijqaEsrM1vwGwpv1ogSgXaTLdiebXCKxyfPfHZq47tcenRBf4oILwTiRkguyNmzXe2Wafzh1R3pbBX-z4YByTw8cMFP-3i-pUlIghgeFoh9UU6yrfsIwK9Sq5hhEKzQFHLw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049470&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the ISM absorption and emission features of Systems <em>A</em> (left three columns) and <em>B</em> (right column). Zero velocity corresponds to the systemic redshift determined from nebular emission lines of each galaxy (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). The red curve in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{H i}$|</span> panels shows the best-fitting DLA profile with the estimated <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N({\\rm H\\, i})$|</span> displayed at the top of each column. At negative velocities, the DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> absorption profiles are presented in the second and third rows, showing blue absorption tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. The 4th\u20136th rows show the low-ionization lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Si ii}\\lambda \\, 1526$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Fe ii}1608$|\u2060</span>, which exhibit asymmetric absorption profiles with extended blue tails, indicating the presence of gas outflows in the ISM. The best-fitting Gaussian models of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$|</span> emission lines are shown in red curves in bottom five rows. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|</span> is fitted with a single Gaussian. The doublets are all fitted with a double Gaussian, and the separation between two Gaussian components are fixed by their rest-frame wavelength separation. We fix the flux ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1666$|</span>/<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1660$|</span> \u00a0=\u00a02.5. The redshift is tied to be consistent among all lines in each galaxy, and the best-fitting values (shown at the top of each column) set the zero velocity marked by the vertical dotted line. Data spectrum (continuum normalized) is shown in black, 1\u03c3 error spectrum in blue, and the best-fitting models in red. Flux and rest-frame equivalent width measured from the best-fitting models for each emission line is listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. While galaxies <em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2 display a strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 and modest <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$|</span> emission features, the data quality is not sufficient to place meaningful constraints on <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}$|\u2060</span>, or <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Apart from the strong DLA features, the prominent <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> absorption profiles in galaxies <em>A</em>1\u20133 show a blue tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>, indicating the presence of stellar winds produced by massive young stars. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> lines are shown in the second and third rows of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. In addition, low-ionization absorption lines, such as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Si ii}$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lambda \\, 1526$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Fe ii}\\lambda \\, 1608$|</span> as presented in the 4th\u20136th rows of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, indicate the presence of outflowing gas in the ISM of these galaxies. These absorption lines are clearly asymmetric with an extended blue wing in <em>A</em>1. A weak, extended blue wing is also visible in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Fe ii}\\lambda \\, 1608$|</span> for <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, while the core is more symmetrically distributed around the systemic velocity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To quantify outflow velocities, we measure the absorption velocity centroid, <em>v</em><sub>centre</sub>, and the maximum velocity of the absorption, <em>v</em><sub>max</sub>. Both quantities are measured with respect to the galaxy systemic velocities derived from nebular emission lines (see below). <em>v</em><sub>centre</sub> is determined to be at the location of the deepest absorption trough. <em>v</em><sub>max</sub> measures the blueshifted velocity at which the absorption is consistent with the continuum to within 1\u03c3 level. It is determined through the relation <em>f</em>(<em>v</em><sub>max</sub>)\u00a0= 1.0 \u2212 \u03b4(<em>v</em><sub>max</sub>), where <em>f</em> is the continuum-normalized flux and \u03b4 is the associated flux error (e.g. Martin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). To estimate the uncertainties of both <em>v</em><sub>max</sub> and <em>v</em><sub>centre</sub>, we repeat the measurements on 1000 random Gaussian generations of the spectra based on the observed intensities and error arrays, and report the mean and standard deviation of the 1000 measured values for both quantities. In addition, to quantify the internal velocity width of the absorption features, we fit a Gaussian profile to the red side of the absorption feature that is redward of the measured <em>v</em><sub>centre</sub>, and obtain an FWHM<sub>red</sub> that is not affected by the extended blue wing. The model Gaussian profile is convolved with the instrument line spread function before fitting with the data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because both <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Si ii}$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lambda \\, 1526$|</span> absorption lines are saturated, we make the measurements using <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Fe ii}\\lambda \\, 1608$|</span> line. We find [<em>v</em><sub>centre</sub>, <em>v</em><sub>max</sub>, FWHM<sub>red</sub>] of [\u221242\u00a0\u00b1\u00a058, \u2212757\u00a0\u00b1\u00a072, 474\u00a0\u00b1\u00a052], [\u221222\u00a0\u00b1\u00a030, \u2212614\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0147, 301\u00a0\u00b1\u00a026], and [\u221238\u00a0\u00b1\u00a028, \u2212480\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0140, 211\u00a0\u00b1\u00a056] \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> for <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, respectively. Both <em>A</em>1 and <em>A</em>2 exhibit an absorption velocity centroid consistent with <em>v</em>\u00a0= 0 to within measurement uncertainties, while <em>A</em>3 displays a slightly more significant blueshift. At the same time, the maximum velocity <em>v</em><sub>max</sub> of \u2248500\u2013760 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> observed in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Fe ii}\\lambda \\, 1608$|</span> exceeds the respective FWHM<sub>red</sub> measured for these galaxies, clearly indicating the presence of high-velocity outflows. We also note that the measured FWHM<sub>red</sub> is broader than the FWHM measured for nebular emission lines in all three galaxies (see below). In particular, for galaxy <em>A</em>1, the absorption line width is \u22483\u00a0times the width inferred from nebular emission lines (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), suggesting the presence of turbulence ISM local to the star-forming regions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All three galaxies show significantly smaller outflow velocities in the line centroids in comparison to typical Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting galaxies, which is \u223c200\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> as reported in Shibuya et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). If the outflows originate in a biconical structure, the small outflow velocities in System <em>A</em> may suggest a large inclination angle of the cones of \u223c80\u00b0, assuming that the mean <em>v</em><sub>centre</sub> among the three galaxies of \u223c34\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> is the projected velocity from an inclined cone flowing out with 200\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Such a large inclination angle is also consistent with the side-lobe like morphology of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae (i.e. the two clouds bracketing the continuum galaxies) and the elongated gap between the two clouds, as described below in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>. In addition, the fact that all three galaxies show similar uncharacteristically small outflow velocities might suggest that they all reside in the same outflow bubble likely originating from galaxy <em>A</em>1.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Different from galaxies in System <em>A</em>, galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 exhibit a strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission with no apparent DLA trough, and resolved <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1906,1908$|</span> doublet features on top of a faint UV continuum. No strong absorption features are detected, but the spectrum does not have sufficient sensitivities for placing strong constraints. We measure a rest-frame equivalent width (EW<sub>rest</sub>) of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission line of galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 over the observed wavelength window from \u03bb<sub>1</sub>\u00a0= 5760 \u00c5 to \u03bb<sub>2</sub>\u00a0= 5796 \u00c5, and obtain EW<sub>rest</sub>(Ly\u2009\u03b1)\u00a0= 33.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.5\u00c5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For all galaxies, we are able to determine an accurate systemic redshift for each of these galaxies by simultaneously fitting multiple emission lines with a Gaussian function, convolved with an appropriate instrument line spread function, which shares a common velocity centroid. Specifically for galaxies in System <em>A</em>, we adopt a single Gaussian model for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> and a double Gaussian model for both <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1660,1666$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1906,1908$|</span> doublets. In addition, the flux ratio of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\, 1666$|</span>/<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\, 1660$|</span> is fixed at 2.5 as expected from their radiative transition probabilities. For galaxy <em>A</em>1, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> is excluded from the fitting due to the lack of detection, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}$|</span> doublets are fitted with a common line width. For galaxy <em>A</em>2, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> is visibly broader than both <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}$|</span> doublets. We therefore allow the width of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> to be a free parameter, while the doublets share a common line width in the fit for <em>A</em>2. The difference in line width between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}$|</span>/<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}$|</span> doublets is not surprising, as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> emission is expected to have both stellar and nebular contributions which can sometimes lead to complex line structures (e.g. Berg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Kehrig et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Nanayakkara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Feltre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). For galaxy <em>A</em>3, fittings with or without <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> line width being a free parameter return consistent results within uncertainties. Therefore, we assign a common line width to all lines fitted for <em>A</em>3 for simplicity.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, we fit a double Gaussian model with a fixed doublet separation to the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1906,1908$|</span> intercombination lines. The best-fitting redshifts, line widths, integrated line fluxes, and EW<sub>rest</sub>, along with associated errors of individual galaxies, are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. The best-fitting line profiles of the emission features are also presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"246049478\" scrollto-destination=\"246049478\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl5\" 1640$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>136\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>0.41\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]} \\, \\lambda 1660$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]} \\, \\lambda 1666$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[C iii]} \\, \\lambda 1906$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>32\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>1.20\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]} \\, \\lambda 1908$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"4\"><em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.7540\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[C iii]} \\, \\lambda 1906$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>43\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>3.36\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.54\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]} \\, \\lambda 1908$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>1.80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.53\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th colspan=\"4\"><em>A</em>1 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.0364\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>FWHM\u00a0</td><td>Flux\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm EW}_{\\rm rest}^b$|</span>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>)\u00a0</td><td>(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\mathrm{10^{-20} \\, erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>)\u00a0</td><td>(\u00c5)\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii} \\, \\lambda 1640$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;45<sup><em>c</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>&lt;0.18<sup><em>d</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}] \\, \\lambda 1660$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>147\u00a0\u00b1\u00a034\u00a0</td><td>35\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td><td>0.14\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]} \\, \\lambda 1666$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>86\u00a0\u00b1\u00a022\u00a0</td><td>0.36\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.11\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span 3.0378\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001<sup><em>e</em></sup>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii} \\, \\lambda 1640$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>673\u00a0\u00b1\u00a083<sup><em>f</em></sup>\u00a0</td><td>49\u00a0\u00b1\u00a07\u00a0</td><td>0.79\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.13\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]} \\, \\lambda 1660$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>237\u00a0\u00b1\u00a014\u00a0</td><td>9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula
