1640$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>136\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09\u00a0</td><td>13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>0.41\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]} \\, \\lambda 1660$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>4\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]} \\, \\lambda 1666$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>10\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.34\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[C iii]} \\, \\lambda 1906$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>32\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>1.20\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]} \\, \\lambda 1908$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>26\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01\u00a0</td><td>0.99\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.08\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td colspan=\"4\"><em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.7540\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.0001\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[C iii]} \\, \\lambda 1906$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>43\u00a0\u00b1\u00a020\u00a0</td><td>0.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>3.36\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.54\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]} \\, \\lambda 1908$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2\u00a0</td><td>1.80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.53\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn8\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn8\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>.<sup><em>a</em></sup> Obtained from a simultaneous fit of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1660,1666$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1906,1908$|\u2060</span>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn9\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn9\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> Rest-frame equivalent width.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn10\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn10\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup> 2\u03c3 upper limit.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn11\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn11\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup> 2\u03c3 upper limit.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn12\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn12\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup> Obtained from a simultaneous fit of all lines listed; same for <em>A</em>3 and <em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn13\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn13\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup> FWHM of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii} \\, \\lambda 1640$|</span> in <em>A</em>2 is not tied with other lines due to its wide line width.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049478\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049479 id=\"246049479\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>4.4 Emission line diagnostics</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The UV emission line properties presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> are typical of star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u2248 3 (e.g. Maseda et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Nanayakkara et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Feltre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>), and reveal a turbulent and high-density nature in the ISM with a radiation field dominated by massive young stars in these galaxies. The best-fitting FWHMs of the emission lines correspond to velocity dispersions of \u224860 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> in A1 and A3, and \u2248100 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> in A2, which are within the typical range measured for <em>z</em>\u00a0= 2\u20133 galaxies (e.g. 108\u00a0\u00b1\u00a086 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> reported in Erb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, and \u224850\u2013150 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> reported in Kulas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The ratio between the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]}$|</span> intercombination lines serves as an important UV diagnostic of the electron density, <em>n</em><sub>e</sub>, in the ISM, although it saturates at density below <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$n_{\\rm e}\\approx 10^3\\, {\\rm cm}^{-3}$|</span> (e.g. Kewley, Nicholls\u00a0&amp; Sutherland <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). The observed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[C iii]}\\lambda \\, 1906$|</span>/<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]}\\lambda \\, 1908$|</span> ratios of these galaxies range from 1.2\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.2 for <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 to 1.9\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.6 for <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, constraining the ISM electron density in both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lesssim 2\\times 10^4\\, {\\rm cm}^{-3}$|</span> for a gas temperature of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10\\, 000$|</span> K (Osterbrock\u00a0&amp; Ferland <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The high-density limits are also comparable to what is seen in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]}$|</span> emitters at <em>z</em> \u2248 3 (e.g. Maseda et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In addition, the detection of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> emission, along with the presence of a prominent P-Cygni profile in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> with blue absorption tail extending beyond <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\Delta \\, v|\\approx 2000$|</span> \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> (second and third rows in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), indicates the presence of massive young stars with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M\\gtrsim 30\\, M_\\odot$|</span> (e.g. Leitherer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Pettini et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Crowther <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Brinchmann, Pettini\u00a0&amp; Charlot <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Cabanac, Valls-Gabaud\u00a0&amp; Lidman <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The presence of broad <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> emission line in <em>A</em>2 is also a sign of Wolf\u2013Rayet stars that have a short lifetime of \u223c5\u00a0Myr (e.g. Schaerer\u00a0&amp; Vacca <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Crowther <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), in agreement with the constant SFR scenario suggested by photometric SED analysis (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> and discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.2</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we investigate the possibility of these galaxies hosting an AGN using emission line diagnostics in the UV. Specifically, Feltre, Charlot\u00a0&amp; Gutkin (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) show that the combination of collisionally excited nebular lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$|</span> and the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|</span> recombination line can serve as a good indicator of the ISM ionization state. We compute the expected line ratios of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii]}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666/\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii]}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908/\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|</span> under different AGN and star formation (SF) ionization radiation fields, using the <span class=\"monospace\"><span class=\"small-caps\">cloudy</span></span> code (version 17.01; Ferland et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). For the AGN spectrum, we adopt the model continuum specified in <span class=\"monospace\"><span class=\"small-caps\">cloudy</span></span> with an effective temperature of 10<sup>6</sup> K, an X-ray to UV ratio of \u03b1<sub>ox</sub>\u00a0= \u22121.4, a UV slope of \u03b1<sub>uv</sub>\u00a0= \u22120.5, and an X-ray slope of \u03b1<sub>x</sub>\u00a0= \u22121. For the SF model, we consider two stellar populations with subsolar (<em>Z</em>\u00a0= 0.001) and solar (<em>Z</em>\u00a0= 0.02) metallicity, respectively. We use the <span class=\"small-caps\">fsps</span> code (v3.1; Conroy, Gunn\u00a0&amp; White <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Conroy\u00a0&amp; Gunn <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) to generate a composite SF spectrum at the age of 250\u00a0Myr with BPASS models, which assumes a Salpeter stellar initial mass function with an upper mass cut-off at 100M<sub>\u2299</sub> (Eldridge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). For each adopted AGN or SF spectrum, we generate a grid of models for the expected line ratios with the following parameters: gas metallicity <em>Z</em>\u00a0= [0.002, 0.02, 0.04], hydrogen density <em>n</em><sub>H</sub>/cm<sup>\u22123</sup>\u00a0= [10, 10<sup>2</sup>, 10<sup>3</sup>, 10<sup>4</sup>], and ionization parameter <em>U</em>\u00a0= [ \u2212 4, \u22123.5, \u22123, \u22122.5, \u22122, \u22121.5]. We set a temperature floor of 10\u2009000\u00a0K. The predicted line flux ratios are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, along with the observed values for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3. The non-detection of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> in galaxy <em>A</em>1 naturally leads to lower limits of both line flux ratios. We also treat the line flux ratios in both <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 as lower limits because of a possible stellar contribution to the measured <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|</span> flux.</p>                        <a id=\"246049482\" scrollto-destination=\"246049482\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=u-WFdkGznDCiQfXaJCaz1i7LUmmzn7cR9fjZOuQgS0jU7jXjhf9NansPT4lATRdo4yJLbgESmUiV0yzGSMVXZmoApiFwqgGqB6nM5cVNzRjvoOnRgqTRV0K9jaxwXWrbsM2dREtEgr~M3IK5-BP6b-1F4CAu129~UbP3NijIxInyYXON6xF7JvY6ra8CMjzmfE~HjlmxHLNKm4e1MOa3Tgc-QUeEO-y39k9AKfn3e5YAFsw~q8nMJZ6SoA-O4yHKMizSe~h6SXtDikyUmBZxAnIyHFJQR0mbWVCapSdY2YbkJNV-To0vtH0gNcz~mFt2el3tKh9xyb0KbiRJkBZqIg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"UV diagnostic diagram between AGN- (grey points) and stellar-dominated (blue and cyan points) radiation fields described in Section\u00a04.4. Gas metallicities range from subsolar Z\u00a0= 0.002 to supersolar Z\u00a0= 0.04. The observed line ratios for galaxies A1, A2, and A3 are shown in squares. All three galaxies exhibit line ratios that are consistent with young stars (rather than AGN) dominating the ISM radiation field.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049482/stab1041fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049482\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=0OqsDpbE1rQF5MvpwyU4l-ldIWGqLSI1UzOyRUVR2N15rFKI4p3RSmN2p2MfYwjrTe37OGzkgG9p7xl-zR5cJqiv7cOVs~XZi8pqSHFSXfEF3Rjk4fTgbFrFhNaGpDezsl3Mjdam~tN11sRQhcpT8Zs1WWtuWWe8AiOBxWVLDYNg2Oq77-LwecUVbcGtnpgexDQu9ozoK1g1fzul0C9aoYgmr2XwWG-dPrF~XDJXB4CgKSt8g~6YkfkPqJRUE4MeV~IFk0-un9lAvCHyudZjFUWqGW~ZHXxGkoslUZnilqjFOiykKqeZS60sR0HqXMNIPK7OEP2ZZaGcENp7o54hEA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049482&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">UV diagnostic diagram between AGN- (grey points) and stellar-dominated (blue and cyan points) radiation fields described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.4</a>. Gas metallicities range from subsolar <em>Z</em>\u00a0= 0.002 to supersolar <em>Z</em>\u00a0= 0.04. The observed line ratios for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 are shown in squares. All three galaxies exhibit line ratios that are consistent with young stars (rather than AGN) dominating the ISM radiation field.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=u-WFdkGznDCiQfXaJCaz1i7LUmmzn7cR9fjZOuQgS0jU7jXjhf9NansPT4lATRdo4yJLbgESmUiV0yzGSMVXZmoApiFwqgGqB6nM5cVNzRjvoOnRgqTRV0K9jaxwXWrbsM2dREtEgr~M3IK5-BP6b-1F4CAu129~UbP3NijIxInyYXON6xF7JvY6ra8CMjzmfE~HjlmxHLNKm4e1MOa3Tgc-QUeEO-y39k9AKfn3e5YAFsw~q8nMJZ6SoA-O4yHKMizSe~h6SXtDikyUmBZxAnIyHFJQR0mbWVCapSdY2YbkJNV-To0vtH0gNcz~mFt2el3tKh9xyb0KbiRJkBZqIg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"UV diagnostic diagram between AGN- (grey points) and stellar-dominated (blue and cyan points) radiation fields described in Section\u00a04.4. Gas metallicities range from subsolar Z\u00a0= 0.002 to supersolar Z\u00a0= 0.04. The observed line ratios for galaxies A1, A2, and A3 are shown in squares. All three galaxies exhibit line ratios that are consistent with young stars (rather than AGN) dominating the ISM radiation field.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049482/stab1041fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049482\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig5.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=0OqsDpbE1rQF5MvpwyU4l-ldIWGqLSI1UzOyRUVR2N15rFKI4p3RSmN2p2MfYwjrTe37OGzkgG9p7xl-zR5cJqiv7cOVs~XZi8pqSHFSXfEF3Rjk4fTgbFrFhNaGpDezsl3Mjdam~tN11sRQhcpT8Zs1WWtuWWe8AiOBxWVLDYNg2Oq77-LwecUVbcGtnpgexDQu9ozoK1g1fzul0C9aoYgmr2XwWG-dPrF~XDJXB4CgKSt8g~6YkfkPqJRUE4MeV~IFk0-un9lAvCHyudZjFUWqGW~ZHXxGkoslUZnilqjFOiykKqeZS60sR0HqXMNIPK7OEP2ZZaGcENp7o54hEA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049482&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">UV diagnostic diagram between AGN- (grey points) and stellar-dominated (blue and cyan points) radiation fields described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.4</a>. Gas metallicities range from subsolar <em>Z</em>\u00a0= 0.002 to supersolar <em>Z</em>\u00a0= 0.04. The observed line ratios for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 are shown in squares. All three galaxies exhibit line ratios that are consistent with young stars (rather than AGN) dominating the ISM radiation field.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> shows that all three galaxies in System <em>A</em> are consistent with an ISM radiation field being dominated by massive young stars and that there is no evidence of an AGN dominating the radiation field in these galaxies. Furthermore, the lack of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> in emission also suggests the absence of AGN as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> emission is expected to be prominent with a hard ionization background (e.g. Gutkin, Charlot\u00a0&amp; Bruzual <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Due to the lack of relevant emission lines in the combined spectrum of <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, we cannot conduct the same exercise for System <em>B</em>. A close examination of available deep X-ray data taken by <em>Chandra</em> also shows that there is no apparent excess of X-ray signal at the locations of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049484 id=\"246049484\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 ANALYSIS: LY\u2009\u03b1 NEBULA PROPERTIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed broad-band photometric and spectroscopic properties of galaxies in System <em>A</em> indicate that these galaxies are typical of UV continuum selected star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u2248 3 with an ISM radiation field dominated by massive young stars, while galaxies in System <em>B</em> display properties that resemble low-mass LAEs in the early epoch. The large amount of ISM gas revealed in the spectra of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, coupled with a wide-spread Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebula revealed in the MUSE data, shows that this is a particularly gas-rich system. Here, we present an analysis of the morphologies and line profiles of the extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae in these two systems.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049486 id=\"246049486\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 Pseudo narrow-band Ly\u2009\u03b1 image and source plane reconstruction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To characterize the extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae in both systems, we first form a pseudo narrow-band Ly\u2009\u03b1 image for each system. We first note that all three galaxies in System <em>A</em> exhibit asymmetric Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission feature within the DLA trough, with an enhanced red peak at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v\\approx +500$|</span> \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> (e.g. top row of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>) from the respective systemic redshifts. The observed asymmetric profile of these emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons is similar to what is seen in the extended nebulae (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.2</a> below) and is characteristic of large-scale outflows that have been commonly identified in high-redshift galaxies (e.g. Franx et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Frye\u00a0&amp; Broadhurst <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Pettini et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Frye, Broadhurst\u00a0&amp; Ben\u00edtez <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). An origin of the emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons in outflows is qualitatively consistent with the presence of gas outflows seen in absorption lines in galaxy spectra and the presence of massive young stars inferred from the UV spectral properties of the galaxies described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.4</a> (see also Pettini et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Cabanac et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, for examples). Given the uncertainty of the lint-of-sight distance between the galaxies and the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission location, whether these photons originate in the star-forming ISM of the galaxies or in the extended nebulae that are blended with the galaxy image by projection remains uncertain. Therefore, we construct two versions of the pseudo narrow-band Ly\u2009\u03b1 image for System <em>A</em>: one without including the emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons in the DLA trough of the continuum sources, and a second one which incorporates both the Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons in the DLA troughs and those in the extended nebulae. As discussed below and shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, this exercise enables a clearer understanding of the differences in the observed surface brightness profiles between multiple images, as well as establishing a direct connection between the galaxies and the line-emitting gas at large distances.</p>                        <a id=\"246049488\" scrollto-destination=\"246049488\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=d091yaoWzvgJtdd2uW-8syuu0lpJ~51Ru-RoLVGanpJfKgO7xvJmUo~3FCvWuk9UT~drmBmxNuw2G~YX8BwOh79a3Is21zN6WRel184If5R18n-SoOo~3S38~~dzxfKBrgyBoITiEDh-F7LTXT2eFMqJFYKbXgg7kKrghAo4CPiCHzn-ZvEvgvf77EeC06o6KmsvvKBCUse342GhIdnzRtbY9gETGilwgUxGcEU~EeYGLiuWUKEVHbNqi2m2Ujh7n2nOidK003OdBLmAPYrtjTmk7lQ4FiEC9sg4ZX-H8PxQ8NgCCWT4biy9Hggi6C~mC54ZpZbs7ji4d6R8NUD3Jw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the lensing configuration of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 arc in System A. Column (1): pseudo narrow-band images without the emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux within the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. The images have been smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of FWHMsmooth\u00a0= 1 arcsec. The contour marks constant surface brightness of $3.7\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$, which is detected at the 3\u03c3 level of significance in the smoothed image. The star symbols mark the positions of the associated star-forming galaxies identified in HST images. Column (2): same as Column (1) but includes Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum (see text). Column (3): contours of multiply lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae determined from Column (2) overlaid on individual galaxy images in the HST data to illustrate the relative alignment between star-forming regions and the line-emitting gas (see also Fig.\u00a01). Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness contours of $3.7\\times 10^{-18}$ and $7.3\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$ are shown in white and red, respectively, and the yellow contours mark the critical curves of the cluster lens for sources at z\u00a0= 3.038. Column (4): the magnification map overlaid with the same Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours to illustrate the spatial variation of lensing magnification across the nebulae. Negative magnification factors indicate flipped parity of the image.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049488/stab1041fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049488\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=vx-VUVAW6ImsJ-4GCUm8sIZGMCbvUWlyWtZDVLBwDhuThJxpM-mBHhFhCDU5Ymu69Oxr2pJPDMqtKOHCxm~Nf3B~EXksX8W4JKdWGH4NZpLHBfYHkIsfHA7QVAVa4fFePpiVOxppIbVKPtDT5tEFh0ShXtBBbAtNAzIjRqHdp-vzJ~Q9E6IpNnJSFs~h9j1P~L5mQNe5RMAYPCo1xYUPcJMnHA1QrW5JpLz2r7CExWYMM3YMguIfWgBF5GrFVHTy1pf1hNCZZwG6WElN3MbGhmXphorChAKbh6SHcz7HW0rypCXA9fBFLHfXL~jyF6vraqDcFkFlYk3GrlKbMv-fUA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049488&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the lensing configuration of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 arc in System <em>A</em>. The images have been smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 1 arcsec. Negative magnification factors indicate flipped parity of the image.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=d091yaoWzvgJtdd2uW-8syuu0lpJ~51Ru-RoLVGanpJfKgO7xvJmUo~3FCvWuk9UT~drmBmxNuw2G~YX8BwOh79a3Is21zN6WRel184If5R18n-SoOo~3S38~~dzxfKBrgyBoITiEDh-F7LTXT2eFMqJFYKbXgg7kKrghAo4CPiCHzn-ZvEvgvf77EeC06o6KmsvvKBCUse342GhIdnzRtbY9gETGilwgUxGcEU~EeYGLiuWUKEVHbNqi2m2Ujh7n2nOidK003OdBLmAPYrtjTmk7lQ4FiEC9sg4ZX-H8PxQ8NgCCWT4biy9Hggi6C~mC54ZpZbs7ji4d6R8NUD3Jw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the lensing configuration of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 arc in System A. The contour marks constant surface brightness of $3.7\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$, which is detected at the 3\u03c3 level of significance in the smoothed image. The star symbols mark the positions of the associated star-forming galaxies identified in HST images. Column (2): same as Column (1) but includes Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum (see text). Column (3): contours of multiply lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae determined from Column (2) overlaid on individual galaxy images in the HST data to illustrate the relative alignment between star-forming regions and the line-emitting gas (see also Fig.\u00a01). Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness contours of $3.7\\times 10^{-18}$ and $7.3\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$ are shown in white and red, respectively, and the yellow contours mark the critical curves of the cluster lens for sources at z\u00a0= 3.038. Column (4): the magnification map overlaid with the same Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours to illustrate the spatial variation of lensing magnification across the nebulae. Negative magnification factors indicate flipped parity of the image.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049488/stab1041fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049488\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig6.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=vx-VUVAW6ImsJ-4GCUm8sIZGMCbvUWlyWtZDVLBwDhuThJxpM-mBHhFhCDU5Ymu69Oxr2pJPDMqtKOHCxm~Nf3B~EXksX8W4JKdWGH4NZpLHBfYHkIsfHA7QVAVa4fFePpiVOxppIbVKPtDT5tEFh0ShXtBBbAtNAzIjRqHdp-vzJ~Q9E6IpNnJSFs~h9j1P~L5mQNe5RMAYPCo1xYUPcJMnHA1QrW5JpLz2r7CExWYMM3YMguIfWgBF5GrFVHTy1pf1hNCZZwG6WElN3MbGhmXphorChAKbh6SHcz7HW0rypCXA9fBFLHfXL~jyF6vraqDcFkFlYk3GrlKbMv-fUA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049488&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the lensing configuration of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 arc in System <em>A</em>. Column (<em>1</em>): pseudo narrow-band images without the emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux within the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. The images have been smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 1 arcsec. The contour marks constant surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, which is detected at the 3\u03c3 level of significance in the smoothed image. The star symbols mark the positions of the associated star-forming galaxies identified in <em>HST</em> images. Column (<em>2</em>): same as Column (<em>1</em>) but includes Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum (see text). Column (<em>3</em>): contours of multiply lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae determined from Column (<em>2</em>) overlaid on individual galaxy images in the <em>HST</em> data to illustrate the relative alignment between star-forming regions and the line-emitting gas (see also Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness contours of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.3\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> are shown in white and red, respectively, and the yellow contours mark the critical curves of the cluster lens for sources at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038. Column (<em>4</em>): the magnification map overlaid with the same Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours to illustrate the spatial variation of lensing magnification across the nebulae. Negative magnification factors indicate flipped parity of the image.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"246049489\" scrollto-destination=\"246049489\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=5HL06vxfkW~SM0PRidEl9YyK9cpAuPXQiA0gPLFQtHn95s2lV4k-N-hDHn4mxDhe~uroSksKsHGhpBfcm9vCRsiyaL0qUaxEkL3VHfNWhINX4X6le0QpS71qDvVwFI2icIwgju6FSyQvVhQFsaZlsNjNcBCc9CP~xsmhIz7r5dx8z3oMKRHb6RUHDCrUpkffBa7G40GUnm8I7KgBqHQPuZ0YPjK7jcubvpGFan9FMaOCcpgfPY0xnZeBWpTkyHsbbVP8~YGLkY6YmF4Qq9DG5Setlf3U1mDQ1s8suuBNxHOI-V6htv~05e1kngGbO9cLlEs3lolbqHOx5oT9dAL9fg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Column (1): de-lensed narrow-band image without Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. The images are smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of FWHMsmooth\u00a0= 0.5 arcsec in the source plane. The contour marks constant surface brightness of $3.7\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$, corresponding to the 3\u03c3 level of significance detected in the image plane, same as contours shown in Column(1) of Fig.\u00a06. The star symbols mark the de-lensed positions of the associated star-forming galaxies identified in HST images. Column (2): same as Column (1) but includes Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. Column (3): de-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours overlaid on de-lensed HST data, with the yellow contours showing the caustics in the source plane. The blue dashed circles in Column (2) mark the apertures for the template spectrum extraction, which we use for the shell model analysis (see Section\u00a05.3). The cyan dashed arrows show the directions along which we extract the one-dimensional surface brightness profile (see Fig.\u00a09 below).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049489/stab1041fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049489\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=d1zBVZ0Y0xUxTEL8m77j3ZmTbYuSUi5DbfbvFKi7rB9j4VMUQkWGTbRm8~Hlu79QHSeAu9AuYltLwJJncZ-NKw3XADleOfs~KdvTSUaIyToffgbEYsY2TihKoRp0hMc7xR7rl1W7Ss7H~832wDGf5W6CXAlvHK~FjpiKCnayVJJfbV7Yh7mmkJSO6E8y6dQknSxddhA2SWurLOBvYOR62c2WrhRo7DATrGqDx96V0tr510-xZzbmu~25H2EmpisofI2AklmOTpEOE8FqIKJi8CedkpTYuGDPs~eBrgkVbWHJgYa-zEBKUjXhtCtErwkafxSvoAITQ3dalPqCL~RICQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049489&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Column (<em>1</em>): de-lensed narrow-band image without Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. The images are smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 0.5 arcsec in the source plane. The contour marks constant surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, corresponding to the 3\u03c3 level of significance detected in the image plane, same as contours shown in Column(<em>1</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The star symbols mark the de-lensed positions of the associated star-forming galaxies identified in <em>HST</em> images. Column (<em>2</em>): same as Column (<em>1</em>) but includes Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. Column (<em>3</em>): de-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours overlaid on de-lensed <em>HST</em> data, with the yellow contours showing the caustics in the source plane. The blue dashed circles in Column (<em>2</em>) mark the apertures for the template spectrum extraction, which we use for the shell model analysis (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a>). The cyan dashed arrows show the directions along which we extract the one-dimensional surface brightness profile (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> below).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=5HL06vxfkW~SM0PRidEl9YyK9cpAuPXQiA0gPLFQtHn95s2lV4k-N-hDHn4mxDhe~uroSksKsHGhpBfcm9vCRsiyaL0qUaxEkL3VHfNWhINX4X6le0QpS71qDvVwFI2icIwgju6FSyQvVhQFsaZlsNjNcBCc9CP~xsmhIz7r5dx8z3oMKRHb6RUHDCrUpkffBa7G40GUnm8I7KgBqHQPuZ0YPjK7jcubvpGFan9FMaOCcpgfPY0xnZeBWpTkyHsbbVP8~YGLkY6YmF4Qq9DG5Setlf3U1mDQ1s8suuBNxHOI-V6htv~05e1kngGbO9cLlEs3lolbqHOx5oT9dAL9fg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Column (1): de-lensed narrow-band image without Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. The images are smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of FWHMsmooth\u00a0= 0.5 arcsec in the source plane. The contour marks constant surface brightness of $3.7\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$, corresponding to the 3\u03c3 level of significance detected in the image plane, same as contours shown in Column(1) of Fig.\u00a06. The star symbols mark the de-lensed positions of the associated star-forming galaxies identified in HST images. Column (2): same as Column (1) but includes Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. Column (3): de-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours overlaid on de-lensed HST data, with the yellow contours showing the caustics in the source plane. The blue dashed circles in Column (2) mark the apertures for the template spectrum extraction, which we use for the shell model analysis (see Section\u00a05.3). The cyan dashed arrows show the directions along which we extract the one-dimensional surface brightness profile (see Fig.\u00a09 below).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049489/stab1041fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049489\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig7.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=d1zBVZ0Y0xUxTEL8m77j3ZmTbYuSUi5DbfbvFKi7rB9j4VMUQkWGTbRm8~Hlu79QHSeAu9AuYltLwJJncZ-NKw3XADleOfs~KdvTSUaIyToffgbEYsY2TihKoRp0hMc7xR7rl1W7Ss7H~832wDGf5W6CXAlvHK~FjpiKCnayVJJfbV7Yh7mmkJSO6E8y6dQknSxddhA2SWurLOBvYOR62c2WrhRo7DATrGqDx96V0tr510-xZzbmu~25H2EmpisofI2AklmOTpEOE8FqIKJi8CedkpTYuGDPs~eBrgkVbWHJgYa-zEBKUjXhtCtErwkafxSvoAITQ3dalPqCL~RICQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049489&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Column (<em>1</em>): de-lensed narrow-band image without Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. The images are smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 0.5 arcsec in the source plane. The contour marks constant surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, corresponding to the 3\u03c3 level of significance detected in the image plane, same as contours shown in Column(<em>1</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The star symbols mark the de-lensed positions of the associated star-forming galaxies identified in <em>HST</em> images. Column (<em>2</em>): same as Column (<em>1</em>) but includes Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. Column (<em>3</em>): de-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours overlaid on de-lensed <em>HST</em> data, with the yellow contours showing the caustics in the source plane. The blue dashed circles in Column (<em>2</em>) mark the apertures for the template spectrum extraction, which we use for the shell model analysis (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a>). The cyan dashed arrows show the directions along which we extract the one-dimensional surface brightness profile (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> below).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To construct a pseudo narrow-band Ly\u2009\u03b1 image for System <em>A</em> without including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons from the DLA troughs, we perform a local continuum subtraction per spaxel within the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line. We determine a wavelength-dependent continuum level based on a linear interpolation of the continuum fluxes observed on the blue and red sides of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line. Specifically, we determine a medium flux over a spectral window of 4830\u20134863 \u00c5 on the blue side and a median flux over 4961\u20134994 \u00c5 on the red side. At <em>z</em> \u2248 3.04, these correspond roughly to [\u22125000, \u22123000] and [+3000, +5000] km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> from the Ly\u2009\u03b1 centroid (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> below). The interpolated value is then subtracted from the observed flux at each spaxel. A pseudo narrow-band image of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission is then created by integrating the flux of each spaxel over the wavelength range from 4890 to 4930 \u00c5, where Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux is detected at a high level of significance (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> below). A smoothed pseudo narrow-band Ly\u2009\u03b1 image, using a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 1 arcsec, is presented in Column (<em>1</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, which shows two nebulae separated roughly by \u22482 arcsec in the image plane and bracketing galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 from the north and south. Furthermore, at the locations of galaxy continuum, there is a net absorption in this pseudo narrow-band image due to the presence of DLAs.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Next, we construct a pseudo narrow-band image that includes the emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons in the DLA troughs. This is accomplished by first identifying the spaxels within the continuum-emitting regions of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 as defined by <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a>). We then adopt the best-fitting DLA model profile for each galaxy presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, and multiply the model by the best-fitting continuum obtained using a low-order polynomial fit to line-free regions in the integrated continuum spectrum presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. Next, the combined DLA-continuum model spectrum is scaled to match the continuum level of the spectrum in each spaxel and subtracted from the data. The amplitude of the continuum model for each spaxel is determined using the spectrum in the wavelength window from 5430 to 5560 \u00c5, corresponding to rest-frame wavelengths from 1345 to 1375 \u00c5, where no narrow-line features are present. The resulting difference data cube is combined with the previous continuum-subtracted data cube in the extended nebula region. A pseudo narrow-band image is then created by integrating over the wavelength range from 4890 to 4930 \u00c5. Similarly, we smooth the image using a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 1 arcsec, and present the smoothed pseudo narrow-band image in Column (<em>2</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In both versions of the pseudo narrow-band image presented in Columns (<em>1</em>) and (<em>2</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, the white contours mark a constant Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, which is detected at the 3\u03c3 level of significance. A strong variation in Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness is clearly seen across both the northern and southern nebulae, suggesting large spatial fluctuations in the underlying gas properties. While there exists a clear gap between the northern and southern nebulae, after including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal inside the DLA troughs, the overlap between the constant Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness contours and these galaxies supports a continuous flow of dense gas from star-forming regions into a low-density halo environment. Furthermore, the surface brightness of the southern nebula in the vicinity of the galaxy continuum in images <em>b</em> and <em>c</em> is relatively more enhanced than that in image <em>a</em> after incorporating the Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal in the DLA troughs (also see Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> below). Specifically, in Column (<em>2</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness in image <em>a</em> in the vicinity of galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 is fainter by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 25{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> compared with images <em>b</em> and <em>c</em>. The reduced Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness in images <em>a</em> suggests that the magnification factor of image <em>a</em> relative to images <em>b</em> and <em>c</em> is smaller than what is predicted by the lens model. Such a difference in surface brightness of lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae is also seen in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>), and is consistent with the discrepancy in de-lensed continuum brightnesses of <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, for which image <em>a</em> is fainter by \u22480.2 mag (see discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Column (<em>3</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness contours showing <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.3\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (i.e. 3\u03c3 and 6\u03c3 determined from the pseudo narrow-band image shown in Column <em>2</em>) are overlaid on top of the <em>HST</em> composite image from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Note that image <em>b</em> is north\u2013south flipped from images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> in this lensing configuration. As a guide, we include the magnification map in Column (<em>4</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> (negative magnification factors indicate flipped parity of the image), overlaid with the same Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Through the deflection field calculated using the fine-tuned lens model (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>), we de-lens both the pseudo narrow-band image and the <em>HST</em> images back to the source plane. The de-lensed pseudo narrow-band image smoothed with a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 0.5 arcsec in the source plane is presented in Columns (<em>1</em>) and (<em>2</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> for before and after including Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission in the DLA troughs, respectively. The reconstructed source-plane images clearly show that most of the northern nebula is merely singly lensed like galaxy <em>A</em>1, while the southern nebula stretches across the lensing field with rapidly changing magnification factors. Image <em>a</em>, covering the full extent of the nebulae in the source plane, constrains the projected size of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae to approximately 30 pkpc from north to south. The de-lensed <em>HST</em> broad-band images, as shown in Columns (<em>3</em>), are in excellent agreement among three multiple images, consistent with the low image position dispersion of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm rms_{\\rm im}}=0.1$|</span> arcsec predicted by the fine-tuned lens model (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>). The de-lensed pseudo narrow-band images show the same surface brightness discrepancy between multiple images as seen in the image plane (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), where the surface brightness near the galaxy continuum regions is fainter in image <em>a</em> as discussed above. The white and red contours in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> correspond to surface brightnesses of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.3\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, same as the contours shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">When computing the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux in the nebulae, we consider image <em>a</em> for the northern nebula to avoid the confusion of partially lensed multiple images, and average images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> for the southern nebula. Due to the contamination from a nearby galaxy at the east side of the southern nebula in image <em>b</em>, we leave out image <em>b</em> in the average. In contrast with the continuum sources, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae span a much larger area in the image plane, within which the magnification factor can vary significantly (see Column 4 of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). Therefore, instead of using a mean magnification factor, we correct the lensing magnification for each spaxel within the extended nebulae before summing over all spaxels within the 3\u03c3 contour for these images. We then integrate the flux over the wavelength range of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (the same wavelength window for constructing the narrow-band image described above). The total de-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux of the southern nebula obtained from image <em>a</em> is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 5{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$25{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>) lower than that from image <em>c</em> before (after) including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs. This difference of Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux between images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> is in agreement with what is observed in the Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness and de-lensed magnitudes of galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>), suggesting again that the magnification factor near the continuum regions in image <em>a</em> is smaller than what is predicted by the lens model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After excluding the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from within the DLA troughs and correcting the lensing magnification, we obtain a total flux of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }(A_{\\rm north})=(2.0\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{-17}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|</span> for the northern nebula, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }(A_{\\rm south})=(2.9\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{-17}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|</span> for the southern nebula. Including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs, the total flux is increased to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }^{\\rm tot}(A_{\\rm north})=(2.7\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{-17}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|</span> for the northern nebula, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }^{\\rm tot}(A_{\\rm south})=(3.8\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{-17}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|</span> for the southern nebula. The Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal inside the DLA troughs therefore accounts for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 25{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> of the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission from both the northern and southern nebulae. At <em>z</em> \u2248 3.038, these flux measurements (including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux in the DLA troughs) correspond to a Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }(A_{\\rm north})=(2.15\\pm 0.07)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> for the northern nebula, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }(A_{\\rm south})=(3.03\\pm 0.08)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> for the southern nebula. Combining both northern and southern nebulae together leads to a total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }(A)=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For System <em>B</em>, no apparent DLA or strong ISM absorption features are detected in the MUSE spectra of the star-forming regions, but the low <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> as a result of a faint continuum makes gas column density estimates highly uncertain. The apparent discontinuity in the continuum blueward and redward of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission line is consistent with the expectation from the Ly\u2009\u03b1 forest in the intergalactic medium at <em>z</em> \u2248 3.75 (e.g. Becker, Rauch\u00a0&amp; Sargent <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). To construct a pseudo narrow-band image for this system, we first subtract the expected continuum at the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 line. Following the approach described above for System <em>A</em>, we determine the continuum level in each spaxel of the star-forming regions by matching the low-order polynomial fit of the UV continuum presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> to the observed spectrum. For spaxels outside of the continuum-emitting regions, the continuum level at the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission line is determined based on a linear interpolation between blue and red continuum fluxes observed within 5730\u20135760 \u00c5 and 5800\u20135830 \u00c5, respectively. A pseudo narrow-band image is then constructed by integrating the flux in the wavelength range from 5766 to 5796 \u00c5. A smoothed version using a Gaussian kernel of FWHM\u00a0= 1 arcsec is presented in Column (<em>1</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, overlaid with constant surface brightness contours of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.8\\times 10^{-18}\\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> detected at 3\u03c3. In Column (<em>2</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, contours of 2.8 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.5\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (i.e. 3\u03c3 and 8\u03c3) are presented along with the <em>HST</em> composite image to illustrate the relative alignment between the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae and the associated galaxies. The magnification map presented in Column (<em>3</em>) shows the fast changing magnification factors across all five lensed images in System <em>B</em>, as the lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting regions straddles multiple critical curves in the image plane. De-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 pseudo narrow-band images (smoothed using a Gaussian kernel of FWHM\u00a0= 0.5 arcsec) and the <em>HST</em> images in the source plane, based on the fine-tuned lens model described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>, are also presented in Columns (<em>4</em>) and (<em>5</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, respectively. Compared with System <em>A</em>, the lensing configuration of System <em>B</em> is more complicated, with images <em>a</em>\u2013<em>d</em> being partial images of different completeness levels. Image <em>e</em> is the only complete lensed image of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebula defined at the 3\u03c3 level of significance in surface brightness. The source plane reconstruction from image <em>e</em> reveals a relatively symmetric Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission morphology, roughly centred near the UV continuum sources. Using image <em>e</em>, we estimate the projected size of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebula to be approximately 10 pkpc in diameter. A small spatial offset, \u22480.1 arcsec, is seen between UV continuum sources and the peak of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission, corresponding to \u22480.7 pkpc at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. It is commonly observed among LAEs that the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission signals can have an offset from the UV continuum, with a median 1D projected offset of \u22480.6 pkpc in previous slit spectroscopic data (e.g. Hoag et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Lemaux et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>; Ribeiro et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Larger offsets have also been found in narrow-band imaging data (e.g. Shibuya et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). However, we note that the continuum fluxes of galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 are much fainter than the LAEs considered in those studies.</p>                        <a id=\"246049498\" scrollto-destination=\"246049498\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=GwEdd5DYzUTtgLkWQ~oXj4y1ovSQTBv-Jf~d56qPCU2ccXhAKTWfKxEoXTOdpshHqjlDFhJ1zTb~XhiY0KdZTtfRgYAHhK5dcqvow9k-OMVHzyHzjhAocpVEFAzN7kd~NJXQiIj-tU8cr5jcN21psW77tFfkXjvo6GBCDhRLB20kNXXOdvAnU7fn8y~icyb~zDTHGJBFfQUIBUrvDlbi-qQXWAjoHM~ZcC9V~VVYVz1E8xfvFOLZrMIiL8jmPteHilqPFCjUwG73bB9NG1OOTQy3giO3OW3O8U43AXgfJbmyZm1MbRKnjDP7LA6YRaUQumfd42UoGZ1StM4txMq5IA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the lensing configuration of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 arc in System B. The black arrows in the bottom three panels indicate the location of the brightest pixels in images c, d, and e (one pixel from each image) that are included in the template Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectrum used for shell model analysis (see Section\u00a05.3). Column (2): contours of multiply lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae overlaid on individual galaxy images in the HST data. Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness contours of $2.8\\times 10^{-18}$ and $7.5\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$ are shown in white and red, respectively. Column (3): the magnification map overlaid with the same Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours to illustrate the spatial variation of lensing magnification across the nebulae. Column (4): de-lensed narrow-band image, smoothed with a Gaussian kernel of FWHMsmooth\u00a0= 0.5 arcsec in the source plane. Compared with System <em>A</em>, the lensing configuration of System <em>B</em> is much more complicated, with images <em>a</em>\u2013<em>d</em> being partial images with different levels of completeness. Image <em>e</em> is the only complete image of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission above 3\u03c3 limiting surface brightness.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=GwEdd5DYzUTtgLkWQ~oXj4y1ovSQTBv-Jf~d56qPCU2ccXhAKTWfKxEoXTOdpshHqjlDFhJ1zTb~XhiY0KdZTtfRgYAHhK5dcqvow9k-OMVHzyHzjhAocpVEFAzN7kd~NJXQiIj-tU8cr5jcN21psW77tFfkXjvo6GBCDhRLB20kNXXOdvAnU7fn8y~icyb~zDTHGJBFfQUIBUrvDlbi-qQXWAjoHM~ZcC9V~VVYVz1E8xfvFOLZrMIiL8jmPteHilqPFCjUwG73bB9NG1OOTQy3giO3OW3O8U43AXgfJbmyZm1MbRKnjDP7LA6YRaUQumfd42UoGZ1StM4txMq5IA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the lensing configuration of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 arc in System B.
