F</em>390<em>W</em>, and<em>F435W</em> bandpasses.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn21\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn21\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup> 2\u03c3 flux upper limit.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049573\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049574 id=\"246049574\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec11>APPENDIX C: FITTING A SHELL MODEL TO STACKED SPECTRA OBTAINED OVER A LARGE AREA WITH FIXED INTRINSIC Ly\u2009\u03b1 LINE WIDTH \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a>, we have shown that the best-fitting shell models for stacked spectra extracted from a large area in both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> require the intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 line width \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> to be much larger than the observed nebular emission line width. We argue that the large \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> is caused by the smearing effect due to the velocity gradient in the nebulae. Here in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figC1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figC1\" data-open=\"figC1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">C1</a>, we show the best-fitting models for the same spectra shown in the top row of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> in the main text, and demonstrate that by fixing \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> to the observed values from galaxy spectra, the best-fitting models provide a worse fit to the data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2002</p>                        <a id=\"246049577\" scrollto-destination=\"246049577\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figC1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure C1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041figa1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=T5h1dzAqhR43DMZE099mTBf~7wxwzCi288jKBqBeo6olWpKl1z~U44x9MWZ9q13Lfu1KEu0KrL6C3eg2Pj2U08BSyttySN-ngoNcXAs5HeSDgQab3W8enMoSICblQ1oj30t6Ss6q9DrEUpFERIL~Y49XzGxFYEBmEXgyI7Ewl~smmb9tBdz4lJqDCQrCR93KM6Nzl~Dn2SgpW5RZQEda4h5R4dFTq4Gq5GiFbxKSubZZsz~OS4POKqFBfdoXZfL9soasnWyWOurRY7aDj1rhNaN62POI3SYmOqVTkuD36gf5Zqx6yvNuPJx5zngNtjuU0PBzaUaGLbvHGYrfHNa~PA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left-hand panel: Stacked spectra from all spaxels within the 3\u03c3 contour in System A, divided into northern and southern nebulae (see Figs\u00a01 and\u00a06). The best-fitting models are shown in dash\u2013dotted and dotted curves for the northern and southern nebula, respectively. To obtain the best-fitting models, we fix the intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 line width \u03c3i to be 95\u00a0km\u2009s\u22121, corresponding to the observed line width measured from the nebular emission lines (see Section\u00a04.3 and Table\u00a05). Compared with the best-fitting models shown in Fig.\u00a010 in the main text where \u03c3i is a free parameter, the models shown here with a fixed \u03c3i provide a worse fit to the data (particularly on the blue peak), which is also reflected with the increased $\\chi ^2_\\nu$. Right-hand panel: Stacked spectral from low- and high-surface brightness regions in System B, extracted from within and outside of the 8\u03c3 contours. The best-fitting models are shown in dash\u2013dotted and dotted curves for low- and high-surface brightness spectra, respectively. Similar to the models for System A, we fix \u03c3i to be 20\u00a0km\u2009s\u22121 as measured from the galaxy spectrum. Although these models with fixed \u03c3i also provide a worse fit to the data compared with the models presented in Fig.\u00a010 where \u03c3i is a free parameter, the difference in $\\chi ^2_\\nu$ is not as significant as the difference seen in System A. This is consistent with System A having a steeper velocity gradient across the nebulae, leading to a more significant smearing effect in the stacked spectra from a large area.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049577/stab1041figa1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049577\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041figa1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=3ft1Tjn0BW5CKr4hX0j0Z9rV1OniLtKWv0bmQE1JGPLlgQwE41vLj1hzhAH1clm3Ed9XAn7KimHVy9rNdPUxG2O3aJfFysEzp0f0zTuu3Dksry3LLcGbp8w2GPdkYqf2x1Jee8MeqKg-l5Wiiie-VaqMbsgqmX-hpdb6Smsr08ZWO4u7lFZ2WD3PP2XqY0GXjpR6oPvdx2RIb2IgAsnBwWV4m1mg2dU7PqR068C4Si8gWcbOLkZtXsveA3oy3dAn3-tOWQRgnoE-aJBUrFbLjmGnJKknyA0zDQ2l99vCqV4Xw9kbUgWqnS7pHFbiBAiDSIvfobPsB1ze7X-ywRwtHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049577&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left-hand panel:</em> Stacked spectra from all spaxels within the 3\u03c3 contour in System <em>A</em>, divided into northern and southern nebulae (see Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). The best-fitting models are shown in dash\u2013dotted and dotted curves for the northern and southern nebula, respectively. To obtain the best-fitting models, we fix the intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 line width \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> to be 95\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, corresponding to the observed line width measured from the nebular emission lines (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3</a> and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). Compared with the best-fitting models shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> in the main text where \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> is a free parameter, the models shown here with a fixed \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> provide a worse fit to the data (particularly on the blue peak), which is also reflected with the increased <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_\\nu$|\u2060</span>. <em>Right-hand panel:</em> Stacked spectral from low- and high-surface brightness regions in System <em>B</em>, extracted from within and outside of the 8\u03c3 contours. The best-fitting models are shown in dash\u2013dotted and dotted curves for low- and high-surface brightness spectra, respectively. Similar to the models for System <em>A</em>, we fix \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> to be 20\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> as measured from the galaxy spectrum. Although these models with fixed \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> also provide a worse fit to the data compared with the models presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> where \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> is a free parameter, the difference in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_\\nu$|</span> is not as significant as the difference seen in System <em>A</em>. This is consistent with System <em>A</em> having a steeper velocity gradient across the nebulae, leading to a more significant smearing effect in the stacked spectra from a large area.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figC1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure C1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041figa1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=T5h1dzAqhR43DMZE099mTBf~7wxwzCi288jKBqBeo6olWpKl1z~U44x9MWZ9q13Lfu1KEu0KrL6C3eg2Pj2U08BSyttySN-ngoNcXAs5HeSDgQab3W8enMoSICblQ1oj30t6Ss6q9DrEUpFERIL~Y49XzGxFYEBmEXgyI7Ewl~smmb9tBdz4lJqDCQrCR93KM6Nzl~Dn2SgpW5RZQEda4h5R4dFTq4Gq5GiFbxKSubZZsz~OS4POKqFBfdoXZfL9soasnWyWOurRY7aDj1rhNaN62POI3SYmOqVTkuD36gf5Zqx6yvNuPJx5zngNtjuU0PBzaUaGLbvHGYrfHNa~PA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left-hand panel: Stacked spectra from all spaxels within the 3\u03c3 contour in System A, divided into northern and southern nebulae (see Figs\u00a01 and\u00a06). The best-fitting models are shown in dash\u2013dotted and dotted curves for the northern and southern nebula, respectively. To obtain the best-fitting models, we fix the intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 line width \u03c3i to be 95\u00a0km\u2009s\u22121, corresponding to the observed line width measured from the nebular emission lines (see Section\u00a04.3 and Table\u00a05). Compared with the best-fitting models shown in Fig.\u00a010 in the main text where \u03c3i is a free parameter, the models shown here with a fixed \u03c3i provide a worse fit to the data (particularly on the blue peak), which is also reflected with the increased $\\chi ^2_\\nu$. Right-hand panel: Stacked spectral from low- and high-surface brightness regions in System B, extracted from within and outside of the 8\u03c3 contours. The best-fitting models are shown in dash\u2013dotted and dotted curves for low- and high-surface brightness spectra, respectively. Similar to the models for System A, we fix \u03c3i to be 20\u00a0km\u2009s\u22121 as measured from the galaxy spectrum. Although these models with fixed \u03c3i also provide a worse fit to the data compared with the models presented in Fig.\u00a010 where \u03c3i is a free parameter, the difference in $\\chi ^2_\\nu$ is not as significant as the difference seen in System A. This is consistent with System A having a steeper velocity gradient across the nebulae, leading to a more significant smearing effect in the stacked spectra from a large area.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049577/stab1041figa1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049577\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041figa1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=3ft1Tjn0BW5CKr4hX0j0Z9rV1OniLtKWv0bmQE1JGPLlgQwE41vLj1hzhAH1clm3Ed9XAn7KimHVy9rNdPUxG2O3aJfFysEzp0f0zTuu3Dksry3LLcGbp8w2GPdkYqf2x1Jee8MeqKg-l5Wiiie-VaqMbsgqmX-hpdb6Smsr08ZWO4u7lFZ2WD3PP2XqY0GXjpR6oPvdx2RIb2IgAsnBwWV4m1mg2dU7PqR068C4Si8gWcbOLkZtXsveA3oy3dAn3-tOWQRgnoE-aJBUrFbLjmGnJKknyA0zDQ2l99vCqV4Xw9kbUgWqnS7pHFbiBAiDSIvfobPsB1ze7X-ywRwtHQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049577&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left-hand panel:</em> Stacked spectra from all spaxels within the 3\u03c3 contour in System <em>A</em>, divided into northern and southern nebulae (see Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>). The best-fitting models are shown in dash\u2013dotted and dotted curves for the northern and southern nebula, respectively. To obtain the best-fitting models, we fix the intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 line width \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> to be 95\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, corresponding to the observed line width measured from the nebular emission lines (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.3</a> and Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). Compared with the best-fitting models shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> in the main text where \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> is a free parameter, the models shown here with a fixed \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> provide a worse fit to the data (particularly on the blue peak), which is also reflected with the increased <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_\\nu$|\u2060</span>. <em>Right-hand panel:</em> Stacked spectral from low- and high-surface brightness regions in System <em>B</em>, extracted from within and outside of the 8\u03c3 contours. The best-fitting models are shown in dash\u2013dotted and dotted curves for low- and high-surface brightness spectra, respectively. Similar to the models for System <em>A</em>, we fix \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> to be 20\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> as measured from the galaxy spectrum. Although these models with fixed \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> also provide a worse fit to the data compared with the models presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> where \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> is a free parameter, the difference in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_\\nu$|</span> is not as significant as the difference seen in System <em>A</em>. This is consistent with System <em>A</em> having a steeper velocity gradient across the nebulae, leading to a more significant smearing effect in the stacked spectra from a large area.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049578 id=\"246049578\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec12>APPENDIX D: Ly\u2009\u03b1 LINE PROFILE FROM ACCELERATING AND DECELERATING EXPANDING CLOUDS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We present the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles emergent at different distances from the centre of a spherical cloud undergoing, respectively, an accelerating and decelerating expansion. The physical parameters of the cloud are <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N(\\hbox{H i})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}= 20$|\u2060</span>, \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u00a0= 0\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> (i.e. all Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons are emitted at the same frequency), and <em>T</em><sub>eff</sub>\u00a0= 10<sup>4</sup> K. The accelerating cloud has a velocity field changing from 0\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> at the centre to 400\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> at the outer edge of the cloud with a constant radial acceleration, while the decelerating cloud has a reverse gradient changing from 0 to 400\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> from the outer edge to the centre of the cloud. We extract the emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles in two projected distance bins from the cloud centre, with an inner bin corresponding to the distance range [0, 0.5<em>R</em><sub>max</sub>] and an outter bin corresponding to [0.5<em>R</em><sub>max</sub>, <em>R</em><sub>max</sub>], where <em>R</em><sub>max</sub> is the radius of the cloud. Note that given a fixed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N(\\hbox{H i})$|\u2060</span>, changing the physical value of <em>R</em><sub>max</sub> does not change the shape of the emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile and therefore <em>R</em><sub>max</sub> is not a parameter in the model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles from these two bins are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figD1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figD1\" data-open=\"figD1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">D1</a>. For the decelerating cloud, the dominant red peak is more blueshifted in the outer bin, while the opposite trend is observed for the accelerating cloud. While the amount of shift in velocity and the profile shapes do not match well with the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles presented in the this work, this simple exercise demonstrates that differential velocity fields in expanding clouds might be a plausible mechanism to produce velocity gradients seen in spatially resolved Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles.</p>                        <a id=\"246049581\" scrollto-destination=\"246049581\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figD1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure D1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041figa2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=NwtN-1PUYre6BlZjVuWMSJjVAWS~WeC3rMG2ApX6Owu6kUv16obWr50D-Q6GgHyGoQvdmxZ5lPpTAzQ590C6xmrjWizSwMIWOhndICB1JeJWY4EBotE-f11l5HWiY4mZ~LnIIj9ipESN1C9~pbtDamdgt9ODTRQ1JiJiBXJ-0xn~A7j9XtgxHdLuuHm54YeKSzEjCfNAgOpdl309WZIAVQ6yKOpyKHJuKPcc0P7WEk0dyreoueAyQBXt-WxWSxmFJdY~sWYm-jbfvLWARjNne5nXC9HigiX4GZEE9Cg8-t6MzmpldEUtz1R9qap48~pg2flqG5nKi2QAUCaWguUR3w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left-hand panel: Emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from the inner and outer bins of a decelerating expanding cloud. The inner and outer bins correspond to the projected distance range of [0, 0.5Rmax] and [0.5Rmax, Rmax] from the centre of the cloud, respectively, where Rmax is the radius of the cloud. The dominant red peak of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles is more blueshifted in the outer bin. The full spectrum extracted from the entire cloud is shown in the dashed black curve. Right-hand panel: same as the left-hand panel but for an accelerating expanding cloud. The profile is more redshifted in the outer bin, contrary to the trend observed for a decelerating cloud.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049581/stab1041figa2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049581\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041figa2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=Sqv1QFPCfjEGbLEgyHCAxyLd0fXO1wxvr9mXRPPFPXHn1~7cWCGuhsUP4qz60yUr-wtgzizDcFpR0gLFKXRiWZ89tPNOWYkWdy93aiXtu6cbJuWNJ6PwZbQCcu2ytO7w3Jn7XXUyte7-LU0ZeeMHHR6SNNlUAv7LZGUuQr7hDIbbv2TgxWhAsN-gOPDVahfDgxdTXip665L6AU9KxFibSbpnWMzDszLpbKPic~uJCBPlXmHVuGvmaJj-yLqpd81BRlRV~jJo8c9W7qQe6DHk~cQYeeuk2Q-gM1p3wofskoiEkutlXii-DYu7FUMozndFu9cJFrLc2WIybYHtXi5Q4Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049581&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left-hand panel:</em> Emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from the inner and outer bins of a decelerating expanding cloud. The inner and outer bins correspond to the projected distance range of [0, 0.5<em>R</em><sub>max</sub>] and [0.5<em>R</em><sub>max</sub>, <em>R</em><sub>max</sub>] from the centre of the cloud, respectively, where <em>R</em><sub>max</sub> is the radius of the cloud. The dominant red peak of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles is more blueshifted in the outer bin. The full spectrum extracted from the entire cloud is shown in the dashed black curve. <em>Right-hand panel:</em> same as the left-hand panel but for an accelerating expanding cloud. The profile is more redshifted in the outer bin, contrary to the trend observed for a decelerating cloud.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figD1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure D1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041figa2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=NwtN-1PUYre6BlZjVuWMSJjVAWS~WeC3rMG2ApX6Owu6kUv16obWr50D-Q6GgHyGoQvdmxZ5lPpTAzQ590C6xmrjWizSwMIWOhndICB1JeJWY4EBotE-f11l5HWiY4mZ~LnIIj9ipESN1C9~pbtDamdgt9ODTRQ1JiJiBXJ-0xn~A7j9XtgxHdLuuHm54YeKSzEjCfNAgOpdl309WZIAVQ6yKOpyKHJuKPcc0P7WEk0dyreoueAyQBXt-WxWSxmFJdY~sWYm-jbfvLWARjNne5nXC9HigiX4GZEE9Cg8-t6MzmpldEUtz1R9qap48~pg2flqG5nKi2QAUCaWguUR3w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Left-hand panel: Emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from the inner and outer bins of a decelerating expanding cloud. The inner and outer bins correspond to the projected distance range of [0, 0.5Rmax] and [0.5Rmax, Rmax] from the centre of the cloud, respectively, where Rmax is the radius of the cloud. The dominant red peak of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles is more blueshifted in the outer bin. The full spectrum extracted from the entire cloud is shown in the dashed black curve. Right-hand panel: same as the left-hand panel but for an accelerating expanding cloud. The profile is more redshifted in the outer bin, contrary to the trend observed for a decelerating cloud.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049581/stab1041figa2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049581\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041figa2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=Sqv1QFPCfjEGbLEgyHCAxyLd0fXO1wxvr9mXRPPFPXHn1~7cWCGuhsUP4qz60yUr-wtgzizDcFpR0gLFKXRiWZ89tPNOWYkWdy93aiXtu6cbJuWNJ6PwZbQCcu2ytO7w3Jn7XXUyte7-LU0ZeeMHHR6SNNlUAv7LZGUuQr7hDIbbv2TgxWhAsN-gOPDVahfDgxdTXip665L6AU9KxFibSbpnWMzDszLpbKPic~uJCBPlXmHVuGvmaJj-yLqpd81BRlRV~jJo8c9W7qQe6DHk~cQYeeuk2Q-gM1p3wofskoiEkutlXii-DYu7FUMozndFu9cJFrLc2WIybYHtXi5Q4Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049581&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041figa2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left-hand panel:</em> Emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from the inner and outer bins of a decelerating expanding cloud. The inner and outer bins correspond to the projected distance range of [0, 0.5<em>R</em><sub>max</sub>] and [0.5<em>R</em><sub>max</sub>, <em>R</em><sub>max</sub>] from the centre of the cloud, respectively, where <em>R</em><sub>max</sub> is the radius of the cloud. The dominant red peak of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles is more blueshifted in the outer bin. The full spectrum extracted from the entire cloud is shown in the dashed black curve. <em>Right-hand panel:</em> same as the left-hand panel but for an accelerating expanding cloud. The profile is more redshifted in the outer bin, contrary to the trend observed for a decelerating cloud.</p></div></div>        <!-- /foreach -->\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-metadata-standalone-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n\r\n        \r\n                    <h2 class=\"authorNotes-section-title\" id=\"authorNotesSectionTitle\" scrollto-destination=\"authorNotesSectionTitle\">Author notes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"afn1\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"afn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">\u2020</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">mandychen@uchicago.edu</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"afn2\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"afn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">\u2021</span></span><div The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System A at a surface brightness of ${\\\\rm SB}_{{\\\\rm Ly}\\\\,\\\\alpha }=3.7\\\\times 10^{-18} \\\\, \\\\mathrm{erg \\\\, s^{-1} \\\\, cm^{-2} \\\\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a05.1 below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at z\u00a0= 3.038. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around lensed images of galaxies A1, A2, and A3, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Note that the galaxy A1 at z\u00a0= 3.0364 is magnified but not multiply lensed. Cluster member galaxy Gm1 is located close to lensed images of System A and is individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a03. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is $L_{{\\\\rm Ly}\\\\,\\\\alpha }=(5.2\\\\pm 0.1)\\\\times 10^{42} \\\\, {\\\\rm erg\\\\, s^{-1}}$ (see Section\u00a05.1).\"}\r\n    </script>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:site_name\" content=\"OUP Academic\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:type\" content=\"article\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:title\" content=\"Resolved galactic superwinds reconstructed around their host galaxies at z &amp;gt; 3\"/>\r\n        <meta property=\"og:description\" content=\"ABSTRACT. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System A at a surface brightness of ${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 &#197; (see Section&#160;5.1 below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at z&#160;= 3.038. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around lensed images of galaxies A1, A2, and A3, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Note that the galaxy A1 at z&#160;= 3.0364 is magnified but not multiply lensed. Cluster member galaxy Gm1 is located close to lensed images of System A and is individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section&#160;3. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is $L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$ (see Section&#160;5.1).\"/>\r\n<meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Chen, Mandy C\" /><meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, The University of Chicago, Chicago, IL 60637, USA\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Chen, Hsiao-Wen\" /><meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, The University of Chicago, Chicago, IL 60637, USA\" /><meta name=\"citation_author\" content=\"Gronke, Max\" /><meta name=\"citation_author_institution\" content=\"Department of Physics\u00a0&amp; (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n            hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\"                 <div class=\"wi-date\">15 April 2021</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<script>\r\n    $(document).ready(function () {\r\n class=\"toolbar-wrap js-toolbar-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"toolbar-inner-wrap\">\r\n                    <ul id=\"Toolbar\" role=\"navigation\">\r\n    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf js-item-pdf\">\r\n        <a class=\"al-link pdf article-pdfLink\" data-article-id=\"6226641\" href=\"/mnras/article-pdf/504/2/2629/37750404/stab1041.pdf\">\r\n            <img class=\"at-views-dropdown drop-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-dropdown=\"FilterDrop\" aria-haspopup=\"true\">\r\n                                <i class=\"icon-menu_views\"></i>\r\n                                <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Mandy C Chen, Hsiao-Wen Chen, Max Gronke, Michael Rauch, Tom Broadhurst,  Resolved galactic superwinds </div>\r\n</div>\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\r\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049422 id=\"246049422\" class=\"abstract-title js-splitscreen-abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper presents a detailed analysis of two giant Lyman-alpha (Ly\u2009\u03b1) arcs detected near galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038 and <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754 lensed by the massive cluster MACS\u20091206\u22120847 (<em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.44). The Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae revealed in deep MUSE observations exhibit a double-peaked profile with a dominant red peak, indicating expansion/outflowing motions. One of the arcs stretches over 1 arcmin around the cluster Einstein radius, resolving the velocity field of the line-emitting gas on kpc scales around three star-forming galaxies of 0.3\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.6\\, L_*$|</span> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038. The second arc spans 15 arcsec in size, roughly centred around two low-mass Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitters of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 0.03\\, L_*$|</span> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. All three galaxies in the <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038 group exhibit prominent damped Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption (DLA) and several metal absorption lines, in addition to nebular emission lines such as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lambda \\, 1640$|</span> and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb1906, 1908. Extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission appears to emerge from star-forming regions with suppressed surface brightness at the centre of each galaxy. Significant spatial variations in the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profile are observed which, when unaccounted for in the integrated line, leads to biased constraints for the underlying gas kinematics. The observed spatial variations indicate the presence of a steep velocity gradient in a continuous flow of high column density gas from star-forming regions into a low-density halo environment. A detailed inspection of available galaxy spectra shows no evidence of AGN activity in the galaxies, and the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals are primarily explained by resonant scattering. The study presented in this paper shows that spatially resolved imaging spectroscopy provides the most detailed insights yet into the kinematics of galactic superwinds associated with star-forming galaxies.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix at-ArticleMetadata\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: evolution&quot;\">galaxies: evolution</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;intergalactic medium&quot;\">intergalactic medium</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: ISM&quot;\">galaxies: ISM</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: kinematics and dynamics&quot;\">galaxies: kinematics and dynamics</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049424 id=\"246049424\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The formation and evolution of galaxies are intimately connected to the properties of the circumgalactic medium (CGM). Characterizing the interactions between galaxies and their surrounding gas, such as gas infall and outflows, is a critical step towards improving our still patchy understanding of the life cycles of baryons and galaxy evolution over cosmic time. But because of the low-density nature of the CGM, studying such tenuous gas has historically relied on absorption spectroscopy along individual QSO sightlines. Over the past few decades, absorption-line studies have yielded sensitive, mostly one-dimensional constraints on the gas density, temperature, metallicity, and kinematics in the circumgalactic space (see the review by Chen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Tumlinson, Peeples\u00a0&amp; Werk <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib133\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib133\" data-open=\"bib133\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Rudie et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>, and references therein). However, uncertainties remain in connecting gas to galaxies in the absence of a spatially resolved two-dimensional map of the gas. To access the spatial information of gas distribution in the CGM, direct detections of the tenuous gas in emission provide a promising avenue. The hydrogen Ly\u2009\u03b1 line, being the strongest emission line expected of photoionized gas at a temperature <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$T\\sim 10\\, 000$|</span> K, provides a sensitive probe of the tenuous CGM (e.g. Osterbrock\u00a0&amp; Ferland <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Draine <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). At <em>z</em> \u2248 2\u20137, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line at 1215 \u00c5 is conveniently redshifted into the atmospheric transmission window and becomes accessible on the ground. In the past two decades, narrow-band imaging and deep long-slit spectroscopic observations have successfully revealed extended line-emitting gas around galaxies (e.g. Adelberger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Rauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Steidel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Xue et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib143\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib143\" data-open=\"bib143\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and QSOs (e.g. Hennawi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Cantalupo, Lilly\u00a0&amp; Haehnelt <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Cantalupo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Those observations have shed light on several important physical processes in the CGM, such as the ubiquity of large-scale gas flows on 10\u2013100 physical kpc (pkpc) scales at high redshifts (e.g. Rauch, Becker\u00a0&amp; Haehnelt <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and the non-trivial contribution of star-forming galaxies to reionization (e.g. Dijkstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Matthee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The recent advent of high-throughput, wide-field optical integral field spectrographs (IFSs) on large ground-based telescopes, such as the Multi Unit Spectroscopic Explorer (MUSE) on the Very Large Telescopes (VLT) (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and the Keck Cosmic Web Imager (KCWI) on the Keck Telescopes (Morrissey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), has brought a significant breakthrough in systematically uncovering extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission in typical, low-mass galaxies as well as QSOs at <em>z</em> \u2248 2\u20137 (e.g. Borisova et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Cai et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Leclercq et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Arrigoni Battaia et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). These sensitive IFS observations have uncovered extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission out to &gt;20\u00a0times the spatial extent of the stellar continuum, and revealed key insights into the physical nature of these extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 sources. For example, significant spatial variations of Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles are directly observed within a single line-emitting nebula (e.g. Rauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Vanzella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib136\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib136\" data-open=\"bib136\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Erb, Steidel\u00a0&amp; Chen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). In addition, there exists a positive correlation between the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line and the continuum UV brightness of the associated star-forming galaxies (e.g. Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib142\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib142\" data-open=\"bib142\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Leclercq et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>), indicating an intimate connection between the origin of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons and star-forming activities (e.g. Dijkstra\u00a0&amp; Kramer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Cantalupo <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Multiple processes can lead to Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission in the CGM, such as fluorescence powered by ionizing photons from star-forming regions or active galactic nuclei (AGNs), cooling radiation, and scattering of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons by mostly neutral hydrogen gas (e.g. Hogan\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Gould\u00a0&amp; Weinberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Cantalupo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Faucher-Gigu\u00e8re et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Kollmeier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Hennawi\u00a0&amp; Prochaska <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Disentangling different processes that contribute to the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal is challenging due to the resonant scattering nature of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons, especially when Ly\u2009\u03b1 is the only observable line feature from the emission regions. At the same time, the detailed double-peaked profiles of spectrally resolved Ly\u2009\u03b1 lines provide a sensitive probe of the underlying gas kinematics. It is expected that Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission originating in infalling and outflowing medium will result in blue-enhanced and red-enhanced peak, respectively (e.g. Dijkstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, and references therein). This has motivated increasingly sophisticated Monte Carlo radiative transfer models that incorporate different gas geometry and kinematics to accurately track Ly\u2009\u03b1 photon scattering and infer the physical properties of the gaseous clouds (e.g. Dijkstra, Haiman\u00a0&amp; Spaans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Hansen\u00a0&amp; Oh <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Verhamme, Schaerer\u00a0&amp; Maselli <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Laursen, Sommer-Larsen\u00a0&amp; Andersen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Schaerer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Gronke, Bull\u00a0&amp; Dijkstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These Monte Carlo Ly\u2009\u03b1 radiative transfer codes can generally reproduce the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 line width based on a combination of thermal broadening and bulk motions, but significant discrepancies are also seen between observations and model predictions (Verhamme et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib138\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib138\" data-open=\"bib138\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Kulas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Orlitov\u00e1 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Such discrepancies have both theoretical and observational implications. Theoretically, there is a lot of room for better capturing the physical processes in radiative transfer simulations, such as a realistic treatment of dust attenuation and gas clumpiness (e.g. Laursen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Dijkstra\u00a0&amp; Kramer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gronke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Observationally, as Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons are scattered both in spectral and spacial dimensions, it is critical to obtain observations with not only high spectral resolution, but also high spatial resolution to provide the best constraints on the source environment.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing provides sharpened images of the high-redshift Universe via an enhanced spatial resolution of highly magnified images of distant galaxies (e.g. Coe et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and recently individual, luminous high-redshift stars (Kelly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Massive galaxy and cluster lenses have revealed detailed properties of lensed background sources down to sub-kpc or even as detailed as tens of pc scales (e.g. Livermore et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bordoloi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Berg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Florian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Multiply lensed QSOs and extended, lensed arcs of bright background sources have been used to spatially resolve the diffuse CGM in absorption spectroscopy (Rauch et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Chen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Zahedy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib145\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib145\" data-open=\"bib145\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Lopez et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Rubin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Mortensen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>). Several gravitationally lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae have also been reported, in which the enhanced spatial resolution has aided to reveal the underlying physical environment of the source in greater details (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib131\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib131\" data-open=\"bib131\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Patr\u00edcio et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Claeyssens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>; Erb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we present a detailed analysis of two gravitationally lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae, System <em>A</em> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) and System <em>B</em> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), detected in deep MUSE observations of the field around the strong lensing cluster, MACS\u20091206\u22120847 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 0.44 (hereafter MACS\u20091206). Both nebulae are multiply lensed to form giant tangential arcs in the image plane around the Einstein radius of the foreground cluster, and both exhibit a double-peaked Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile. In particular, the serendipitous alignment of the nebula in System <em>A</em> results in an extended low surface brightness arc of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }\\approx 3\\times 10^{-18}\\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> and \u22481 arcmin in length, comprising three contiguous lensed images (Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), while System <em>B</em> forms an arc of \u224815 arcsec in length with high surface brightness peaks exceeding <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }\\approx 2\\times 10^{-17}\\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>. In addition, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting region in System <em>A</em> consists of two separate nebulae, detached from a group of three continuum sources with one being an <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 1.6\\, L_*$|</span> galaxy and the other two being sub-<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> galaxies. All three of these galaxies exhibit prominent interstellar absorption lines, including hydrogen damped Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption (DLA) in their spectra. One of the sub-<em>L</em><sub>*</sub> galaxies (<em>A</em>3 in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> below) is further resolved into two high-intensity peaks. In contrast, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebula in System <em>B</em> exhibits a symmetric morphology in the source plane, centred approximately at two compact continuum sources separated by \u22480.1 arcsec (\u22480.3\u20130.5 arcsec in the image plane), both of which are low-luminosity <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 0.03\\, L_*$|</span> Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitters (LAE) with a rest-frame Ly\u2009\u03b1 equivalent width of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$W ({\\rm Ly\\,\\alpha })\\approx 30\\, \\text{A}$|\u2060</span>.</p>                        <a id=\"246049431\" scrollto-destination=\"246049431\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=MrB3udd7Uroryv2Epfg0yTma3xRx1C904L87fVrbwyPlBDq9OQ35ro~vxSExcgUfWUebxj7RkN9n~fr-kM-6IAXcZIUB7j1UY5NauZzCblC1t1lmVlcgWkqARLOARMr3Ol6WazG1MvyHe1VjW8wdkmNnnG36iCR3jiivbBfxhzGgihHpPKjEwoEQE-KUbaTXtRvkDfwRbP~~nr2TUJCkcXyrWMLILY4SClHqrbtntSwvS6nPL9i4VqQrdPdl-vQMbKBC12lQvc6SjBFtzvCCCL7xFxAVsjfDhjBEVj2L9Q40BBcxXh0H~1YfW7AzGjJvIs6Fcc1yP5BukHDUUx52xQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Composite image of the core region of MACS\u20091206, produced using HST F475W (blue), F814W (green), and F160W (red) images. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System A at a surface brightness of ${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a05.1 below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at z\u00a0= 3.038. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around lensed images of galaxies A1, A2, and A3, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Note that the galaxy A1 at z\u00a0= 3.0364 is magnified but not multiply lensed. Cluster member galaxy Gm1 is located close to lensed images of System A and is individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a03. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is $L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$ (see Section\u00a05.1).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049431/stab1041fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049431\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=Y-ecEzQnwrq38WuslkGLdkIQ9ocCN8RTh0Pt7m~qT81YE5hbDnKqVotmaDCn3vTn3Nkf9JUDmTRTWYHuiKnizibT6SiRDVuNwinMTvgmWZNknrkHkF5B65IU2mE0VKkNcibnB~o-ipU~yGfl5WABUygTHQ-F-CgmQMQ7twvbSyyOKkT1NyqrYPhShegCZ2epxJuyAWUQvSkMaQS6yJVDJxN7wHJJfGrDSZPOZmJbl5in7UqlMSSCWxGNWEVpwUgLN-F3zFd0YAQZeJvDvSfcI03dYbmZhKPulQelxBCWCoTvT0TMxbpx85Gmet-3OZC4He~ihUEgXb1Ix9AAmqKrLA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049431&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Composite image of the core region of MACS\u20091206, produced using <em>HST F</em>475<em>W</em> (blue), <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> (green), and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> (red) images. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System <em>A</em> at a surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around lensed images of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Note that the galaxy <em>A</em>1 at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.0364 is magnified but not multiply lensed. Cluster member galaxy Gm1 is located close to lensed images of System <em>A</em> and is individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig1.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=MrB3udd7Uroryv2Epfg0yTma3xRx1C904L87fVrbwyPlBDq9OQ35ro~vxSExcgUfWUebxj7RkN9n~fr-kM-6IAXcZIUB7j1UY5NauZzCblC1t1lmVlcgWkqARLOARMr3Ol6WazG1MvyHe1VjW8wdkmNnnG36iCR3jiivbBfxhzGgihHpPKjEwoEQE-KUbaTXtRvkDfwRbP~~nr2TUJCkcXyrWMLILY4SClHqrbtntSwvS6nPL9i4VqQrdPdl-vQMbKBC12lQvc6SjBFtzvCCCL7xFxAVsjfDhjBEVj2L9Q40BBcxXh0H~1YfW7AzGjJvIs6Fcc1yP5BukHDUUx52xQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Composite image of the core region of MACS\u20091206, produced using HST F475W (blue), F814W (green), and F160W (red) images. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System A at a surface brightness of ${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a05.1 below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at z\u00a0= 3.038. The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System B at ${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$, integrated over the spectral window of 5766\u20135796 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a05.1 below). The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System <em>B</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, integrated over the spectral window of 5766\u20135796 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around the lensed images of galaxy <em>B</em> consisting of components <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Cluster member galaxies Gm2 and Gm3 are located close to lensed images of System <em>B</em> and are individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(9.8\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{41} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig2.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=SqpSHO~WoQ5rxZA~2ebCgSh06npMIvr6AtK-IZOqlKgi2ynAmwrr8KzkJGk8zWCBWBlBMyCkI-n~yyDQ-olGH7kf-RXQ3mC3IX6AxXk15ZsOuvTKWLf06GCb9KO9Yhmza1FIbvyIDaR0rCsbyCkurpYF6otnVhMORWPLWizV8E7HwmgT4B80uJ8M0cZ-T1Ly-koYR2f4eakiWYioqPTxX7PtAf0VNZ3uCoXnZ~wNYNOWfBKa09klVsckznO6HM3kEPWr5uTwPWhp~50Nq3mHMjy7ISvLbbhU-3g5pvfPP5fawxXSgt97VSiDHkqKY18u5697~OqNWl7001bi3MzhsQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Same as Fig.\u00a01, while highlighting the configuration of System B.
