The white contours indicate the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission associated with System <em>B</em> at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm SB}_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, integrated over the spectral window of 5766\u20135796 \u00c5 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below). The surface brightness limit corresponds to a 3\u03c3 limiting flux over a circular aperture of 1 arcsec in diameter, roughly the size of the PSF measured in the MUSE data. The yellow contours show the critical curve of the cluster lens for a source at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. The left-hand panels show zoomed-in regions around the lensed images of galaxy <em>B</em> consisting of components <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, along with the Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours. Cluster member galaxies Gm2 and Gm3 are located close to lensed images of System <em>B</em> and are individually optimized in the lens modelling process as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. After correcting for the lensing magnification, the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from the nebula is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\,\\alpha }=(9.8\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{41} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this study, we examine the underlying gas flows by combining spatially resolved Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission profiles from MUSE and known star formation properties of the neighbouring galaxies from available <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) broad-band photometry. This paper is organized as follows. First, the archival data included in our analysis are presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">2</a>, including broad-band imaging data by <em>HST</em> and IFS data by VLT/MUSE. The lens models fine-tuned to best reproduce multiple images from Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>. In Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>, we present detailed analysis of UV continuum galaxies and the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line-emitting gas, respectively. We discuss our results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a>, and conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a>. Throughout this paper, we adopt a Hubble constant of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0= 70\u00a0km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub>\u00a0= 0.3, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda = 0.7$|</span> when deriving distances, masses, and luminosities. All magnitudes quoted are in the AB system.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049434 id=\"246049434\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 OBSERVATIONAL DATA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MACS\u20091206 is a well-studied cluster, which was first identified as a luminous X-ray source in the <em>ROSAT</em> All Sky Survey (Voges et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib140\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib140\" data-open=\"bib140\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; B\u00f6hringer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) and later confirmed to be a massive, strong-lensing cluster by the Massive Cluster Survey (Ebeling, Edge\u00a0&amp; Henry <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Ebeling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). It was also selected as one of the 25 clusters in the <em>Cluster Lensing And Supernova Survey with Hubble</em> (CLASH) program (Postman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Exquisite imaging and spectroscopic data of this cluster field are available in public data archives, including high-quality multiband imaging data from the <em>HST</em>, follow-up galaxy spectroscopic survey data from the CLASH-VLT redshift survey (Biviano et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Rosati et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and wide-field IFS data obtained using VLT/MUSE (Bacon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). High-level science products are retrieved from these public data archives for our study. In this section, we provide a summary of these data products.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049436 id=\"246049436\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>2.1 <em>HST</em> images</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">High spatial resolution, UV, optical, and near-infrared imaging data of the field around MACS\u20091206 obtained using the <em>HST</em> were retrieved from the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST) archive<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> (PI: M. Postman). These include images taken using the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS), the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3), and a suite of UV, optical, and near-infrared filters (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> below). Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> show composite images of the central region of MACS\u20091206 from combining <em>F</em>475<em>W</em> (blue), <em>F</em>814<em>W</em> (green), and <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> (red) images, highlighting the lensing configurations of System <em>A</em> and System <em>B</em>, respectively. Detailed photometric properties of each system derived from these <em>HST</em> data are described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the close proximity of <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 in the source plane (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a> below), it is possible that they correspond to distinct star-forming regions in the same galaxy at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. However, without high-resolution infrared data, we cannot determine confidently whether or not <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 originate in the same galaxy. We therefore proceed with referring to <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 as individual galaxies for simplicity.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049439 id=\"246049439\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>2.2 MUSE IFS data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Wide-field IFS data of MACS\u20091206 were obtained using MUSE on the VLT UT4. The observations were carried out under Program ID\u2019s 095.A-0181(A) and 097.A-0269(A) to cover an effective area of 2.63 arcmin<sup>2</sup> around the cluster in three pointings (PI: J. Richard), which are part of a systematic survey of 12 strong lensing clusters using MUSE (Richard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2021</a>). In the region where lensed images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are found, a total exposure time of \u22484\u00a0h was collected. Pipeline-processed and flux-calibrated data cubes were retrieved from the ESO Phase 3 Archive, covering a wavelength range of 4750\u20139300 \u00c5 with a spectral resolution of FWHM \u2248 170 (110) \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> at \u22485000 (7000) \u00c5 and a pixel scale of 0.2 arcsec\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.2 arcsec. The mean point spread function (PSF) in the final combined data cube was determined using a bright star, and found to be \u22481 arcsec at 7000 \u00c5. Astrometry of the combined MUSE data cube was recalibrated to match the world coordinate system of available <em>HST</em> images. The pipeline-generated combined data cube contains non-negligible sky residuals that affected the detection of faint emission features. Additional sky subtraction was therefore performed using a median sky residual spectrum generated from object-free spaxels in the data cube. Detailed spectroscopic properties of both continuum sources and Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae are described in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>, respectively. Finally, the wavelength array is converted to vacuum to facilitate accurate velocity calculations based on known rest-frame UV wavelengths.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049441 id=\"246049441\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 CLUSTER LENS MODELLING</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">To determine the intrinsic properties of both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, it is necessary to construct a cluster lens model to correct for the gravitational lensing effect. Here, we employ the software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> (version 6.5) (Jullo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) to construct a parametric cluster lens model of MACS\u20091206 by incorporating known multiply lensed galaxies identified in the MUSE data (Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and those reported in the literature (e.g. Umetsu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib134\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib134\" data-open=\"bib134\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Zitrin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib147\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib147\" data-open=\"bib147\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Eichner et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). As both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are in the core region of the cluster, we only include the strong lensing constraints and do not consider weak lensing effect in our lens modelling process. We first obtain a fiducial cluster lens model that gives a good fit to a total of 72 multiple images from 21 background sources. Those images cover a field of view (FOV) of \u22482 arcmin relatively evenly, providing robust constraints for the projected cluster mass distribution within this FOV. We then fine-tune the lens model by considering only multiple images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, optimizing the mass distribution projected close to those particular images as well as the multiply lensed extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae. Details regarding the lens modelling process are described below.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049443 id=\"246049443\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Fiducial cluster lens model</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Following Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), we adopt a parametric model based on a pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distribution (PIEMD) (Kassiola\u00a0&amp; Kovner <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>) of ellipticity \u03f5 and include two additional isothermal halo components to represent the cluster-scale diffuse mass. This three-halo configuration is found to minimize the dispersion between predicted and observed image positions for all multiply lensed sources (see Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>, for detailed discussions). The convergence of PIEMD is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1619361932826\" content-id=\"update1619361932826\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _\\mathrm{ c} = \\frac{\\sigma _{v}^2}{2\\, G\\, \\Sigma _{\\mathrm{ cr}}\\, \\sqrt{R_{\\epsilon }^{2}+r_{\\mathrm{ c}}^{2}}} ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>R</em><sub>\u03f5</sub> is the distance from the centre of the cluster, defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nR_{\\epsilon }^2 = \\frac{x^2}{(1+\\epsilon)^2}+\\frac{y^2}{(1-\\epsilon)^2},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div><em>r</em><sub>c</sub> is the core radius, and \u03a3<sub>cr</sub> is the projected critical mass density. Given the angular diameter distances between the observer and the lens (<em>D<sub>l</sub></em>), the lens and the source (<em>D<sub>ls</sub></em>), and the observer and the source (<em>D<sub>s</sub></em>), the projected critical mass density is defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1619361989971\" content-id=\"update1619361989971\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\Sigma _{\\mathrm{ cr}} = \\frac{c^2}{4\\pi G}\\frac{D_s}{D_lD_{ls}}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>All six parameter of the three PIEMD haloes (x, y, <em>r<sub>c</sub></em>, \u03f5, position angle, velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>v</em></sub>) are free to vary. We also include external shear (parametrized by the intensity \u03b3<sub>shear</sub> and position angle \u03b8<sub>shear</sub>) to account for possible massive structures in regions further away from the cluster core.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the cluster-scale diffuse mass distribution, we account for local perturbations in the vicinity of individual galaxies by including 128 cluster member galaxies in the lens model. These member galaxies are selected based on their redshifts in the catalogue of Molino et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), which is downloaded from the MAST archive.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> We first eliminate galaxies fainter than <em>AB</em>\u00a0= 24 mag in the <em>F</em>160<em>W</em> band. For galaxies with spectroscopic redshifts, we select those with 0.425 &lt; <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub> &lt; 0.453. For galaxies without <em>z</em><sub>spec</sub>, we apply the same criterion based on available photometric redshifts. A total of 128 cluster members are selected from this exercise. Note that in general, the cluster lensing potential is dominated by the large-scale diffuse mass distribution, which is primarily in the form of dark matter. Member galaxies only introduce perturbations local to the location of individual galaxies. Therefore, in cases where lensed images do not appear close to individual member galaxies (\u22645 arcsec, corresponding to typical Einstein radius of individual galaxies), the variation in the selection of member galaxies does not introduce significant uncertainties to the cluster lensing potential. However, in cases where lensed images form close to individual galaxies, careful modelling of those individual galaxies is required to accurately reproduce the positions of nearby images. As our goal here is to obtain a good cluster-scale lens model instead of optimizing individual galaxy mass distributions, we exclude image systems 2, 7, 13, 21, 24, and 27 in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) (see their fig.\u00a01), whose multiple images fall very close to massive cluster member galaxies. This way we do not need to fine-tune every member galaxy with lensed images nearby and still maintain the accuracy of the large-scale cluster lens model.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We include cluster member galaxies as 128 dual pseudo-isothermal elliptical mass distributions (dPIE) (El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) located at their detected light centroids, with the ellipticity and position angle fixed to their observed values obtained from the Molino et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) catalogue. The convergence of the dPIE profile is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1619362188013\" content-id=\"update1619362188013\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\kappa _g = \\frac{\\sigma _{g,v}^2}{2\\, G\\, \\Sigma _{\\mathrm{ cr}}}\\left(\\frac{1}{R_{g,\\epsilon }}-\\frac{1}{\\sqrt{R_{g,\\epsilon }^2+r_{g,t}^2}}\\right) ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where <em>r<sub>g, t</sub></em> is the truncation radius. To reduce the total number of free parameters, we scale all 128 member galaxies with a constant mass-to-light ratio through <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\sigma _{g,v} = \\sigma _{g,v}^0(\\frac{L}{L_0})^{\\frac{1}{4}}, \\, r_{g,t} = r_{g,t}^0(\\frac{L}{L_0})^{\\frac{1}{4}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>where <em>L</em><sub>0</sub> is the reference luminosity with magnitude <em>m</em><sub><em>F</em>814<em>W</em></sub>\u00a0= 19.6. Hence there are only two free parameters for member galaxies: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _{g,v}^0$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$r_{g,t}^0$|\u2060</span>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Constraints of this fiducial cluster lens model are positions of 72 multiple images from 21 background sources identified by Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), excluding image systems 2, 7, 13, 21, 24, and 27 for reasons described above. The optimization is performed based on object positions in the source plane. We obtain similar best-fitting parameters as Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The root-mean-square positional offset between observed and predicted images is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\, {\\rm rms}\\, \\rangle _{\\rm im} =0{_{.}^{\\prime\\prime}} 76$|</span> in the image plane, averaged over all 72 images of 21 sources. The rms position offsets for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are found to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\, {\\rm rms}\\, \\rangle _{\\rm im}=0.38$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\langle \\, {\\rm rms}\\, \\rangle _{\\rm im}=0. 73$|</span> arcsec, respectively. In the Appendix, we list the coordinates and redshifts of all 72 images used as constraints, as well as the best-fitting model parameters.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049448 id=\"246049448\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Fine-tuned lens model for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the fiducial cluster lens model described above, we now optimize the lens model for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> separately to ensure the highest accuracy in matching the observed locations of multiply lensed images in these two systems. In the fiducial model, the respective centres of the three cluster-scale PIEMD haloes are located at \u22482 arcsec from the brightest cluster galaxy (BCG), \u224813 arcsec north-west and \u224830 arcsec south-east of the BCG (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA2\" data-open=\"tblA2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a> for a summary). As the south-east cluster-scale PIEMD halo occurs close to the lensed images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, we obtain a refined lens model, leaving all parameters of this PIEMD halo free while fixing the other two cluster-scale PIEMD haloes to their best-fitting parameters in the fiducial model. We also notice that three of the cluster member galaxies (marked as Gm1, Gm2, and Gm3 in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>) are located close to some images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. We therefore allow the velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>g, v</em></sub> and truncation radius <em>r<sub>g, t</sub></em> of these three cluster members to vary freely in the fine-tuned model optimization, instead of being scaled together with the rest of member galaxies. Finally, the external shear parameters are fixed to their best-fitting values in the fiducial model.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because we are particularly interested in accurately producing the lensing effect for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, we also include constraints from the two substructures of <em>A</em>3 (designated <em>A</em>31 and <em>A</em>32 in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>), and the fainter galaxy <em>B</em>2 in System <em>B</em>, which are not used in Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). With a total of 18 multiple images of <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> as constraints (the first 18 entries in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>), we then run <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstool</span> again with the above set-up, and obtain a fine-tuned model. This model places significantly more weight on the local perturbers (Gm1, Gm2, and Gm3) and provides much improved root-mean-square positional offsets for the systems of interest in this study. The rms position offsets for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are reduced to rms<sub>im</sub>\u00a0= 0.1 arcsec and rms<sub>im</sub>\u00a0= 0.21 arcsec, respectively. The best-fitting parameters are listed Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA3\" data-open=\"tblA3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a> in the Appendix. In Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show the predicted critical curves by this fine-tuned model for sources at the redshifts of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. Mean lensing magnification factors of multiple images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> based on the fine-tuned lens model are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Wherever required in subsequent analyses, we use this fine-tuned model to derive image position deflections and magnifications.</p>                        <a id=\"246049451\" scrollto-destination=\"246049451\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mean lensing magnification of multiple images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. Calculated based on the fine-tuned lens model as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3.2</a>.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mu }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mu }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>1\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>15.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.3\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>10.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>5.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>13.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>6.2\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mu }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mu }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>1\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>15.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.3\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>10.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>5.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>13.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>6.2\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049451\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Mean lensing magnification of multiple images of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mu }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mu }$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><em>A</em>1\u00a0</td><td>3.8\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>15.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.3\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>10.4\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>5.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.1\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>1<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>7.5\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.5\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>a</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.2\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>4.4\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>13.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td><em>A</em>3<em>c</em>\u00a0</td><td>6.2\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>d</em>\u00a0</td><td>12.0\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td><em>B</em>2<em>e</em>\u00a0</td><td>8.4\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049451\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049452 id=\"246049452\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 ANALYSIS: GALAXY PROPERTIES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> comprise two distinct components: (1) the continuum sources detected in the broad-band <em>HST</em> images and (2) the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae that are more spatially extended than the continuum sources and are only visible in the MUSE IFS data. Available broad-band photometry and spectra of the galaxies provide important constraints for the star formation histories and the underlying stellar populations. In this section, we investigate the properties of the galaxies by analysing the photometric and spectroscopic data of the continuum sources. We will present the analysis of the associated Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049454 id=\"246049454\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Photometric properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Accurate photometric measurements of galaxies in Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> are challenging due to the crowding of members of the lensing cluster and non-negligible intracluster light (e.g. Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). We first measure broad-band magnitudes of individual lensed images of each galaxy in different bandpasses using a combination of circular and isophotal apertures determined by <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (v.2.19.5; Bertin\u00a0&amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>). These measurements (presented in the Appendix) are then corrected for lensing magnifications based on the fine-tuned lens model (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 in System <em>A</em>, their <em>b</em> images occur between two bright foreground galaxies, resulting in uncertain background subtraction in the photometric measurements. The de-magnified apparent magnitudes of <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 are therefore determined based on an average of images a and c. The de-magnified magnitudes of <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 in image <em>a</em> are \u22480.2 mag fainter than that in image c, suggesting that the true magnification factor for image <em>a</em> relative to image <em>c</em> is smaller than what is predicted by the lens model. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5</a> below, we also show that the apparent Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness in the extended nebulae from image <em>a</em> is fainter than what is seen in images <em>b</em> and <em>c</em>, supporting a smaller relative magnification factor at the location of image <em>a</em>. Such a discrepancy in image brightnesses is commonly seen in strongly lensed galaxies and quasars, and is often due to the limited accuracy of lens models and/or the presence of small-scale substructures in the lens (e.g. McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The discrepancy of \u22480.2 mag seen here is within the typical scatter of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim 25{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> between de-lensed magnitudes of multiply lensed galaxies in cluster lenses (e.g. Lam et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>). By averaging the de-lensed magnitudes between images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em>, we therefore mitigate the effect of lensing uncertainty on the magnification of these two galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Similarly, the <em>b</em> images of galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 are excluded due to the contamination from the nearby cluster member galaxy Gm3. In addition, image <em>e</em> of <em>B</em>1 is unusually bright compared with its counter part in images <em>a, c</em>, and <em>d</em>, which are between 0.8 and 1.2 mag fainter than image <em>e</em> across different bandpasses after the lensing correction. Such an enhancement in brightness is not observed in image <em>e</em> of <em>B</em>2. This brightness anomaly of <em>B</em>1<em>e</em> can also be seen in the colour image in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and may be attributed to magnification perturbation caused by unseen substructures local to <em>B</em>1<em>e</em> (e.g. McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Consequently, the de-magnified apparent magnitudes of <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 are determined by averaging measurements of images <em>a, c</em>, and <em>d</em>. Finally, Galactic extinction corrections are calculated using the NED Galactic Extinction Calculator<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> and applied to the observed magnitudes in individual bandpasses following the Schlafly\u00a0&amp; Finkbeiner (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) extinction map.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For galaxies in System <em>A</em> (<em>B</em>), the bandpasses bluer of <em>F</em>390<em>W</em> (<em>F</em>475<em>W</em>) correspond to rest-frame wavelengths \u03bb<sub>rest</sub> &lt; 912\u00c5, and no fluxes are detected above the background noise. We therefore place a 2\u03c3 upper limit of the observed flux in each of these bandpasses. Unfortunately, these images are not sufficiently sensitive to provide meaningful constraints for the escape fraction of ionizing photons from these galaxies. The final de-magnified apparent magnitudes of galaxies <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> in different bandpasses are presented in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, while the direct measurements of individual images are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a> for reference.</p>                        <a id=\"246049459\" scrollto-destination=\"246049459\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of galaxy photometry for System <em>A</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>.</p></div> class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn4\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn4\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>.<sup><em>a</em></sup> All magnitudes are de-magnified based on the lens model described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>., and averaged among images <em>a, c</em>, and <em>d</em>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn5\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn5\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> At <em>z</em>\u00a0= 4, typical star-forming galaxies have <em>M</em><sub>1500</sub>*\u00a0= \u221221.1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1 (e.g. Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn6\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn6\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup> 2\u03c3 UV flux upper limit, averaged among the <em>F</em>225<em>W, F</em>275<em>W, F</em>336<em>W, F</em>390<em>W</em>, and <em>F</em>435<em>W</em> bandpasses.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn7\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn7\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup> 2\u03c3 flux upper limit.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049460\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To characterize the intrinsic luminosities of these galaxies, we also estimate the rest-frame UV absolute magnitudes at 1500 \u00c5, <em>M</em><sub>1500</sub>, using the observed <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> (<em>F</em>775<em>W</em>) brightness for galaxies in System <em>A</em> (<em>B</em>). At the respective redshifts of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, these bandpasses correspond roughly to the rest-frame 1500 \u00c5, and provide a robust estimate of the intrinsic UV luminosity. The absolute magnitudes of <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, <em>A</em>3, <em>B</em>1, and <em>B</em>2, at rest-frame 1500 \u00c5 are found to be <em>M</em><sub>1500</sub>\u00a0= \u221221.52, \u221219.87, \u221219.63, \u221217.23, and \u221217.01, corresponding to 1.61, 0.35, 0.28, 0.03, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.03\\, L_*$|\u2060</span>, respectively, for a characteristic rest-frame absolute magnitude of <em>M</em><sub>*</sub>\u00a0= \u221221 (e.g. Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Reddy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049462 id=\"246049462\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2>4.2 Stellar population parameters</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The observed broad-band spectral energy distributions (SEDs) of galaxies in Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> based on the photometric measurements presented in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> are typical of star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3\u20134 (e.g. Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). To quantify the star formation histories, we perform a stellar population synthesis analysis using <em>Bayesian Analysis of Galaxies for Physical Inference and Parameter EStimation</em> (<span class=\"small-caps\">bagpipes</span>, Carnall et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), which employs the 2016 version of the Bruzual\u00a0&amp; Charlot (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) stellar synthesis models. We assume an exponentially declining star formation model, SFR(<em>t</em>)\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>e</em><sup>\u2212<em>t</em>/\u03c4</sup>, where \u03c4 represents the e-folding time and is a free parameter, and infer the stellar mass (<em>M</em><sub>star</sub>), star formation rate (SFR), age and dust extinction (<em>A<sub>V</sub></em>) of the continuum sources in both systems based on the observed SEDs from <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> to <em>F</em>160<em>W</em>. Because of a strong degeneracy between stellar age, metallicity, and dust attenuation (e.g. Conroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), we impose a metallicity prior based on the mass\u2013metallicity relation for high-redshift galaxies (e.g. Ma et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and fix the metallicity of <em>A</em>1 to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$20{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> of the solar value, 10\u00a0per\u2009cent for <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, and 5\u00a0per\u2009cent for <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$16{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span>\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$84{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> confidence intervals in <em>M</em><sub>star</sub>, SFR, age, and <em>A<sub>V</sub></em> are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. All five galaxies are best characterized by a long star formation e-folding time that exceeds \u03c4\u00a0= 1\u00a0Gyr, along with a relatively young, best-fitting stellar age. In particular, the best-fitting stellar ages for galaxies in System <em>A</em> are less than 200\u00a0Myr, making the adopted exponentially declining star formation model equivalent to a constant SFR scenario. This makes the inferred stellar age and SFR insensitive to the adopted star formation history, either exponentially declining or rising (Reddy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). As discussed below, a constant star formation history is also consistent with the spectral features uncovered in the MUSE data. The inferred SFR for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 range between 10 and 100 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\rm M}_\\odot \\, {\\rm yr}^{-1}$|</span> and <em>M</em><sub>star</sub> between 10<sup>9</sup> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10^{10}\\, {\\rm M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>, typical of UV luminous star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u2248 3 (e.g. Shapley <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). In contrast, galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 have significantly lower SFR and stellar mass with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm star}\\approx 10^8\\, {\\rm M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>, more typical of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitters (LAE) at <em>z</em> \u2248 3 with a characteristic star formation time-scale of \u2272 1\u00a0Gyr (e.g. Feltre et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"246049465\" scrollto-destination=\"246049465\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">SED fitting results, showing <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$16\\,\\, \\mathrm{ per\\, cent}$|</span>\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$84\\,\\,\\mathrm{ per \\,cent}$|</span> confidence interval for each parameter.</p></div> </div><div 0.91]\u00a0</td><td>[0.43,1.31]\u00a0</td><td>[1.31,4.35]\u00a0</td><td>[0.47,0.74]\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049465\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049466 id=\"246049466\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>4.3 Spectroscopic properties</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3\u20134, available MUSE data cover the rest-frame wavelength range from \u03bb<sub>rest</sub> &gt; 1200 \u00c5 to \u03bb<sub>rest</sub> &lt; 1920 \u00c5, and provide additional constraints for the star-forming interstellar medium (ISM) and the stellar populations in Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. We extract individual galaxy spectra using spherical apertures centred on the location of the continuum sources, with varying sizes for different images depending on the intrinsic image size and magnification. Because galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 are blended in the ground-based MUSE data, we are only able to extract a single spectrum for these two galaxies. The extracted spectra (without lensing correction) are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, along with the corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectra. For galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, the spectra shown are combined from images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em>, while image <em>b</em> is excluded due to possible contamination from nearby cluster member galaxies. Similarly for <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, image b is excluded from the combined spectrum due to possible contamination from the nearby elliptical galaxy. Note that the brightness anomaly of <em>B</em>1e described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a> does not affect the spectral features due to the achromatic nature of lensing. Image <em>e</em> is therefore included in the combined spectrum.</p>                        <a id=\"246049468\" scrollto-destination=\"246049468\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=4OAdQGvQptKQyvBvtj7zl~v1KN4mIGKLDVbGsIy0s0azge~ES32ez739gVyCJK3yf7yZtF1bviKZZoUVCUQJOeGoV9xvZRyOvmTqnJ4p5nH1K7SSI9q8480Mk32GhCOUuwzZrc1nVE3NFmHC8jQ7cjbsL0GImdTFcVSNBv7CMn03EF9uCwNS~jHjbl22db9tdgbm40jU~TfVjihcotA47Yv30I2EbSz~crX708pnnQyJEoGfXY5C8FHnvuPzx1RyKcdJJx1l1YF7pz-nGPzfTTX9uW5AjR9SlW5gVtXcGnvGKToOPheKL3F8PajUQsJCxqlZXknussW8JDBOHGdc-A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sky-subtracted spectra of Systems A and B without lensing magnification corrections. For A2 and A3, multiple images a and c are stacked. For B1\u00a0+\u00a0B2 combined spectrum, images a, c, d, and e are stacked. Rest-frame wavelength is calculated according to the best-fitting redshift of each galaxy, as marked in their individual panels. The corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectrum is shown in blue in each panel. The red dashed lines indicate major emission features and the green dotted lines indicate major absorption features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049468/stab1041fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049468\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=BtI~4A8-PR8SHKpVFoqedZNbtui4uyq4r50kFNja-vZNRvfZy6bMyb27ywBl4wo3ioeJ7Qg3nXWueh1IU4KYXBRPzf5Y0ABs3p9PvTNiTN9Wepo8Abz0~3gIBRkGjjx2LfZryCKew~JUYJ0UgHuJYCiJVx0OwveRaYvN6OKF9z-ul8zEW3qe5sJSsl3bk9S5DiWo-~7SZDCmcaQ62lY8tMiDwS3-WmurBsnoKFmkzJ91TfEePxHKRc9~29ALhJVf495OI9vfLsu3z6lFv2bwqXwWeA2TydH7aMoto4U59KENY8FoZ0WzcjAhqNB7GOrI0AouMrNJtMZFsL33w6H8rA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049468&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sky-subtracted spectra of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> without lensing magnification corrections. For <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, multiple images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> are stacked. For <em>B</em>1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>B</em>2 combined spectrum, images <em>a, c, d</em>, and <em>e</em> are stacked. Rest-frame wavelength is calculated according to the best-fitting redshift of each galaxy, as marked in their individual panels. The corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectrum is shown in blue in each panel. The red dashed lines indicate major emission features and the green dotted lines indicate major absorption features.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=4OAdQGvQptKQyvBvtj7zl~v1KN4mIGKLDVbGsIy0s0azge~ES32ez739gVyCJK3yf7yZtF1bviKZZoUVCUQJOeGoV9xvZRyOvmTqnJ4p5nH1K7SSI9q8480Mk32GhCOUuwzZrc1nVE3NFmHC8jQ7cjbsL0GImdTFcVSNBv7CMn03EF9uCwNS~jHjbl22db9tdgbm40jU~TfVjihcotA47Yv30I2EbSz~crX708pnnQyJEoGfXY5C8FHnvuPzx1RyKcdJJx1l1YF7pz-nGPzfTTX9uW5AjR9SlW5gVtXcGnvGKToOPheKL3F8PajUQsJCxqlZXknussW8JDBOHGdc-A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Sky-subtracted spectra of Systems A and B without lensing magnification corrections. For A2 and A3, multiple images a and c are stacked. For B1\u00a0+\u00a0B2 combined spectrum, images a, c, d, and e are stacked. Rest-frame wavelength is calculated according to the best-fitting redshift of each galaxy, as marked in their individual panels. The corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectrum is shown in blue in each panel. The red dashed lines indicate major emission features and the green dotted lines indicate major absorption features.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049468/stab1041fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049468\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig3.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=BtI~4A8-PR8SHKpVFoqedZNbtui4uyq4r50kFNja-vZNRvfZy6bMyb27ywBl4wo3ioeJ7Qg3nXWueh1IU4KYXBRPzf5Y0ABs3p9PvTNiTN9Wepo8Abz0~3gIBRkGjjx2LfZryCKew~JUYJ0UgHuJYCiJVx0OwveRaYvN6OKF9z-ul8zEW3qe5sJSsl3bk9S5DiWo-~7SZDCmcaQ62lY8tMiDwS3-WmurBsnoKFmkzJ91TfEePxHKRc9~29ALhJVf495OI9vfLsu3z6lFv2bwqXwWeA2TydH7aMoto4U59KENY8FoZ0WzcjAhqNB7GOrI0AouMrNJtMZFsL33w6H8rA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049468&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Sky-subtracted spectra of Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> without lensing magnification corrections. For <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, multiple images <em>a</em> and <em>c</em> are stacked. For <em>B</em>1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>B</em>2 combined spectrum, images <em>a, c, d</em>, and <em>e</em> are stacked. Rest-frame wavelength is calculated according to the best-fitting redshift of each galaxy, as marked in their individual panels. The corresponding 1\u03c3 error spectrum is shown in blue in each panel. The red dashed lines indicate major emission features and the green dotted lines indicate major absorption features.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectra of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 are characterized by three distinct features: (1) a blue continuum consistent with the broad-band photometry presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>; (2) strong interstellar absorption due to neutral hydrogen and heavy ions (marked in green, dotted line) that are commonly seen in <em>z</em> \u2248 3 galaxies (e.g. Shapley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Erb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and (3) nebular emission lines due to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda \\, 1640$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1660,1666$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1906,1908$|\u2060</span>, as well as excited <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Si ii}$|</span>*\u03bb\u20091264, 1309, and 1530 lines. The strong DLA features observed in the spectra of galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 reveal the presence of a significant amount of neutral gas in the ISM of these galaxies. A Voigt profile analysis of the red damping wing at the systemic redshifts of these galaxies (see below) yields best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{H i}$|</span> column densities of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{i}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}=20.9\\pm 0.1$|\u2060</span>, 21.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1, and 21.3\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.1 for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, respectively, indicating a minimum surface neutral gas mass density of \u03a3<sub>gas</sub>\u00a0= 8\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$20\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot \\, {\\rm pc}^{-2}$|\u2060</span>. The best-fitting DLA profiles are presented in the top row of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. Note that the blue-side of the observed DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground and therefore excluded from the fit.</p>                        <a id=\"246049470\" scrollto-destination=\"246049470\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=jBQubozZbKjDKkx~K9MEXV0nUxfAubaYcDeJ20Isa3RGasiznQqD6zpKOArk2p6C91SECoDCDQ7Q1RYHIEGKa0~KwEFcAXGbMUFgV~tLM19jUYUgZlXymnwArGGDP08yJAyHIGZNQvF28EEWL680BqLF-8ZcWgXMiQuPydYtvqRMUGohwY605lh7oc6xZH1fpCKzCqHR5~Raj1zl6NKN5xwXJXponVamVbf3-bUPzCHp7lf0TZQfvJD4z3iDWjrRj~gsNpA1eAYhNAKj0g4pIQL2ogvhjM5~opcDb6XjI3S61OKz0N-End0NnPkO2DETlNiS8QvFY0shF~lPw4fpnw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the ISM absorption and emission features of Systems A (left three columns) and B (right column). Zero velocity corresponds to the systemic redshift determined from nebular emission lines of each galaxy (see Table\u00a05). The red curve in the $\\hbox{H i}$ panels shows the best-fitting DLA profile with the estimated $N({\\rm H\\, i})$ displayed at the top of each column. At negative velocities, the DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground. The $\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$ absorption profiles are presented in the second and third rows, showing blue absorption tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$. The 4th\u20136th rows show the low-ionization lines $\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$, $\\hbox{Si ii}\\lambda \\, 1526$, and $\\hbox{Fe ii}1608$, which exhibit asymmetric absorption profiles with extended blue tails, indicating the presence of gas outflows in the ISM. The best-fitting Gaussian models of $\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$, $\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$, and $\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$ emission lines are shown in red curves in bottom five rows. $\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$ is fitted with a single Gaussian. The doublets are all fitted with a double Gaussian, and the separation between two Gaussian components are fixed by their rest-frame wavelength separation. We fix the flux ratio $\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1666$/$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1660$ \u00a0=\u00a02.5. The redshift is tied to be consistent among all lines in each galaxy, and the best-fitting values (shown at the top of each column) set the zero velocity marked by the vertical dotted line. Data spectrum (continuum normalized) is shown in black, 1\u03c3 error spectrum in blue, and the best-fitting models in red. Flux and rest-frame equivalent width measured from the best-fitting models for each emission line is listed in Table\u00a05. While galaxies B1/B2 display a strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 and modest $\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$ emission features, the data quality is not sufficient to place meaningful constraints on $\\hbox{He ii}$, or $\\hbox{O iii}$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049470/stab1041fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049470\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=nuZCVtOGNlTW6jUy7ZMJfVfSXg0tgeg-Qh1VDcan1KzC3ZdW--gOGlCPlJz3HRjMdSbCdIJHHt5LyaqnLL8pJ61is8Zhl3NopTOECXMLZUwyt3dhzMKXjWY-cXBSCexBG1pHfwivpG18AxijFXHPTDQGOYNC~3vzTH-nyNi2~Rpi7CA-FV2xNzv-8AaguAmmPv8fr7qu77DcTH069nEijqaEsrM1vwGwpv1ogSgXaTLdiebXCKxyfPfHZq47tcenRBf4oILwTiRkguyNmzXe2Wafzh1R3pbBX-z4YByTw8cMFP-3i-pUlIghgeFoh9UU6yrfsIwK9Sq5hhEKzQFHLw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049470&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the ISM absorption and emission features of Systems <em>A</em> (left three columns) and <em>B</em> (right column). Zero velocity corresponds to the systemic redshift determined from nebular emission lines of each galaxy (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). The red curve in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{H i}$|</span> panels shows the best-fitting DLA profile with the estimated <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N({\\rm H\\, i})$|</span> displayed at the top of each column. At negative velocities, the DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> absorption profiles are presented in the second and third rows, showing blue absorption tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. The 4th\u20136th rows show the low-ionization lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Si ii}\\lambda \\, 1526$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Fe ii}1608$|\u2060</span>, which exhibit asymmetric absorption profiles with extended blue tails, indicating the presence of gas outflows in the ISM. The best-fitting Gaussian models of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$|</span> emission lines are shown in red curves in bottom five rows. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|</span> is fitted with a single Gaussian. The doublets are all fitted with a double Gaussian, and the separation between two Gaussian components are fixed by their rest-frame wavelength separation. We fix the flux ratio <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1666$|</span>/<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda 1660$|</span> \u00a0=\u00a02.5. The redshift is tied to be consistent among all lines in each galaxy, and the best-fitting values (shown at the top of each column) set the zero velocity marked by the vertical dotted line. Data spectrum (continuum normalized) is shown in black, 1\u03c3 error spectrum in blue, and the best-fitting models in red. Flux and rest-frame equivalent width measured from the best-fitting models for each emission line is listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. While galaxies <em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2 display a strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 and modest <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$|</span> emission features, the data quality is not sufficient to place meaningful constraints on <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}$|\u2060</span>, or <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}$|\u2060</span>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=jBQubozZbKjDKkx~K9MEXV0nUxfAubaYcDeJ20Isa3RGasiznQqD6zpKOArk2p6C91SECoDCDQ7Q1RYHIEGKa0~KwEFcAXGbMUFgV~tLM19jUYUgZlXymnwArGGDP08yJAyHIGZNQvF28EEWL680BqLF-8ZcWgXMiQuPydYtvqRMUGohwY605lh7oc6xZH1fpCKzCqHR5~Raj1zl6NKN5xwXJXponVamVbf3-bUPzCHp7lf0TZQfvJD4z3iDWjrRj~gsNpA1eAYhNAKj0g4pIQL2ogvhjM5~opcDb6XjI3S61OKz0N-End0NnPkO2DETlNiS8QvFY0shF~lPw4fpnw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Summary of the ISM absorption and emission features of Systems A (left three columns) and B (right column). Zero velocity corresponds to the systemic redshift determined from nebular emission lines of each galaxy (see Table\u00a05). The red curve in the $\\hbox{H i}$ panels shows the best-fitting DLA profile with the estimated $N({\\rm H\\, i})$ displayed at the top of each column. At negative velocities, the DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground. The $\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$ absorption profiles are presented in the second and third rows, showing blue absorption tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$. The 4th\u20136th rows show the low-ionization lines $\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$, $\\hbox{Si ii}\\lambda \\, 1526$, and $\\hbox{Fe ii}1608$, which exhibit asymmetric absorption profiles with extended blue tails, indicating the presence of gas outflows in the ISM. The best-fitting Gaussian models of $\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$, $\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$, and $\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$ emission lines are shown in red curves in bottom five rows. $\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$ is fitted with a single Gaussian. Flux and rest-frame equivalent width measured from the best-fitting models for each emission line is listed in Table\u00a05. While galaxies B1/B2 display a strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 and modest $\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$ emission features, the data quality is not sufficient to place meaningful constraints on $\\hbox{He ii}$, or $\\hbox{O iii}$.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049470/stab1041fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049470\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig4.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=nuZCVtOGNlTW6jUy7ZMJfVfSXg0tgeg-Qh1VDcan1KzC3ZdW--gOGlCPlJz3HRjMdSbCdIJHHt5LyaqnLL8pJ61is8Zhl3NopTOECXMLZUwyt3dhzMKXjWY-cXBSCexBG1pHfwivpG18AxijFXHPTDQGOYNC~3vzTH-nyNi2~Rpi7CA-FV2xNzv-8AaguAmmPv8fr7qu77DcTH069nEijqaEsrM1vwGwpv1ogSgXaTLdiebXCKxyfPfHZq47tcenRBf4oILwTiRkguyNmzXe2Wafzh1R3pbBX-z4YByTw8cMFP-3i-pUlIghgeFoh9UU6yrfsIwK9Sq5hhEKzQFHLw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049470&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the ISM absorption and emission features of Systems <em>A</em> (left three columns) and <em>B</em> (right column). Zero velocity corresponds to the systemic redshift determined from nebular emission lines of each galaxy (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>). The red curve in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{H i}$|</span> panels shows the best-fitting DLA profile with the estimated <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N({\\rm H\\, i})$|</span> displayed at the top of each column. At negative velocities, the DLA profiles are contaminated by the forest of Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorption lines in the foreground. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iv}\\lambda \\lambda \\, 1548,1550$|</span> absorption profiles are presented in the second and third rows, showing blue absorption tail extending beyond \u22122500 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. The 4th\u20136th rows show the low-ionization lines <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C ii}\\lambda \\, 1334$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Si ii}\\lambda \\, 1526$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{Fe ii}1608$|\u2060</span>, which exhibit asymmetric absorption profiles with extended blue tails, indicating the presence of gas outflows in the ISM. The best-fitting Gaussian models of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{O iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1660,1666$|\u2060</span>, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{C iii}\\lambda \\lambda 1906,1908$|</span> emission lines are shown in red curves in bottom five rows. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{He ii}\\lambda 1640$|</span> is fitted with a single Gaussian.
