Image e is the only complete image of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission above 3\u03c3 limiting surface brightness.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049498/stab1041fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049498\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig8.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=G8JkiP2lVCur9jOpnBYYPuQsRoFQpMGvzmRbtYE8cEi5bWrCb7KitDZkbEJzheUDCiRDeqgvNpggfJCBRSOV7BgxMsNJIIlz148Ill9Lbx4jWnB248Fq1o-z8K7Kmq9K-9m-5wOzIIuBcnru~MHk8vQLtkJbHZbAN7GeGAo8Ld1Mxes7HA~PisBZ~rqc-ZogFgn5v1usL-HVe9a3A0HeEAvb5DNfQODHN44eDrpeEqZGOz~KIxRppEF13S5AaIl4L~~Z3Ur9TwiabTlOFqlWQynPc7TLv0AG2S14lD7YQ78Vc~qpvUG0f3TbUVyNmQjMAKQX5DtVfY502RWCCacBAA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049498&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the lensing configuration of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 arc in System <em>B</em>. Column (<em>1</em>): pseudo narrow-band image of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission, smoothed with a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 1 arcsec. The contour marks constant surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.8\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, which is detected at the 3\u03c3 level of significance. The star symbols mark the positions of the associated star-forming galaxies identified in <em>HST</em> images, and the yellow contours show the critical curve for a source at <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub>\u00a0= 3.754. The black arrows in the bottom three panels indicate the location of the brightest pixels in images c, d, and e (one pixel from each image) that are included in the template Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectrum used for shell model analysis (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a>). Column (<em>2</em>): contours of multiply lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae overlaid on individual galaxy images in the <em>HST</em> data. Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness contours of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.8\\times 10^{-18}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.5\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> are shown in white and red, respectively. Column (<em>3</em>): the magnification map overlaid with the same Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours to illustrate the spatial variation of lensing magnification across the nebulae. Column (<em>4</em>): de-lensed narrow-band image, smoothed with a Gaussian kernel of FWHM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 0.5 arcsec in the source plane. The white contours mark constant surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.8\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, corresponding to the 3\u03c3 level of significance detected in the image plane, same as contours shown in Column(<em>1</em>). Column (<em>5</em>): de-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 contours overlaid on de-lensed <em>HST</em> data, with the yellow contours showing the caustics in the source plane. The white and red contours mark the 3\u03c3 and 8\u03c3 Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness, same as the contours in Column(<em>2</em>). The cyan dashed arrow shows the direction along which we extract the one-dimensional surface brightness profile (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> below). Compared with System <em>A</em>, the lensing configuration of System <em>B</em> is much more complicated, with images <em>a</em>\u2013<em>d</em> being partial images with different levels of completeness. Image <em>e</em> is the only complete image of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission above 3\u03c3 limiting surface brightness.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use image <em>e</em>, the most complete image among all five multiple images of System <em>B</em>, to compute the total flux of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission. Despite the flux anomaly observed in image <em>e</em> of galaxy <em>B</em>1 as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a>, the effect is likely localized (since image <em>e</em> of <em>B</em>2 does not show the same brightness enhancement) and therefore will not significantly bias the total Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the extended nebula. After correcting the lensing magnification for each spaxel, we obtain a total flux of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }(B)=(7.4\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{-18}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, integrated across the wavelength range of 5766\u20135796 \u00c5 (the same wavelength window for constructing the narrow-band image described above) and summed over all spaxels within the 3\u03c3 contour in image <em>e</em>. At <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754, the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux translates to a total luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }(B)=(9.8\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{41} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For both systems, we also extract the de-lensed one-dimensional Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness profile in the source plane starting from the galaxy continuum regions to the edge of each nebula (near the 3\u03c3 surface brightness contours), as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a> below, we derive the velocity gradient within the nebulae in both systems. As the velocity gradient suggests non-spherical gas flows in both systems, we therefore use a series of 2 arcsec\u00a0\u00d7 0<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$.$|</span>6 arcsec (1 arcsec\u00a0\u00d7 0.15 arcsec) pseudo slits for System <em>A</em> (System <em>B</em>), instead of circular annuli. We then extract the surface brightness profiles along directions guided by the velocity gradient within the nebulae (cyan dashed arrows in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>; also see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a> below). The position angle of the pseudo slit is 25\u00b0 north through east for System <em>A</em> and 60\u00b0 north through west for System <em>B</em>. The first aperture (distance of zero) is centred on the de-lensed locations of galaxy <em>A</em>1 (<em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3) for the northern (southern) nebula in System <em>A</em>, and the distance of the subsequent apertures are measured from these corresponding continuum regions. For System <em>B</em>, the distance is measured from the location of <em>B</em>1, where we put the first aperture. We show the surface brightness profiles for System <em>A</em> both before and after including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux inside the DLA troughs from star-forming regions (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"246049501\" scrollto-destination=\"246049501\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=CQRlHCay~0lvacvT-xJIZvd0Ho0oyUuAArkuMGwcy2p8x5L60DAwld3xm15AEUUB8l8BfgEw04WztRM6z1btQF8Usfndc2cwz1EOiNM4SYt5hGeroxbB-056vOeaIJyftE90Y63GbpK~L2ahxCiGCEM7P7XFDr7cTekyED7h5EsET1mmCyNVy1g~1t6hXUhofLkfmWKb6aNz1otv1FVL-PRuvnie1-uGuQtz8BPrIFX6Wz0dCcDzr0cddX6JfoZ0Kh9Lt9NuagvklkpMyxYgCR~jit5~h0mg4825~2jp699YZ9afUOvvInH1d5dGfX86clevvLfE-q6OWeEEypj5VA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"De-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness profile, extracted along the directions indicated in Figs\u00a07 and\u00a08. For System A, we present the surface brightness profile both before and after including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. Distance is measured from the location of A1 (A2 and A3) for the northern (southern) nebula. For System B, zero distance corresponds to the location of B1. Note that we use rectangle apertures to extract the surface brightness profile as guided by the velocity gradient within the nebulae, instead of circular annuli (see text). In both systems, there is a decrease in surface brightness at small distances. The suppression may be attributed to either attenuation by the observed high neutral gas column density and possibly high dust content in System A or by a reduced total gas column as a result of galactic scale outflows in System B.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049501/stab1041fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049501\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=Yf2NcjrZ0zZGhJzPuU~RGutJ3IUTiZMVv1PGUCh8wGiJue0Moh~FfRyIoK89xZai0SRcMRy2Rt7pbwncz~LPTK~8VvPiceH5X9ljEbA~QXzGSaGnPHArJxkf1lzDKcrrd8aBMQ0gTi9razgFEdd7nJJwPwe9Cvi70pzNqT6Q8Er6QuFU5qNwa8LKYOUaf-PDW~XgshYBUpwarZ~uxuoa4PdqOU3nTsNCcfbfjJPig0FJJH~lzWf1rF~W0wRBADUt-D6N3tNVU5GOCBBniCJ20L0RAq8fUmSKDREyyeF6d9G~62InWOn~2IVJjSj9wcBZK~AigMHkQ4MKxQg2s0fbrg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049501&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">De-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness profile, extracted along the directions indicated in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. For System <em>A</em>, we present the surface brightness profile both before and after including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. Distance is measured from the location of <em>A</em>1 (<em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3) for the northern (southern) nebula. For System <em>B</em>, zero distance corresponds to the location of <em>B</em>1. Note that we use rectangle apertures to extract the surface brightness profile as guided by the velocity gradient within the nebulae, instead of circular annuli (see text). In both systems, there is a decrease in surface brightness at small distances. The suppression may be attributed to either attenuation by the observed high neutral gas column density and possibly high dust content in System <em>A</em> or by a reduced total gas column as a result of galactic scale outflows in System <em>B</em>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=CQRlHCay~0lvacvT-xJIZvd0Ho0oyUuAArkuMGwcy2p8x5L60DAwld3xm15AEUUB8l8BfgEw04WztRM6z1btQF8Usfndc2cwz1EOiNM4SYt5hGeroxbB-056vOeaIJyftE90Y63GbpK~L2ahxCiGCEM7P7XFDr7cTekyED7h5EsET1mmCyNVy1g~1t6hXUhofLkfmWKb6aNz1otv1FVL-PRuvnie1-uGuQtz8BPrIFX6Wz0dCcDzr0cddX6JfoZ0Kh9Lt9NuagvklkpMyxYgCR~jit5~h0mg4825~2jp699YZ9afUOvvInH1d5dGfX86clevvLfE-q6OWeEEypj5VA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"De-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness profile, extracted along the directions indicated in Figs\u00a07 and\u00a08. For System A, we present the surface brightness profile both before and after including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. Distance is measured from the location of A1 (A2 and A3) for the northern (southern) nebula. For System B, zero distance corresponds to the location of B1. Note that we use rectangle apertures to extract the surface brightness profile as guided by the velocity gradient within the nebulae, instead of circular annuli (see text). In both systems, there is a decrease in surface brightness at small distances. The suppression may be attributed to either attenuation by the observed high neutral gas column density and possibly high dust content in System A or by a reduced total gas column as a result of galactic scale outflows in System B.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig9.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049501/stab1041fig9.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig9.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049501\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig9.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=Yf2NcjrZ0zZGhJzPuU~RGutJ3IUTiZMVv1PGUCh8wGiJue0Moh~FfRyIoK89xZai0SRcMRy2Rt7pbwncz~LPTK~8VvPiceH5X9ljEbA~QXzGSaGnPHArJxkf1lzDKcrrd8aBMQ0gTi9razgFEdd7nJJwPwe9Cvi70pzNqT6Q8Er6QuFU5qNwa8LKYOUaf-PDW~XgshYBUpwarZ~uxuoa4PdqOU3nTsNCcfbfjJPig0FJJH~lzWf1rF~W0wRBADUt-D6N3tNVU5GOCBBniCJ20L0RAq8fUmSKDREyyeF6d9G~62InWOn~2IVJjSj9wcBZK~AigMHkQ4MKxQg2s0fbrg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049501&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig9.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">De-lensed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness profile, extracted along the directions indicated in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. For System <em>A</em>, we present the surface brightness profile both before and after including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs at the locations of galaxy continuum. Distance is measured from the location of <em>A</em>1 (<em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3) for the northern (southern) nebula. For System <em>B</em>, zero distance corresponds to the location of <em>B</em>1. Note that we use rectangle apertures to extract the surface brightness profile as guided by the velocity gradient within the nebulae, instead of circular annuli (see text). In both systems, there is a decrease in surface brightness at small distances. The suppression may be attributed to either attenuation by the observed high neutral gas column density and possibly high dust content in System <em>A</em> or by a reduced total gas column as a result of galactic scale outflows in System <em>B</em>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As discussed above, Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness from the southern nebula agrees well across all three multiple images before including Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from DLA troughs, while image <em>a</em> becomes dimmer than images <em>b</em> and <em>c</em> after including the Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux from the DLA troughs, suggesting a relatively smaller magnification factor in image <em>a</em> than what is predicted by the lens model at the locations of <em>A</em>2<em>a</em> and <em>A</em>3<em>a</em>. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> shows that both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> exhibit a general decline in Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness with increasing projected distance. Applying a simple exponential profile to characterize the observed surface brightness, SB(Ly\u2009\u03b1)\u00a0\u221d\u00a0exp(\u2212 <em>D</em>/<em>D<sub>s</sub></em>), we find the best-fitting scale radius of <em>D<sub>s</sub></em> \u2248 18 pkpc for System <em>A</em> and <em>D<sub>s</sub></em> \u2248 1.5\u00a0kpc for System <em>B</em> (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a>), corresponding to a half-light radius of <em>r<sub>e</sub></em> \u2248 30 and 2.5 pkpc for Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, respectively. These are consistent with the typical size found for Lyman break galaxies (e.g. Steidel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) and LAEs (e.g. Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Leclercq et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">At the same time, we also see a suppressed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness at the locations of the galaxies. The suppression resembles what is seen in the \u2018net absorption\u2019 subsample of stacked Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness profiles of Steidel et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). We propose that the suppression may be attributed to attenuation by dusty outflows, which is supported by the observed high neutral gas column density and blueshifted low-ionization ISM absorption line in System <em>A</em>. Under the dusty outflow scenario, the radial extent of the observed dip in the centre of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness profile is then a direct measure of the projected radius of the dusty outflows, which in the present cases amounts to \u2272 5 pkpc for System <em>A</em> and \u2272 1 pkpc for System <em>B</em>. Dust in the ISM could also contribute to the suppression of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal in the gap, which would imply an anisotropic distribution of the dusty material in the ISM given the presence of extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae at larger distances away from the line of sight. Alternatively, the suppression may be attributed to a reduced <em>N</em>(H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) as a result of galactic scale outflows or galaxy interactions (e.g. Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049504 id=\"246049504\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>5.2 Spatial variation of line profiles</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the surface brightness variation in the narrow-band images, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae in both systems exhibit a double-peaked profile with a significantly enhanced red peak that indicates expansion/outflowing motions. In the <em>top-left</em> panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, we present stacked Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectra from the northern and southern nebulae in System <em>A</em>. The spectra are extracted separately from within the 3\u03c3 contours in Column (<em>2</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. In the <em>top-right</em> panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, we present stacked Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectra for System <em>B</em>, extracted from within the low-surface brightness (between 3\u03c3 and 8\u03c3 contours) and high-surface brightness (within the 8\u03c3 contours) regions shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. An overall shift in wavelength, both in the peak locations and the location of the valley of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line, is clearly seen between the northern and southern nebulae in System <em>A</em>, with the northern nebula being blueshifted by \u2248200 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> relative to the southern one, suggesting a large velocity gradient across the line-emitting region. At the same time, no significant differences are seen between low- and high-surface brightness regions in System <em>B</em>.</p>                        <a id=\"246049506\" scrollto-destination=\"246049506\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=XcwwfJRY6L5Xe-DkSqcrZVInIcTQtro8ubDzUKhQc-lWtZJi1ZAAaK9aTWqHrIWiCLLpPR2TG~Xf1IxRfvOa1HCyec0z3cD3tRhLl3BJpdnWybZhOI~qwDFqpqaOEeUmIRK9supPjXM0HBYcmaxAFSfycWONb70i-f7SJMeUo7K8~~LBsOb~B1P4VC54gI30mG5ZzD5f8yvT3vFdnOfPndpZycLgzlo4rSRiKnqcMvaGcNs-p2ffMI3NoMHDUd6-oJ63QMRiAdiM5MfGj5JlLOZKoYAlpNUcRezGcBwo1f9qaccuvUhRMLI2omzBLAigw8Gh5m84ehYA2fYMU-cgkw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spatial variation of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles and its impact on the best-fitting shell model for Systems A (left) and B (right). Top panels display the summed Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles over a large area, while bottom panels display the template Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from localized, small apertures indicated in Fig.\u00a07 for System A and stacked brightest pixels from multiple images c, d, and e for System B (see text) . The corresponding best-fitting model profiles from the expanding shell model described in the text are included as dotted and dash\u2013dotted curves with the best-fitting parameters summarized in the legend, following the order of [$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{i}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}$, $v_{\\rm exp}\\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$, $\\sigma _i \\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$, $\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$, $\\Delta \\, v\\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$]. For the large area sums in the top panels, System A is naturally divided into northern and southern nebulae, while System B is broadly divided by low- and high-surface brightness regions, between, within, and outside of the 8\u03c3 contours. Zero velocity corresponds to zsys\u00a0= 3.0364 for System A, which is the systemic redshift of A1, and zsys\u00a0= 3.7540 for System B, which is the systemic redshift of B1 and B2. The largest distinction between large and small aperture stacks is seen in System A, both in terms of the flux level in the valley between the blue and red peak as well as the profile line width, which is captured by a combination of neutral hydrogen column density $\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{I}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}$, intrinsic line width (\u03c3i), and effective temperature ($\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$). The line profiles are significantly broader in the stacked spectra obtained over a larger area. In contrast, such distinction is much less visible in System B.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049506/stab1041fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049506\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=1Po31QmUcPHpzIcjGSw1hSwJnPAHrWJN4VlpQNAWRr8EVQAwL1HHO1wIrJwMXT-4z3pxC5ah1-e5vx~rxXVko31u1XA01iwdKLUWHjrtGQ2OdwhrAN05eHPGADBriaqdPvQX3cfBP5~cFv4IrMxtTpXaQ5F97X36XzrUGgkPYA9beTZFutcf8Ryi2Si7CiihNxsn6ZGhpHMVz43KO9wN2lTyKQZ3DSu6uWxFesl6FCSn5sMcz2xA4j4z6Ex5lH-XQ0xf45fUl8i6XykdCFw563XjPBmb1-9beZ8Ljm9spDV-hOSy38lq2C0qZ4XpK0aPDScndwmiNvSz8Bt1fgZQ8Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049506&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spatial variation of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles and its impact on the best-fitting shell model for Systems <em>A</em> (<em>left</em>) and <em>B</em> (<em>right</em>). <em>Top</em> panels display the summed Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles over a large area, while <em>bottom</em> panels display the template Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from localized, small apertures indicated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> for System <em>A</em> and stacked brightest pixels from multiple images <em>c, d</em>, and <em>e</em> for System <em>B</em> (see text) . The corresponding best-fitting model profiles from the expanding shell model described in the text are included as dotted and dash\u2013dotted curves with the best-fitting parameters summarized in the legend, following the order of [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{i}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_{\\rm exp}\\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _i \\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v\\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$|</span>]. For the large area sums in the <em>top</em> panels, System <em>A</em> is naturally divided into northern and southern nebulae, while System <em>B</em> is broadly divided by low- and high-surface brightness regions, between, within, and outside of the 8\u03c3 contours. Zero velocity corresponds to <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub>\u00a0= 3.0364 for System <em>A</em>, which is the systemic redshift of <em>A</em>1, and <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub>\u00a0= 3.7540 for System <em>B</em>, which is the systemic redshift of <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2. The largest distinction between large and small aperture stacks is seen in System <em>A</em>, both in terms of the flux level in the valley between the blue and red peak as well as the profile line width, which is captured by a combination of neutral hydrogen column density <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{I}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, intrinsic line width (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>), and effective temperature (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$|\u2060</span>). The line profiles are significantly broader in the stacked spectra obtained over a larger area. In contrast, such distinction is much less visible in System <em>B</em>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig10\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=XcwwfJRY6L5Xe-DkSqcrZVInIcTQtro8ubDzUKhQc-lWtZJi1ZAAaK9aTWqHrIWiCLLpPR2TG~Xf1IxRfvOa1HCyec0z3cD3tRhLl3BJpdnWybZhOI~qwDFqpqaOEeUmIRK9supPjXM0HBYcmaxAFSfycWONb70i-f7SJMeUo7K8~~LBsOb~B1P4VC54gI30mG5ZzD5f8yvT3vFdnOfPndpZycLgzlo4rSRiKnqcMvaGcNs-p2ffMI3NoMHDUd6-oJ63QMRiAdiM5MfGj5JlLOZKoYAlpNUcRezGcBwo1f9qaccuvUhRMLI2omzBLAigw8Gh5m84ehYA2fYMU-cgkw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Spatial variation of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles and its impact on the best-fitting shell model for Systems A (left) and B (right). Top panels display the summed Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles over a large area, while bottom panels display the template Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from localized, small apertures indicated in Fig.\u00a07 for System A and stacked brightest pixels from multiple images c, d, and e for System B (see text) . The corresponding best-fitting model profiles from the expanding shell model described in the text are included as dotted and dash\u2013dotted curves with the best-fitting parameters summarized in the legend, following the order of [$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{i}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}$, $v_{\\rm exp}\\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$, $\\sigma _i \\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$, $\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$, $\\Delta \\, v\\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$]. For the large area sums in the top panels, System A is naturally divided into northern and southern nebulae, while System B is broadly divided by low- and high-surface brightness regions, between, within, and outside of the 8\u03c3 contours. Zero velocity corresponds to zsys\u00a0= 3.0364 for System A, which is the systemic redshift of A1, and zsys\u00a0= 3.7540 for System B, which is the systemic redshift of B1 and B2. The largest distinction between large and small aperture stacks is seen in System A, both in terms of the flux level in the valley between the blue and red peak as well as the profile line width, which is captured by a combination of neutral hydrogen column density $\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{I}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}$, intrinsic line width (\u03c3i), and effective temperature ($\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$). The line profiles are significantly broader in the stacked spectra obtained over a larger area. In contrast, such distinction is much less visible in System B.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig10.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049506/stab1041fig10.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig10.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049506\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig10.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=1Po31QmUcPHpzIcjGSw1hSwJnPAHrWJN4VlpQNAWRr8EVQAwL1HHO1wIrJwMXT-4z3pxC5ah1-e5vx~rxXVko31u1XA01iwdKLUWHjrtGQ2OdwhrAN05eHPGADBriaqdPvQX3cfBP5~cFv4IrMxtTpXaQ5F97X36XzrUGgkPYA9beTZFutcf8Ryi2Si7CiihNxsn6ZGhpHMVz43KO9wN2lTyKQZ3DSu6uWxFesl6FCSn5sMcz2xA4j4z6Ex5lH-XQ0xf45fUl8i6XykdCFw563XjPBmb1-9beZ8Ljm9spDV-hOSy38lq2C0qZ4XpK0aPDScndwmiNvSz8Bt1fgZQ8Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049506&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig10.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spatial variation of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles and its impact on the best-fitting shell model for Systems <em>A</em> (<em>left</em>) and <em>B</em> (<em>right</em>). <em>Top</em> panels display the summed Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles over a large area, while <em>bottom</em> panels display the template Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from localized, small apertures indicated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a> for System <em>A</em> and stacked brightest pixels from multiple images <em>c, d</em>, and <em>e</em> for System <em>B</em> (see text) . The corresponding best-fitting model profiles from the expanding shell model described in the text are included as dotted and dash\u2013dotted curves with the best-fitting parameters summarized in the legend, following the order of [<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{i}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$v_{\\rm exp}\\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _i \\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v\\, {\\rm (km\\, s^{-1})}$|</span>]. For the large area sums in the <em>top</em> panels, System <em>A</em> is naturally divided into northern and southern nebulae, while System <em>B</em> is broadly divided by low- and high-surface brightness regions, between, within, and outside of the 8\u03c3 contours. Zero velocity corresponds to <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub>\u00a0= 3.0364 for System <em>A</em>, which is the systemic redshift of <em>A</em>1, and <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub>\u00a0= 3.7540 for System <em>B</em>, which is the systemic redshift of <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2. The largest distinction between large and small aperture stacks is seen in System <em>A</em>, both in terms of the flux level in the valley between the blue and red peak as well as the profile line width, which is captured by a combination of neutral hydrogen column density <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{I}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, intrinsic line width (\u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>), and effective temperature (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$|\u2060</span>). The line profiles are significantly broader in the stacked spectra obtained over a larger area. In contrast, such distinction is much less visible in System <em>B</em>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To investigate in detail the velocity offset and possible spatial fluctuations in the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles across both nebulae, we need to employ smaller apertures for extracting Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectra. Specifically, we consider two competing factors when determining the extraction apertures: (1) the <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> necessary to obtain significant signal in both the blue and red peaks and (2) possible spatial smearing of the extracted Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile over a large aperture that may lead to erroneous characteristics of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile. Because of the low surface brightness nature across all regions in System <em>A</em>, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line per spaxel does not have sufficiently high signals. We therefore experiment with extracting Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectra from a range of aperture sizes to identify an appropriate aperture size for achieving a sufficiently high <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> while limiting the smearing effect from combining different regions. We obtain the optimal extraction aperture from a localized, small area with a radius of 0.5 arcsec centred near the highest surface brightness peak in the reconstructed source-plane narrow-band image (blue dashed circles in Column 2 of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). We then identify the spaxels located within this area in the image plane in all three multiple images <em>a, b</em>, and <em>c</em>, and construct a template spectrum for System <em>A</em> by coadding the spectra from all identified spaxels, which contains the information of gas properties in the brightest region of the nebula. The template spectrum is displayed in the <em>bottom-left</em> panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although the <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> of the template spectrum is lower than what is seen in the large-area stacks (<em>upper-left</em> panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>), the signal is strong enough to demonstrate the significant difference between the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from small and large areas. Specifically, the template spectrum has a narrower width than the large-area stacks from both the northern and southern nebulae. In addition, the template spectrum exhibits a flux level that is consistent with zero at the bottom of the valley between the red and blue peaks. The observed zero flux in the valley is consistently seen across the nebulae in all spectra extracted from small apertures, and differs from the distinctly non-zero flux observed in the stacked spectra over the larger nebulae (see also fig.\u00a03 of Caminha et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Such difference can be naturally explained by the presence of a large velocity gradient in the nebulae that results in smearing of the combined Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile. But because a non-zero flux in the valley of a double-peaked Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile would lead to very different parameters constraints for the expanding shell model (e.g. Dijkstra et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Hansen\u00a0&amp; Oh <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Verhamme et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Laursen et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Schaerer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Gronke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, also see below), the ability to spatially resolve the velocity field is necessary for obtaining accurate constraints for the underlying gas properties. In our study, we leverage lensing magnifications to resolve spatial variations on scales as small as \u22482 pkpc along both nebulae (Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>) in ground-based, seeing-limited data, though we caution that variations on smaller scales may still be present in these clouds (e.g. Cantalupo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For System <em>B</em>, because the nebula is significantly brighter than what is seen in System <em>A</em> and the distinction in the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile is subtle between different locations, we construct a template spectrum using only the brightest pixels in images <em>c, d</em>, and <em>e</em> (one pixel from each image) to better constrain possible velocity gradient and spatial variation over a small area. The locations of the three brightest pixels included in the template spectrum are indicated by the black arrows in Column (<em>1</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. The template spectrum for System <em>B</em> is displayed in the <em>bottom-right</em> panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>, and does not show significant differences from the stacked spectra from larger areas (<em>upper-right</em> panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049510 id=\"246049510\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>5.3 Physical properties of Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae under an expanding shell model</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We utilize the spatially and spectrally resolved Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles from MUSE observations and a Ly\u2009\u03b1 Monte Carlo radiative transfer code <span class=\"monospace\"><span class=\"small-caps\">tlac</span></span> (Gronke\u00a0&amp; Dijkstra <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Gronke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to model the physical properties of the line-emitting gas. We adopt an expanding shell model that has successfully explained many observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectra across a wide range of redshifts based on a finite set of parameters, including the neutral hydrogen column density, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N(\\hbox{H i})$|\u2060</span>, the expansion velocity, <em>v</em><sub>exp</sub>, intrinsic line width, \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>, effective temperature, <em>T</em><sub>eff</sub>, and systemic velocity, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v$|</span> (e.g. Verhamme et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Gronke <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Yang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib144\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib144\" data-open=\"bib144\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As illustrated in Verhamme et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib137\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib137\" data-open=\"bib137\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), while there are considerable degeneracies between different parameters of the shell model, the peak separation increases primarily with <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N(\\hbox{H i})$|\u2060</span>, and the red-to-blue peak ratio increases with <em>v</em><sub>exp</sub>, while <em>T</em><sub>eff</sub> and \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> set the overall line width (see also Gronke et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, for a more detailed discussion on the effect of these parameters). In most cases this simple shell model provides a crude estimate of the underlying kinematic properties of the gas, but there are also known cases where the model failed to provide a good fit to data (e.g. Kulas et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Orlitov\u00e1 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We note that the shell models are developed for a spherical shell expanding radially outward, which may work better for unresolved Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae under the assumption that the emission sources are at the centre of the gas. In applying these models to System <em>A</em>, for which the Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons may originate outside of the nebulae, we attribute the enhanced red peak in the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile per spaxel to cloud expansion relative to a fiducial reference point interior to the cloud along the observer\u2019s line of sight. In addition, we attribute the observed velocity shear to the motion of this reference point relative to the systemic redshift of the galaxies. Although the source of photons likely lies outside of the nebulae (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a> below for discussions on the origin of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons), the problem is equivalent to extracting the Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal from one hemisphere of a spherical shell. Because of spherical isotropy inherent to the shell model, we expect that considering one hemisphere would result in an overall reduction in the amplitude of the signal, instead of altering the line profile. Guided by this understanding, we proceed with approximating the signal in each spaxel with expectations from an expanding shell model for constraining the systemic velocity at each location.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">For our analysis, we assume a homogeneous medium of constant gas density and compare the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles with predictions over a grid of model parameters. To fully explore the allowed parameter space, we construct a model grid that covers <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N(\\hbox{H i})/{\\rm cm^{-2}}$|</span> from 15.1 to 21.1, <em>v</em><sub>exp</sub> from 10 to 400 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>, \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> from 25 to 700 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, T_{\\rm eff}/{\\rm K}$|</span> from 3.0 to 6.0, and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v$|</span> from \u2212100 to 550 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. The velocity offset, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v$|\u2060</span>, is calculated with respect to the systemic redshift <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub> listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. We use 10\u2009000 photons and 100 frequency bins to generate each model profile. Each model profile is also convolved with MUSE line spread function before compared to observations. Given the uncertainty of the dust attenuation effect on Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons, we do not include dust in our models and it will be explored separately in the future. For each model, we compute a likelihood function <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mathscr L}$|</span> defined as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;&amp;{\\mathscr L}(N_{\\hbox{H i}}, v_{\\rm exp}, \\sigma _i, T_{\\rm eff}, \\Delta \\, v) \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;&amp; = \\prod _j \\exp \\left\\lbrace -\\frac{[D(\\lambda _{j})-M(\\lambda _{j}| N_{\\hbox{H i}}, v_{\\rm exp}, \\sigma _i, T_{\\rm eff}, \\Delta \\, v)]^2}{2\\, S^2(\\lambda _{j})}\\right\\rbrace ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>where <em>D</em>(\u03bb<sub><em>j</em></sub>) and <em>M</em>(\u03bb<sub><em>j</em></sub>) are the observed and model spectra, respectively, and <em>S</em>(\u03bb<sub><em>j</em></sub>) is the corresponding error spectrum. The likelihood function is computed over the wavelength range of 4890\u20134930 \u00c5 (5766\u20135796 \u00c5) for System <em>A</em> (System <em>B</em>), and can be translated to \u03c7<sup>2</sup> following <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2=-2\\ln \\, {\\mathscr L}$|\u2060</span>. We then construct a marginalized likelihood function for each parameter by integrating <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\mathscr L}$|</span> over all other parameters, and find the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$95{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> confidence interval centred around the best-fitting value. Note that since we do not explicitly include turbulent broadening in the models here, the temperature inferred from the model represents an effective temperature that includes non-thermal motion. For reference, for an intrinsic gas temperature of <em>T</em>\u00a0= 10<sup>4</sup> K, an inferred effective temperature of <em>T</em><sub>eff</sub>\u00a0= 10<sup>5</sup> (10<sup>6</sup>) K implies an underlying bulk flow of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sigma _v^{\\rm bulk}\\approx 30$|</span> (90) \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>.</div>                        <a id=\"246049515\" scrollto-destination=\"246049515\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl6\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl6\" data-id=\"tbl6\"><span class=\"label\">Table 6.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of the best-fitting parameters (95 per cent confidence interval) for characterizing the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile under an expanding shell model.</p></div> </div><div spectrum\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$20.3^{+0.2}_{-0.2}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula 3.7540\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>3\u03c3\u20138\u03c3\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$16.2^{+3.4}_{-0.7}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn14\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn14\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>.<sup><em>a</em></sup> Values without errors indicate a prior specified by the nebular emission lines (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn15\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn15\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup> Relative velocity with respect to <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049515\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">To illustrate the impact of velocity smearing on the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile analysis, we first consider stacked spectra obtained over a large area along with the best-fitting model profiles (<em>top</em> panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>). The best-fitting parameters and the associated 95\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence intervals are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The large <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _\\nu ^2$|</span> values in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> show that an expanding shell model fails to provide a good fit for the high <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> stacked Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectra for both systems. A close examination of the profiles in the <em>top</em> panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a> shows that the best-fitting models with an uncharacteristically large intrinsic line width of \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> \u2248 500\u2013650 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> provide a poor fit to the blue peak of the northern and southern nebulae in System <em>A</em>. The best-fitting \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> is substantially broader than either what is seen in the nebular emission lines (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) or what is expected for the velocity dispersion in haloes of a comparable mass scale for the host galaxies (e.g. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm halo}\\lt 10^{12}\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot$|\u2060</span>; Trainor\u00a0&amp; Steidel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib132\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib132\" data-open=\"bib132\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). For System <em>B</em>, while the small <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _\\nu ^2$|</span> for the stacked spectrum from low-surface brightness regions suggests a good fit to the data, the model remains poorly constrained with large associated uncertainties due to the low <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> of the data. At the same time, the best-fitting shell model produces a relatively poor fit to the blue peak of high <em>S</em>/<em>N</em>, high-surface brightness regions, leading to a large <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _\\nu ^2$|\u2060</span>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To improve the precision and accuracy of the model constraints, we perform the profile analysis for the template spectra extracted from localized, small apertures presented in the <em>bottom</em> panels of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>. In addition, we adopt the observed nebular line width (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl5\" data-open=\"tbl5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) as a prior for modelling the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles. This is justified by the understanding that these Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons likely originate in the star-forming regions of the associated galaxies (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a> below). Specifically, we set \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u00a0= 100 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> for System <em>A</em> based on the observed FWHM of \u2248240 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> in galaxy <em>A</em>2, and \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub>\u00a0= 20 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> for System <em>B</em> based on the observed FWHM of \u224840 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> in galaxies <em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2. The best-fitting model profiles are shown in dotted and dash\u2013dotted curves and best-fitting parameters are presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. It is immediately clear that the resulting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi _\\nu ^2$|</span> is reduced substantially and the parameters are well constrained. In contrast, setting the same prior on \u03c3<sub><em>i</em></sub> when fitting the stacked spectra from larger apertures results in poor model fits with larger <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\chi ^2_\\nu$|</span> values (see Appendix). This again underscores the smearing effect on stacked Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles extracted from larger areas, which can significantly bias the constrained gas properties with the presence of velocity gradient and spatial variations in the line-emitting region. The best-fitting models also suggest that both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> consistently require a large neutral hydrogen column density, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N(\\hbox{H i})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}\\gtrsim 19$|</span> for explaining the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles from localized locations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because of the competing factors between spectral qualities (i.e. <em>S</em>/<em>N</em>) and velocity smearing, in addition to a strong degeneracy between different model parameters with modest <em>S</em>/<em>N</em> data, we continue the analysis with a focus on constraining the velocity field, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v$|\u2060</span>, across the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae. This is achieved by cross-correlating the best-fitting shell model for the template Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectra with each spaxel within the 3\u03c3 contours in both systems to measure velocity offsets at different locations. To optimize the cross-correlation analysis, we spatially smooth the data cube with a Gaussian filter of FHWM<sub>smooth</sub>\u00a0= 1 arcsec before extracting individual spectra. The resulting velocity maps are presented in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> for System <em>A</em> and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a> for System <em>B</em>. We also present de-lensed velocity maps of both nebulae in the source plane. We have also experimented with constraining the velocity gradient by fitting an asymmetric Gaussian function (e.g. see equation 1 of Leclercq et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2020</a>) to the red peak of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile from every spaxel within the 3\u03c3 contour in both systems, and we obtain a similar velocity gradient as shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig12\" data-open=\"fig12\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">12</a>. Our method utilizing the best-fitting model of the template spectra enables us to determine the systemic velocity offset \u0394<em>v</em> of the line-emitting gas in the frame of the nearby star-forming region, thereby connecting the nebulae with the associated star-forming regions.</p>                        <a id=\"246049519\" scrollto-destination=\"246049519\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig11\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 11.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/m_stab1041fig11.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&amp;Signature=bwjytzwVQMTyL1OQXFJh6ZSR7V95uG7s-gi-XsIHLJ5~QtwR8D7byuH161XKKcqJx8Ssx7H4JdHCz~iUllYCUerMj1AqlYwz3TTAvwWs8BfjylJKIYiJcbmuQiTe5B9PXs0Mt28qTkyiOHndjT73vj4kOiyVfbzBGv-QnSVm~A6RFtganxeKi-EJEVwJ70AL5FmhbdmiSM6PGevdjLR0AeDPmfdSkiT9G~mPtLed~edcHpeVzAUXbCwmg5Fa7LUpOPkotn0uGMwJZb48jyy~i878xk4WEImdsMP9bU7qMkQwCYHzGth3ssuoJg1a9k6xrzxHhEBhpSTytKWQw2nyhQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Column (1): velocity map of multiple images a, b, and c in System A, derived from cross-correlating the best-fitting shell model for the template spectrum (bottom-left panel of Fig.\u00a010) and spectra extracted from spaxels within the 3\u03c3 contours.
