Zero velocity corresponds to zsys\u00a0= 3.7540, which is the systemic redshift of B1/B2 derived from nebular emission lines Right-hand panel: de-lensed velocity map of image e in the source plane. The star symbols mark the position of B1/B2 determined from HST images (see Fig.\u00a08). The black arrow, same as in Column (1) of Fig.\u00a08, indicates the brightest pixel in image e that is included in the template spectrum.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig12.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/246049520/stab1041fig12.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig12.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"246049520\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/504/2/10.1093_mnras_stab1041/1/stab1041fig12.jpeg?Expires=1639262653&Signature=ZsoTb2izvM8xINiZ8RU4ZQxx3jpT3UeUv6-VTWVUOs1qriV8xAM4jgtdlGUKFRBK5VJ9-BAIwtSjb6Pyu5FjvbuFfpEf6BHb~767-9UXgicpDMcQdYu08gZzteAwuy8cOX2gvJrPbwkhp6Ql~OvpkWCRxJIbkZ1fYwUGJQGUuLnzNprJlxP47FD5NNVl-5XoJw9HweJBQBmPAQP27vpOPp8XU3RD0QrlAg4rG4vhWfL~s3XZo81vxR8SpUI1eesjxa1RVrBDv1vRK9CN2kQewa8Eo2EiMrbkOiKILuTiNKKqbVYkGgzr2uxb-qDg8kj2ZjR4inTzoCnIv8HIbn9xQQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=246049520&ar=6226641&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stab1041fig12.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Left-hand panel</em>: velocity map of image <em>e</em> in System <em>B</em>, derived from cross-correlating the best-fitting shell model for the template spectrum (<em>bottom-right</em> panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>) and spectra extracted from spaxels within the 3\u03c3 contour. Zero velocity corresponds to <em>z</em><sub>sys</sub>\u00a0= 3.7540, which is the systemic redshift of <em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2 derived from nebular emission lines <em>Right-hand panel</em>: de-lensed velocity map of image <em>e</em> in the source plane. The star symbols mark the position of <em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2 determined from <em>HST</em> images (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). The black arrow, same as in Column (<em>1</em>) of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, indicates the brightest pixel in image e that is included in the template spectrum.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our analysis of System <em>A</em> has uncovered a highly organized velocity field across the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting nebulae, with increasing velocity offset from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v\\approx 0$|</span> \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> at \u224811 pkpc south of galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v\\approx +250$|</span> \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> at the locations of these galaxies (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>). In the north, the velocity offset decreases from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v\\gtrsim +200$|</span> \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> at the location of galaxy <em>A</em>1 to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Delta \\, v\\approx -150$|</span> \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> at \u224813 pkpc north-west of <em>A</em>1. The inferred velocity offset shows that the line-emitting gas closest to the galaxies is receding from the galaxies. Different from the extended blue wings seen in ISM absorption lines, this velocity offset seen in Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission places the gas behind the star-forming region. The observed steep velocity gradient, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\Delta \\, v/\\Delta \\, r_\\perp | \\approx 22\\!-\\!27\\, \\, \\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}\\, {\\rm pkpc}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>, together with a large best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N(\\hbox{H i})$|</span> and an enhanced red peak in the Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile across the nebula supports a scenario in which high column density gas is driven outward from the galaxies to beyond 10 pkpc in projected distance into the low-density surroundings. Due to a lack of AGN activities (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.4</a>), the outflows are likely driven by star formation in these young galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">It is interesting that there exists an apparent gap in Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal between the northern and southern nebulae. One possible explanation for this gap is a reduced <em>N</em>(H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>) as a result of galaxy interactions. A lack of strong Ly\u2009\u03b1 absorber has been seen at projected distances of &lt;20 pkpc from an interacting galaxy pair at low redshift with an upper limit of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N({\\rm H\\,{i}})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}\\lesssim 13.7$|</span> (e.g. Johnson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). In the optically thin regime, we estimate a 2\u03c3 upper limit of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N(\\hbox{H i})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}\\lt 16.4$|</span> at \u22485 pkpc based on the observed 2\u03c3 upper limit in Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness and an assumption of 100\u00a0per\u2009cent escape fraction of ionizing photons from the galaxies. While at this limit, the gas would still be optically thick to Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons, we cannot rule out the possibility of a significantly lower <em>N</em>(H\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>). Other plausible explanations for the gap also include a lack of illumination from young stars due to anisotropic leakage of Ly\u2009\u03b1 and ionizing photons, and attenuation of Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal due to highly neutral, dusty gas in-between these galaxies (also see discussion in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6</a> below).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In contrast, System <em>B</em> exhibits distinct properties from System <em>A</em>. The Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebula appears to be distributed symmetrically around galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 with the peak intensity located close to star-forming regions. The inferred line-of-sight velocity offset of \u2248\u2212100 \u2009<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}$|</span> near the location of the galaxies, coupled with the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile, again supports an outflow scenario from the galaxies. The observed velocity gradient of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\Delta \\, v/\\Delta \\, r_\\perp | \\approx 20\\, \\, \\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}\\, {\\rm kpc}^{-1}$|</span> towards the outer edge of the nebula may be explained by a line-of-sight projection effect.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049524 id=\"246049524\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have shown that by accounting for spatial variations in the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles, we are able to determine the velocity field and constrain gas flows across the nebulae. Given the proximity of the line-emitting gas to star-forming galaxies and the relatively small velocity offset between gas and galaxies, we argue that the gas is being driven out of the star-forming regions at a modest speed. Specifically, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebula of System <em>B</em> exhibits a relatively symmetrical morphology with the peak of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission located close to the star-forming regions. This configuration is typical of low-mass LAEs at high redshifts (e.g. Wisotzki et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib141\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib141\" data-open=\"bib141\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Leclercq et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and suggests that gas flows outward from the star-forming regions into the low-density halo environment. At the same time, galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 share similar spectral and photometric properties (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>). The close proximity of these three galaxies suggest that they may share an interactive group environment and are part of a common CGM. The Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae are clearly offset to one side of the galaxies with the highest surface brightness regions bordering the continuum-emitting regions (see Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). While the star-forming regions contribute significantly to the extended Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission, the connection between the star-forming regions and the large-scale outflows remains uncertain.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We consider two plausible scenarios for the origin of the outflows. First, the northern nebula originates in gas flowing out of <em>A</em>1, while the southern nebula originates in gas flowing out of galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3. This is plausible if all three galaxies are capable of driving galactic scale super winds. Applying the conversion factor of Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), we estimate an unobscured SFR of \u224822, 5, and 4 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{ M}_\\odot \\, {\\rm yr}^{-1}$|</span> for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, respectively, based on the observed rest-frame UV absolute magnitudes <em>M</em><sub>1500</sub> presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. In the presence of dust, this observed <em>M</em><sub>1500</sub> and inferred SFR are likely lower limits to the intrinsic values. In addition, we estimate a total projected area based on the continuum regions determined by <span class=\"small-caps\">sextractor</span> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a>) and apply lensing magnification corrections based on the fine-tuned lens model (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a>). We find the intrinsic projected area of <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 to be \u224850, 11, and 11 pkpc<sup>2</sup>, respectively. For galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3, these are based on an average over all three images, <em>a, b</em>, and <em>c</em> after lensing magnification corrections. Combining the estimated unobscured SFR and projected area leads to an estimate of SFR per unit area of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gtrsim 0.4\\, \\mathrm{ M}_\\odot \\, {\\rm yr}^{-1}\\, {\\rm pkpc}^{-2}$|</span> in these individual galaxies. This exceeds the empirical threshold seen in driving galactic scale super winds in local starburst galaxies (e.g. Heckman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Alternatively, galaxy <em>A</em>1 may be the single dominant source driving the outflows seen in both the northern and southern nebulae. Apart from being the most massive galaxy with the highest SFR in the group, <em>A</em>1 also shows more extended blue wings in the low-ionization ISM absorption lines (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), suggesting the presence of galactic outflows that are more prominent than what is seen from the same line features in galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3. In this scenario where galaxy <em>A</em>1 is the origin of the outflows on both sides, the gap in Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission between the northern and southern nebulae is likely due to dusty outflow materials from galaxy <em>A</em>1 that cover the gap area along the line of sight.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A remaining question of the observed line-emitting nebulae is the origin of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons. As described earlier, multiple mechanisms can lead to Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission in diffuse gas, including cooling radiation, fluorescence powered by ionizing photons from either star-forming regions or AGN, and resonant scattering by neutral hydrogen gas (e.g. Hogan\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1987</a>; Gould\u00a0&amp; Weinberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Cantalupo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Faucher-Gigu\u00e8re et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Kollmeier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Hennawi\u00a0&amp; Prochaska <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Disentangling between different mechanisms that are responsible for the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals is challenging, especially when the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line is the only observable feature in the nebulae.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the two systems in our study, however, the observed spectral properties of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line enable us to rule out cooling radiation and photoionization due to the cosmic UV background radiation as a dominant mechanism for powering the observed emission. Specifically, radiatively cooled gas is expected to condense and sink through the hot ambient medium, resulting in infall, and the majority of the photons will travel through the infalling clouds before escaping the medium (e.g. Faucher-Gigu\u00e8re et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The expectation of an enhanced blue-peak from infalling gas in inconsistent with the observations. In addition, the expected Ly\u2009\u03b1 fluorescence signal from cosmic UV background alone is low with surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\lesssim 10^{-19}\\, \\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$|</span> (e.g. Kollmeier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We therefore proceed with considerations of the two remaining scenarios: (1) Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons arising as a result of fluorescence powered by ionizing photons from star-forming regions and (2) Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons produced in the galaxies and resonantly scattered by neutral hydrogen in the nebulae. The first scenario requires a non-zero escape fraction of ionizing photons from the galaxies, while the second scenario corresponds to the shell model analysis described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.3</a>. Here, we also discuss the implications of these scenarios.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049531 id=\"246049531\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission from recombination radiation and implications for the escape fraction of ionizing radiation from star-forming galaxies</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We first consider the possibility that the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals are powered by <em>in\u00a0situ</em> star formation directly underneath the nebulae. Available deep <em>HST</em> F606W image places strong constraints on the rest-frame UV continuum flux at the location of the nebulae. Using the integrated Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }=(2.15\\pm 0.07)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$[3.49\\pm 0.08]\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|\u2060</span>) for the northern (southern) nebula of System <em>A</em>, we infer an SFR of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 1.1 \\, (2.3) \\, {\\rm M}_\\odot \\, \\mathrm{yr^{-1}}$|</span> based on a conversion factor of Ly\u2009\u03b1/H\u2009\u03b1\u00a0= 8.7 (Hayes <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, and references therein) and the H\u2009\u03b1\u2013SFR relation of Kennicutt\u00a0&amp; Evans (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). From the inferred SFR, we derive the expected apparent magnitude in the <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> bandpass (corresponding to 1500 \u00c5 in the rest frame at <em>z</em> \u2248 3) of <em>AB</em>(<em>F</em>606<em>W</em>) \u2248 27.3 (26.5) using the FUV flux-SFR relation of Madau\u00a0&amp; Dickinson (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) for the underlying star-forming regions in the northern (southern) nebula. The inferred <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> magnitude is roughly more than 2 mag brighter than the 2\u03c3 detection limit in the <em>F</em>606<em>W</em> bandpass (<em>AB</em>(F606W) \u2248 29 within an aperture of 0.5 arcsec in diameter), but no flux is detected at the location of the nebulae away from the galaxies. While we consider <em>in\u00a0situ</em> star formation an unlikely scenario for powering the Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals, we cannot rule out the possibility that dust obscurations may have played a role in blocking the FUV photons along the line of sight. Deeper imaging data at submillimetre are needed for constraining the effect of dust. In the following discussion, we proceed with considerations of external sources for powering the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For photoionization by the nearby galaxies, the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 intensity is connected to the incident ionizing radiation field and the discussion often involves considerations of two different regimes, optically thin versus optically thick gas. For the purpose of our study, both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> consistently require a large <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$N(\\hbox{H i})$|\u2060</span>, exceeding <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N(\\hbox{H i})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}\\approx 19$|</span> (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl6\" data-open=\"tbl6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>), for explaining the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 profile. We therefore consider only optically thick regime in the subsequent discussion.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">In optically thick regime, ionization occurs in the surface of a cloud illuminated by the ionizing source and roughly 66\u00a0per\u2009cent of all ionizing photons are converted into Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons through recombination cascades in the surface layer (i.e. \u03b7<sub>B</sub>\u00a0= 0.66) (Osterbrock\u00a0&amp; Ferland <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). The surface brightness of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission is connected to ionizing photon flux according to <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1619443115259\" content-id=\"update1619443115259\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\mathrm{SB_{Ly\\alpha }} &amp;=&amp; f_g\\, f_{\\rm esc}\\, \\frac{\\eta _{\\mathrm{B}}\\, h\\, \\nu _{\\mathrm{Ly\\alpha }}}{(1+z)^4}\\frac{\\Phi }{\\pi } \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp; = &amp; 3.2\\times 10^{-18} f_g\\, f_{\\rm esc}\\left(\\frac{1+z}{4.0}\\right)^{-4} \\left(\\frac{D}{{\\rm 10\\, pkpc}}\\right)^{-2} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp; &amp; \\left(\\frac{\\Phi _0}{10^7\\, {\\rm s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}}\\right) \\ \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}} ,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(7)</span></div>where <em>f<sub>g</sub></em> is the geometric correction coefficient to account for partial illumination of the nebula and redistribution of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons, <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> is the fraction of ionizing photons that escape the galaxies, <em>D</em> is the distance of the cloud from the ionizing source, and \u03a6<sub>0</sub> is the ionizing photon flux at a distance of 1\u00a0kpc from the source. In principle, comparing the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness with the expected ionizing radiation field from the SED analysis of the galaxies constrains <em>f</em><sub>g</sub> and <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> based on equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update1619443115259\"></span><a href=\"#update1619443115259\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a>). In practice, uncertainties in the inferred galaxy spectra are large. Therefore, it is not trivial to obtain accurate constraints for <em>f<sub>g</sub></em> and <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub>.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For System <em>A</em>, we estimate the total ionizing photon fluxes from <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 using the best-fitting <span class=\"small-caps\">Bagpipes</span> model spectra and find, respectively, \u03a6<sub>0</sub> \u2248 3.4\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>8</sup>, 8.1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>7</sup>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$5.1\\times 10^7\\, {\\rm s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|</span> at <em>D</em>\u00a0= 10 pkpc. Assuming <em>f</em><sub>g</sub>\u00a0= 0.5 from numerical simulations (e.g. Cantalupo et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Kollmeier et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm esc}\\lt 10{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> as a fiducial upper limit for ionizing photon escape fraction (e.g. Chen, Prochaska\u00a0&amp; Gnedin <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Vanzella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib135\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib135\" data-open=\"bib135\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Grazian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), the observed peak Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.3\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (the 6\u03c3 contour in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>) implies a distance limit of <em>D</em> &lt; 8.5 pkpc from <em>A</em>1 and <em>D</em> &lt; 3.3 pkpc from <em>A</em>3. Adopting the low-intensity contour of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> would increase the distance limit by 40\u00a0per\u2009cent to <em>D</em> &lt; 12 pkpc from <em>A</em>1 and <em>D</em> &lt; 4.6 pkpc from <em>A</em>3. The observed extent of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission of \u227310 pkpc (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>) therefore requires <em>A</em>1 to be the dominant source of ionizing photons with an escape fraction <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sim 10{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Current observations suggest that the escape fraction of ionizing photons from massive (&gt;<em>L</em><sub>*</sub>) galaxies at <em>z</em> \u2248 3 is much smaller than <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$10{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> (e.g. Grazian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The inferred large log<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(\\hbox{H i}$|\u2060</span>) based on Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles also suggests that <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> is likely to be small. In addition, in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.2</a>, we show that resonant scattering of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons produced in the star-forming regions can account for the full extent of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae. We therefore conclude that recombination radiation from photoionized gas alone is unlikely to dominate the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signal in System <em>A</em>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We repeat the same exercise for System <em>B</em>. Due to the smaller physical scale of System <em>B</em>, we estimate the ionizing photon flux at a distance of <em>D</em>\u00a0= 1 pkpc. Using the best-fitting <span class=\"small-caps\">Bagpipes</span> model spectra, we obtain the total ionizing photon flux from <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 combined to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Phi \\approx 1.4\\times 10^8\\, {\\rm s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|</span> at 1 pkpc. The observed surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.5\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (the 8\u03c3 contour in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>) leads to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(f_{\\rm g}f_{\\rm esc})\\approx 33{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, or <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$f_{\\rm esc}=66{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> assuming <em>f</em><sub>g</sub>\u00a0= 0.5. At the limit of <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> &lt; 1, we infer the distance limit of <em>D</em> &lt; 1.2 pkpc for the high-intensity contours. With the low-intensity surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (the 3\u03c3 contour in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>), the inferred distance limit is increased to <em>D</em> &lt; 2 pkpc. Because the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission extends to \u2273 4 pkpc in the source plane (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>), we conclude that recombination radiation from photoionized gas alone <em>cannot</em> explain all of the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons away from the galaxies in System <em>B</em>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049537 id=\"246049537\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission from scattering and implications for dust attenuation</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Given the star-forming nature of the galaxies in both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>, we now consider the scenario in which the Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons are produced in the star-forming ISM of the galaxies and resonantly scattered through the spatially extended nebulae. Using the estimated SFR in the 16\u00a0per\u2009cent\u201384\u00a0per\u2009cent confidence interval for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3 (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), we infer a total intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\rm int}_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }/(10^{44}\\, {\\rm erg}\\, {\\rm s}^{-1})=1.46$|</span>\u20131.65, 0.17\u20130.19, and 0.21\u20130.26 for galaxies <em>A</em>1, <em>A</em>2, and <em>A</em>3, respectively, using the conversion factor of Ly\u2009\u03b1/H\u2009\u03b1\u00a0= 8.7 (Hayes <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, and references therein) and the H\u2009\u03b1\u2013SFR relation of Kennicutt\u00a0&amp; Evans (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). For System <em>B</em>, the same exercise leads to an intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\rm int}_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }=$|</span>(1.2\u20132.1)<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\times 10^{42}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> for galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2 combined.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">While these star-forming galaxies may be intrinsically luminous in Ly\u2009\u03b1, we expect that a large fraction of these Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons are unable to escape the ISM due to a substantial amount of dust attenuation. We obtain an empirical estimate of the attenuation factor <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$k_{\\rm dust}=1 - L_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }^{\\rm obs}/L_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }^{\\rm int}$|</span> based on the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.15\\times 10^{42}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> for the northern nebula and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.43\\times 10^{42}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> for the southern nebula, and the intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity from star-forming regions described above. Attributing the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission of the northern (southern) nebula to the scattering of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons from galaxy <em>A</em>1 (galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3), we estimate <em>k</em><sub>dust</sub> to be <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 98{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 92{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> for the northern and southern nebula, respectively.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Following the optically thick prescription from equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update1619443115259\"></span><a href=\"#update1619443115259\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">7</a>) and replacing ionizing photon flux with Ly\u2009\u03b1 photon flux \u03a6<sub>Ly\u2009\u03b1</sub>, we can now connect the Ly\u2009\u03b1 scattering surface brightness to <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\rm int}_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }$|</span> following <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"\" content-id=\"\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\mathrm{SB_{Ly\\alpha }} &amp;=&amp; \\frac{h\\, \\nu _{\\mathrm{Ly\\alpha }}}{(1+z)^4}\\frac{\\Phi _{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }}{\\pi } \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp;=&amp; \\frac{h\\, \\nu _{\\mathrm{Ly\\alpha }}}{(1+z)^4}\\frac{(1-k_{\\rm dust})\\, L^{\\rm int}_{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }}{4\\pi ^2\\, D^2\\, h\\, \\nu _{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div></div><div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update1619456604279\" content-id=\"update1619456604279\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp; = &amp; 2.4\\times 10^{-18} \\left(\\frac{1+z}{4.0}\\right)^{-4} \\left(\\frac{D}{10\\, {\\rm pkpc}}\\right)^{-2} \\nonumber \\\\\r\n&amp; &amp; \\frac{(1-k_{\\rm dust})\\, L^{\\rm int}_{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }}{10^{42}\\, {\\rm erg}\\, {\\rm s}^{-1}}\\ \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}.\r\n\\end{eqnarray*}$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(8)</span></div>Equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update1619456604279\"></span><a href=\"#update1619456604279\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">8</a>) leads to a distance estimate of <em>D</em><sub>north</sub> \u2248 14 pkpc between the northern nebula and galaxy <em>A</em>1 for an observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (the 3\u03c3 contour in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), an intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\rm int}_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }=(1.46$|</span>\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.65)\\times 10^{44}\\, {\\rm erg}\\, {\\rm s}^{-1}$|</span> for <em>A</em>1, and an attenuation factor of 98\u00a0per\u2009cent. At higher intensity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.3\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (the 6\u03c3 contour in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>), the distance is reduced to \u224810 pkpc. The inferred distance range is fully consistent with the extent of the northern nebula relative to <em>A</em>1. In addition, the estimated amount of dust attenuation agrees with <em>A<sub>V</sub></em> \u2248 0.7 mag inferred from the SED analysis presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.2</a> (see also Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>). Based on the Calzetti et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>) extinction law for starburst galaxies, the estimated stellar extinction of <em>A<sub>V</sub></em> \u2248 0.7 mag corresponds to an extinction magnitude of <em>A</em><sub>1215</sub> \u2248 5.2 mag for the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission line, or <em>k</em><sub>dust</sub> \u2248 99\u00a0per\u2009cent for the Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons. It suggests that resonant scattering alone can fully account for the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 brightness in the northern nebula.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For the southern nebula, galaxies <em>A</em>2 and <em>A</em>3 together contribute to a total intrinsic Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\rm int}_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }=3.8$|</span>\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$4.5\\times 10^{43}\\, {\\rm erg}\\, {\\rm s}^{-1}$|\u2060</span>. Adopting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$k_{\\rm dust}=92{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> leads to a distance estimate of <em>D</em><sub>south</sub> \u2248 10 pkpc for the high-intensity region and <em>D</em><sub>south</sub> \u2248 15 pkpc for the low-intensity region between galaxies <em>A</em>2/<em>A</em>3 and the southern nebula. Similarly, the estimated size is consistent with the observed extent of the southern nebula (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>). Although the dust attenuation of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$92{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> is in tension with the estimated <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$k_{\\rm dust}\\approx 99{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> based on the SED analysis, we argue that a possible contribution of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons from galaxy <em>A</em>1, together with uncertainties in <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.1</a>) and <em>k</em><sub>dust</sub> in an inhomogeneous, clumpy medium could account for the observed extent of Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals in the southern nebula (e.g. Neufeld <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1991</a>; Hansen\u00a0&amp; Oh <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For galaxies <em>B</em>1 and <em>B</em>2, the uncertainty in <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$k_{\\rm dust}=1 - L_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }^{\\rm obs}/L_{\\rm Ly\\alpha }^{\\rm int}$|</span> is larger, ranging between \u224820 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$50{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Meanwhile, uncertainties in <em>A<sub>V</sub></em> are also larger, lying in the range <em>A<sub>V</sub></em> \u2248 0.05\u20130.25 for <em>B</em>1 and <em>A<sub>V</sub></em> \u2248 0.5\u20130.7 for <em>B</em>2 (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>), corresponding to a wide range of dust attenuation of \u224830\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$99{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|</span> for Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons, in agreement with the empirical <em>k</em><sub>dust</sub> of \u224820\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$50{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>. Adopting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$k_{\\rm dust}=50{{\\ \\rm per\\ cent}}$|\u2060</span>, equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update1619456604279\"></span><a href=\"#update1619456604279\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">8</a>) leads to a distance estimate of <em>D</em> \u2248 3 pkpc between galaxies <em>B</em>1/<em>B</em>2 and the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 intensity peak of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$7.5\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (the 8\u03c3 contour in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>). At <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathrm{SB_{Ly\\alpha }}=2.8\\times 10^{-18} \\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (the 3\u03c3 contour in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>), we estimate a distance of \u22485 pkpc, which agrees well with the observed extent of the nebula.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The above exercise shows that resonant scattering of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons produced in nearby star-forming regions may be sufficient for explaining the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals in both systems without invoking additional emission sources. This is in contrast with the recombination radiation scenario discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec6-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">6.1</a>. It shows that even at 100\u00a0per\u2009cent escape fraction of ionizing photons, recombination is insufficient for explaining the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux in System <em>B</em> and that it would require an escape fraction of \u223c10\u00a0per\u2009cent from <em>A</em>1 for recombination to contribute significantly to the emission signal.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049544 id=\"246049544\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-3>6.3 Systematics in interpreting the spatial and spectral profiles of the nebulae</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Due to the clumpy nature of line-emitting gas, the surface brightness profile of extended nebulae is subject to the spatial variation of lensing magnification and its associated uncertainties in the image plane. In principle, gravitational lensing conserves surface brightness of a light-emitting source. However, the conservation of surface brightness does not apply when the lensed image of the source is not resolved in the data. In our study, the spatial resolution is limited by the size of the seeing disc in ground-based observations. We see that the source-plane image reconstructed from less magnified regions appear to be fainter (e.g. image <em>a</em> of System <em>A</em>) than those reconstructed from more highly magnified images (e.g. images <em>b</em> and <em>c</em> of System <em>A</em>). This surface brightness discrepancy suggests that the individual clumps, even after being magnified by the cluster lens, are still not resolved by the data. Apart from the decrease of surface brightness in image <em>a</em> of System <em>A</em> as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">5.1</a>, we also see discrepancy of Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness near critical curves where the magnification factor is much larger (e.g. in System <em>B</em>, the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitting region that straddles the critical curve between images <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> shows the highest apparent surface brightness across the whole lensed arc). Adopting \u03bc \u2248 20 as the fiducial magnification factor near the critical curves, we estimate that the clump size should be \u22721.5\u00a0kpc in order for the gas clumps to remain unresolved in lensed images recorded under 1 arcsec seeing. This upper limit is in agreement with clump sizes of cold gas in the CGM constrained in absorption studies (e.g. Zahedy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib146\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib146\" data-open=\"bib146\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). Furthermore, small-scale substructures in the lens can also introduce additional perturbations to the lensing effect across an extended source (e.g. the unusually large magnification at the location of image <em>B</em>1<em>e</em>, see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a>). In order to accurately quantify the intrinsic surface brightness distribution of extended and clumpy sources in strong lensing fields, a better understanding of the systematic uncertainties of lensing magnification as a function of image position is necessary.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Systematic uncertainties also remain in the shell model analysis on the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profiles and the interpretation of the velocity gradient derived from spatially varying Ly\u2009\u03b1 lines in both Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>. For example, our shell model does not include radiative transfer effects inside the galaxies, which would reshape the input Ly\u2009\u03b1 line from a single Gaussian into a double-peaked profile. This provides a likely explanation for the large redshift observed at the location of the continuum regions in System <em>A</em> (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>). However, a clumpy ISM may also be transparent to Lya photons, resulting in a wider Gaussian linewidth instead. In addition, because the signal strength is dominated by the much stronger red peak in the Ly\u2009\u03b1 line (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig10\" data-open=\"fig10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">10</a>), the inferred velocity offset could simply represent a shift in the location of the red peak. The observed blueshifted velocity with increasing projected distance in System <em>A</em> (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig11\" data-open=\"fig11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">11</a>) may also be explained in part due to line-of-sight projection of a uniformly expanding sphere. While a complete 3D radiative transfer model to consider different possible cloud geometry is beyond the scope of this paper, an initial exercise that explores different cloud geometry and velocity field shows that the emergent spectrum will be increasingly blueshifted (redshifted) from the centre to the edge of the cloud with decelerating (accelerating) gas expansions. We show one example of such exercise in Appendix\u00a0\u00a0<a class=\"js-jumplink\" href=\"#sec12\">D</a>, where we extract the emergent Ly\u2009\u03b1 line profile as a function of projected distance from the centre of a spherical cloud that is undergoing expansion with an accelerating or decelerating velocity field. We therefore argue that System <em>A</em> is likely decelerating while System <em>B</em> is accelerating as the gas move outward from the star-forming regions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In summary, the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission morphology in System <em>A</em> clearly indicates a more complicated gas geometry than what is assumed in current radiative transfer simulations. In addition, significant uncertainties remain in terms of the origin and the spatial distribution of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission sources, the effect of local ISM on the Ly\u2009\u03b1 spectra emergent from the star-forming regions prior to the scattering of large-scale gas in the CGM, as well as the effect of dust and gas clumpiness. All of these factors can alter the shape of the emerging line profile, the surface brightness profile, and the velocity gradient of Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission in an extended gas cloud. A more sophisticated radiative transfer model is needed to fully explore the parameter space.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049548 id=\"246049548\" class=\"section-title js-splitscreen-section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Combining the strong cluster lensing power with deep wide-field integral field spectroscopic data, we have carried out a detailed analysis of two giant Ly\u2009\u03b1 arcs to spatially and spectrally resolve gas flows around two active star-forming regions at <em>z</em> &gt; 3. Both Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae are found to be spatially offset from the associated star-forming region and both exhibit a double-peaked profile with a significantly enhanced red peak that indicates expansion/outflowing motions. One of the arcs with Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$3.7\\times 10^{-18}\\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, detected at the 3\u03c3 level of significance, stretches over 1 arcmin around the Einstein radius of the cluster, resolving the velocity field of the line-emitting gas on sub-kpc scales around a group of three star-forming galaxies of 0.3\u2013<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.6\\, L_*$|</span> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038. Based on a lens model constructed from deep <em>HST</em> images, the de-magnified source-plane Ly\u2009\u03b1 image exhibits a symmetric double-lobe structure of \u224830 pkpc across, encompassing the galaxy group. The total integrated Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux across the nebula is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(6.5\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{-17}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|</span> after correcting lensing magnifications, corresponding to a total Ly\u2009\u03b1 luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }=(5.2\\pm 0.1)\\times 10^{42} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> at <em>z</em> \u2248 3.038. The second arc with Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$2.8\\times 10^{-18}\\, \\mathrm{erg \\, s^{-1} \\, cm^{-2} \\, arcsec^{-2}}$|</span> (3\u03c3) spans 15 arcsec in size, roughly centred around a pair of low-mass dwarf Ly\u2009\u03b1 emitters of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\approx 0.03\\, L_*$|</span> at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754. The total integrated Ly\u2009\u03b1 flux is <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$(7.4\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{-18}\\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}}$|\u2060</span>, corresponding to a total luminosity of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{{\\rm Ly}\\alpha }=(9.8\\pm 0.2)\\times 10^{41} \\, {\\rm erg\\, s^{-1}}$|</span> at <em>z</em> \u2248 3.754. Here, we summarize the main findings of our study:</p><ol class=\"number\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">A strong variation in the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness is clearly seen across both nebulae, suggesting large spatial fluctuations in the underlying gas properties. While the nebulae at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.038 is split into northern and southern lobes bracketing the group of luminous star-forming galaxies, the one at <em>z</em>\u00a0= 3.754 appears to be more symmetrically distributed around the associated low-mass galaxies.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Spatial variations in the kinematics profile of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission line are also detected in both nebulae, revealing highly organized velocity fields across the nebulae. We show that such spatial variations, if unaccounted for in integrated Ly\u2009\u03b1 profiles, may lead to biased results in constraining the underlying gas kinematics. By applying a simple expanding shell model to the spatially varying Ly\u2009\u03b1 line, we infer a large velocity gradient of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$|\\Delta \\, v/\\Delta \\, r_\\perp | \\approx 22-27\\, \\, \\rm {km\\, s}^{-1}\\, {\\rm pkpc}^{-1}$|</span> and high neutral hydrogen column density of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\log \\, N(\\hbox{H i})/{\\rm cm}^{-2}\\gtrsim 19.5$|</span> for both nebulae. The result supports a scenario in which high column density gas is driven outward from the galaxies to beyond 10 pkpc in projected distance into the low-density surroundings.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Combining known star formation properties of the galaxies and the observed extent and surface brightness of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 signals, we show that the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons likely originate from a combination of resonant scattering of Ly\u2009\u03b1 photons from the nearby star-forming regions and recombination radiation due to escaping ionizing photons, although the relative contribution of these two mechanisms cannot be accurately determined with the current data.</p></li></ol><p class=\"chapter-para\">Both nebulae provide clear-cut examples of gas outflows that are thought to be widespread at high redshift and may be responsible for metal enrichment of the Ly\u2009\u03b1 forest in general. While the hydrogen Ly\u2009\u03b1 line, being the strongest emission line in diffuse, photoionized gas, enables sensitive studies of spatially extended outflows beyond active star-forming regions, large uncertainties remain due to the resonant nature of this transition. Future observations targeting non-resonant transitions, such as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[O ii]}\\lambda \\lambda 3727, \\, 3730$|\u2060</span>, H\u03b2\u03bb4863, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[O iii]}\\lambda 5008$|\u2060</span>, and H\u03b1\u03bb6565, within the line-emitting nebulae will provide the necessary discriminating power to resolve the degeneracy between different physical parameters. Based on the observed Ly\u2009\u03b1 surface brightness in Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> and under the assumption that the Ly\u2009\u03b1 emission arises from recombination radiation of photoionized gas, we estimate the expected H\u2009\u03b1 and H\u2009\u03b2 surface brightness to be approximately 3 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1\\times 10^{-19}\\, \\rm erg \\, s^{-1}\\, cm^{-2}\\, arcsec^{-2}$|\u2060</span>, respectively. The <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[O iii]}\\lambda 5008$|</span> line is expected to be between 3 and 10\u00a0times brighter than H\u2009\u03b2 in photoionized, low-metallicity gas (e.g. Kewley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2019</a>). While the H\u2009\u03b1 line is redshifted out of the detection window with existing near-infrared spectrographs on the ground, it is possible to detect H\u03b2\u03bb4863 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\hbox{[O iii]}\\lambda 5008$|</span> lines in under \u224820\u00a0h, within the reach of current observing facilities. We therefore argue that follow-up near-infrared integral field observations, targeting rest-frame optical, non-resonant lines in known Ly\u2009\u03b1 nebulae, will greatly improve the physical constraints of gas flows around distant star-forming galaxies.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=246049552 id=\"246049552\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title js-splitscreen-backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We thank Erin Boettcher, Fakhri Zahedy, Claude-Andr\u00e9 Faucher-Gigu\u00e8re, and Irina Zhuravleva for helpful discussions. ascl:1611.003</div>.</p><!--citationLinks: case 2--><div class=\"citation-links\"><p class=\"citation-links-compatibility\"><span class=\"google-scholar-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec9>APPENDIX A: LENS CONSTRAINTS AND PARAMETERS</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA1\" data-open=\"tblA1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>, we list the coordinates of all multiple images used as constraints in our lens 1\u00a0</td><td>\u22128.803112\u00a0</td><td>6.0106\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>26<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>181.551211\u00a0</td><td>\u22128.803668\u00a0</td><td>6.0106\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn16\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn16\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. We adopt the multiple image identifications from Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), while excluding image systems 2, 7, 13, 21, 24, and 27 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a> for detailed discussions). We rename their image system 11 to be <em>A</em>2, and add <em>A</em>31 and <em>A</em>32 (the north and south substructures of <em>A</em>3). Similarly, we rename image system 14 to be <em>B</em>1, and add <em>B</em>2 (the fainter structure near <em>B</em>1 at the same redshift). We also update redshifts for <em>A</em>2, <em>A</em>3, <em>B</em>1, and <em>B</em>2 to be their best-fitting values from fitting the observed emission lines (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>). For the fiducial model, we use all images listed except for <em>A</em>31, <em>A</em>32, and <em>B</em>2. For the fine-tuned model, we only use systems <em>A</em>2, <em>A</em>31, <em>A</em>32, <em>B</em>1, and <em>B</em>2, excluding all other lensed systems, in order to optimize the model specifically for <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049566\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblA1\" data-id=\"tblA1\"><span class=\"label\">Table A1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Coordinates and redshifts of multiple images included for lens modelling.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span 1\u00a0</td><td>\u22128.803112\u00a0</td><td>6.0106\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>26<em>b</em>\u00a0</td><td>181.551211\u00a0</td><td>\u22128.803668\u00a0</td><td>6.0106\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn16\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn16\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. We adopt the multiple image identifications from Caminha et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), while excluding image systems 2, 7, 13, 21, 24, and 27 (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">3</a> for detailed discussions). We rename their image system 11 to be <em>A</em>2, and add <em>A</em>31 and <em>A</em>32 (the north and south substructures of <em>A</em>3). Similarly, we rename image system 14 to be <em>B</em>1, and add <em>B</em>2 (the fainter structure near <em>B</em>1 at the same redshift). We also update redshifts for <em>A</em>2, <em>A</em>3, <em>B</em>1, and <em>B</em>2 to be their best-fitting values from fitting the observed emission lines (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4</a>). For the fiducial model, we use all images listed except for <em>A</em>31, <em>A</em>32, and <em>B</em>2. For the fine-tuned model, we only use systems <em>A</em>2, <em>A</em>31, <em>A</em>32, <em>B</em>1, and <em>B</em>2, excluding all other lensed systems, in order to optimize the model specifically for <em>A</em> and <em>B</em>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049566\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                        <a id=\"246049567\" scrollto-destination=\"246049567\"></a>\r\n<div class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Note</em>. Positions x and y are relative to the position of the BCG at RA\u00a0= 181.550648\u00b0 and Dec.\u00a0= \u22128.800952\u00b0, with positive offsets point to west and north. The first and second cluster-scale PIEMD haloes, external shear, and galaxy members are fixed to their best-fitting values from the fiducial model, as listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblA2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblA2\" data-open=\"tblA2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/246049568\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=246049569 id=\"246049569\" class=\"appendix-title js-splitscreen-appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec10>APPENDIX B: PHOTOMETRY FOR INDIVIDUAL IMAGES OF SYSTEMS <em>A</em> AND <em>B</em></h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a>, we presented the photometric magnitudes of galaxies in Systems <em>A</em> and <em>B</em> after correcting the lensing magnification and averaging among multiple images. Here in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tblB1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tblB1\" data-open=\"tblB1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">B1</a>, we list the direct measurements from the data for each individual images without correcting for lensing effect. Note that the Galactic extinction is corrected for each bandpass.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2002</p>                        <a id=\"246049573\" scrollto-destination=\"246049573\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tblB1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tblB1\" data-id=\"tblB1\"><span class=\"label\">Table B1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Photometry from <em>HST</em> data, directly measured for each individual image without correcting for lensing magnification. The foreground Galactic extinction is corrected (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec js-xref-sec\">4.1</a> for details).</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-tblfn19\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn19\" class=\"footnote\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes</em>.<sup><em>a</em></sup> 2\u03c3 UV flux upper limit, averaged among the <em>F</em>225<em>W, F</em>275<em>W</em>, and<em>F</em>336<em>W</em> bandpasses.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-tblfn20\"></span><div content-id=\"tblfn20\"
